Name: Loaded Pistol
About: This cocktail by Erick Castro the co-founder of San Diego’s Polite Provisions uses grasshopper salt as a rim.This recipe originally appeared as part of “Infused Salts Are the Next Big Cocktail Ingredients.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir for 30 seconds. Strain into double Old Fashioned glass over a large ice cube. Garnish with sprinkle of grasshopper salt. *Grasshopper salt: In a blender add 1/2 cup flaky sea salt and 2 tsp dehydrated grasshoppers. Set blender to pulse and blend for 7-12 seconds or until grasshoppers and salt are well-mixed. Store and seal grasshopper salt in airtight container.
Ingredients: Mezcal;Sweet vermouth;Strega;Grapefruit bitters

Name: Rich Table
About: This cocktail by Morgan Schick the creative director of San Francisco’s Bon Vivants and Trick Dog uses infused salt as a garnish. This recipe originally appeared as part of “Infused Salts Are the Next Big Cocktail Ingredients.”
HowToMake: Rim a highball glass with pinot noir sea salt. Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a highball over fresh ice. Top with club soda. *Doug fir vodka: Add 16 oz Absolut Elyx vodka and 15 g fir tips into container and blend well. Let sit for 2 days. Strain through coffee filter. **Shiso-avocado syrup: Roast 2 avocado pits at 200 degrees F until shells start to dry out. Let cool peel and chop into quarters. In a pot toast pits along with 3/4 oz black peppercorns. Add 14 oz white sugar and 14 oz water bring to a boil then let simmer. Add 1/3 oz red shiso leaves and remove from heat. Steep for 30 minutes and strain.
Ingredients: Doug fir vodka;Martini & Rossi Riserva Speciale Ambrato vermouth;Ancho Reyes chile liqueur;Shiso-avocado syrup;Fresh lemon juice;Club soda to top;Pinot noir sea salt rim

Name: Hot Like Kohli
About: This take on a Spicy Margarita by Mikey Belasco the lead bartender at New York City’s GupShup yields herbal and floral notes. This recipe originally appeared as part of “Infused Salts Are the Next Big Cocktail Ingredients.”
HowToMake: Rim a rocks glass with chile-salt mix. Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into prepared glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a lemon wheel. *Green-chile-infused batch of tequila mezcal and pear cordial: In a 32 oz Mason jar add 12 oz Tromba blanco tequila 6 oz El Silencio mezcal 6 oz pear cordial 5 small whole green chiles and 5 small green chiles sliced down middle with seeds exposed. (When handling chiles use plastic gloves.) Seal and let sit for 24 hours then fine-strain to remove seeds. **1 oz Matcha-cilantro-mint simple syrup: Add 1 oz simple syrup and 1 tbsp matcha powder into medium-size pot at medium heat and stir for 2-3 minutes. Add 1 pinch of loose chopped cilantro stems removed and 1 pinch of mint leaves stems removed. Simmer for 12-15 minutes. Pour into large container and place container in an ice bath for 15 minutes then let sit at room temperature for 30 minutes. Fine-strain to remove leaves and powder residue. Can keep refrigerated for 1 month. ***Chile-salt mix: Combine 8 oz Marhaba Tajín powder 4 oz kosher salt 2 dried Thai Bird chiles 1 tbsp sugar 1 tsp ground pasilla negro chiles and 1/2 oz fresh lime juice.
Ingredients: Green-chile-infused tequila mezcal and pear cordial;Matcha-cilantro-mint simple syrup;Fresh lime juice;Chile tincture

Name: Paloma Milk Punch
About: This drink by Aaron Deary at Philadelphia’s R&D is textured subtly herbal fresh and vaguely familiar—a Paloma after a day of self-care and nip-tucking. With tequila hoja santa Chinese five-spice tarragon grapefruit coconut milk and club soda he admits that calling it a Paloma is a bit of a stretch. But without spices Deary says it wouldn’t be a milk punch either. “It’s about taking something that people recognize and combining it with something they’ve never seen before” he says. This recipe originally appeared as part of “In Pursuit of the Perfect Dairy-Free Milk Punch.”
HowToMake: Serves 10. In a Lexan or large shallow container combine tequila both liqueurs hoja santa and tarragon tea and spice mixture. Infuse for 2 hours then strain out spices. Return liquid to container. In a jug or container with a spout combine lime juice and grapefruit juice. Heat coconut milk to 170 degrees F stirring constantly. Transfer hot coconut milk to a jug or container with a spout. Very slowly and simultaneously pour both coconut milk and citrus over entire surface of punch. Milk will break initially then become cloudy. After 30 minutes a layer of curds should form. Rest punch at room temperature for 1 hour then transfer to a refrigerator for 1 hour. Strain punch through cheesecloth then through coffee filters or a Superbag and refrigerate. Pour approximately 3 oz into a rocks glass over a large ice cube. Top with club soda. *Hoja santa and tarragon tea: Bring 1 L filtered water to boil. Add 1 large hoja santa leaf 5 tarragon sprigs and simmer for 20 minutes. Strain through fine-mesh strainer and chill in ice bath. **Spice mixture: Toast 1 3/4 oz cinnamon sticks 1 oz star anise pods 1/3 oz Szechuan peppercorns 1/3 oz whole cloves 1 oz green cardamom pods and 1/3 oz fennel seeds in a pan over medium heat until fragrant for no more than 5 minutes. (Start with cinnamon and star anise then add rest as they toast quickly.) Remove and let cool.
Ingredients: Blanco tequila;Giffard crème de pamplemousse rose liqueur;Ancho Reyes verde chile liqueur;Hoja santa and tarragon tea;Spice mixture;Fresh lime juice;Grapefruit juice;Coconut milk;Club soda to top

Name: Hit Me Baby One More Gluhwein
About: Between the ode to Britney and the subtly sweet aromatic liqueur that defines the flavor profile of this recipe from Townshend’s distillery in Portland Ore. this easy mulled wine riff is a cold-weather crowd pleaser. Thanks to the use of cream sherry and a minimal touch of honey expect a rich round mouthfeel without the typical cloying sweetness of traditional glühwein.This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Warming Crock-Pot Cocktail Recipes to Try at Home.”
HowToMake: Serves 10. Add all ingredients into a slow cooker and set temperature to “low” for approximately one hour. Switch to “keep warm” and serve as desired. Add honey to taste if necessary. Garnish with an orange peel along with spices of choice such as a cinnamon stick star anise and grated nutmeg.
Ingredients: Syrah (750 mL);Townshend Bluebird alpine liqueur (375 mL);Peels and juice of 1/2 orange;Honey;Cream sherry (375 mL);Grated nutmeg

Name: Temple Toddy
About: Inspired by a trip to Ireland and an affinity for the tropics award-winning bartender Steven Gonzalez of The Living Room at Park Hyatt in New York City adds an unexpected flavor to the traditional toddy with the addition of mango. In this recipe the whiskey is added at the very end minimizing any compromise to the spirit’s flavor profile and allowing it to shine in the finished product.This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Warming Crock-Pot Cocktail Recipes to Try at Home.”
HowToMake: Peel and chop the apple lemon mango and ginger. Add the apple lemon mango ginger star anise cinnamon sticks and 32 oz water into a Crock-Pot. Cover and set  to “low.” Cook for 1 hour. Muddle all solids and strain mixture through a fine strainer. (Yields 6 oz.). Combine mixture whiskey and honey into a Hot Toddy mug. Garnish with a cinnamon stick and a lemon wheel.
Ingredients: Granny Smith apple;Lemon;Mango;Ginger (2 in);Star anise;Cinnamon sticks;Jameson Irish whiskey;Honey

Name: Bring Me Back Something French
About: There’s something about anise and chocolate that wins every single time. In this rich low-ABV hot cocoa recipe by Stephen Denaro of Craft & Commerce in San Diego (home to Tiki speakeasy False Idol) the build itself is simple enough focusing the bulk of the work on the hot chocolate itself.This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Warming Crock-Pot Cocktail Recipes to Try at Home.”
HowToMake: Place a Crock-Pot bag in the pot (to will aid in cleanup and prevent sticking) add in first six ingredients and set to high. (Yields 6 oz.). Once mixture is hot turn Crock-Pot to “warm” stirring periodically to prevent separation. Add mixture and absinthe into a decorative mug and stir. Garnish with vanilla whipped cream decorative sugar and 2 Pocky sticks. **Vanilla whipped cream: Add 2 cups heavy cream and 3 oz Monin vanilla syrup in a mixing bowl and beat with a hand mixer until it begins to peak.
Ingredients: Whole milk;Sweetened condensed milk (14 oz);Cocoa powder;Heavy cream;Semisweet chocolate chips;Salt;Absinthe

Name: Hey Gourdgeous
About: According to NYC bartender and consultant Joanna Carpenter mini pumpkins are more than just throwaway fall décor. If you have the time (and an efficient scooping tool) this recipe along with its over-the-top edible vessels should be at the top of your list for winter kitchen experiments. This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Warming Crock-Pot Cocktail Recipes to Try at Home.”
HowToMake: In a slow cooker add apples lemon juice maple syrup and 8 oz water then top with ginger cinnamon sticks star anise cloves and nutmeg. Stir then cover and cook on high for one hour. Add apple brandy and amaro and gently stir to mix. Cover again and cook on high for another hour. Turn to low to keep warm and serve as needed. *Spiced-butter-brushed baked mini pumpkins: Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Slice off tops of 6 small pumpkins and hollow out insides making sure not to scoop the walls too thin. Arrange pumpkins on a baking sheet cut side down and bake for 10-12 minutes or until the insides are mushy. In the meantime in a shallow saucepan on medium heat add 2 sticks of salted butter 4 cinnamon sticks and 1 tsp ground nutmeg. When butter is melted stir in 1 cup packed brown sugar until completely mixed. Keep warm on very low heat so the mixture doesn't burn. Remove pumpkins from oven and turn them cut side up. Let stand to cool for 10 minutes. Brush spiced butter over inside of each pumpkin before pouring warm cocktail from slow cooker into each pumpkin.
Ingredients: Granny Smith apples cored and cut into chunks;Fresh lemon juice;Real maple syrup;Fresh ginger peeled and sliced;Cinnamon sticks;Star anise;Whole cloves;Ground nutmeg;Apple brandy (750 mL);Amaro Montenegro (375 mL);Spiced-butter-brushed baked mini pumpkins

Name: Apple Cranberry Moscow Mule
About: It’s no surprise that the Moscow Mule is one of the most popular cocktails of the last 20 years. It is easy to make and easy to drink and comes in its own cool mug. This fun fall recipe pairs cran-apple and lime juice with vodka and ginger beer. Add plenty of fresh fruits as a garnish and you have a Moscow Mule that can take you right into the new year.
HowToMake: Pour the first 3 ingredients into a mule mug and add ice. Top with ginger beer. Garnish with fresh cranberries and apple slices.
Ingredients: Vodka;Cran-Apple juice;Fresh lime juice;Ginger beer to top

Name: Red Beans & Rice Orgeat Recip
About: Orgeat the staple sweetener used in Tiki drinks is made with almonds. But if you have a nut allergy this is a great alternative. The red beans give it the feel of adzuki (sweet red bean mash popular in Chinese pastries) and the citrus in orange blossom water complements the vanilla beans better and makes the orgeat a little more versatile for classic Tiki drinks. This recipe originally appeared as part of “This Is the Only Nut-Free Orgeat Recipe You’ll Ever Need.”
HowToMake: In a large rondeau pot toast beans and rice until lightly browned. Add vodka orange blossom water vanilla beans and 8 cups water and bring to a boil. Remove from heat strain liquid and reserve liquid. Put resulting mash back in pot add 8 cups sugar and 8 cups water. Bring to a boil remove from heat strain and reserve liquid. Combine mash and both reserved liquids. Keeps in refrigerator for up to one month.
Ingredients: Dry red beans;White rice;Vodka;Orange blossom water;Vanilla beans;Sugar

Name: A La Louisiane
About: The A La Louisiane (sometimes called De La Louisiane) is the former house drink of New Orleans’ restaurant La Louisiane. A variation on the Vieux Carré the cocktail’s herbal flavors can be punched up or scaled back depending on the amount of Bénédictine Peychaud’s and absinthe you use.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a skewered maraschino cherry.
Ingredients: Rye whiskey;Sweet vermouth;Bénédictine;Peychaud’s bitters;Absinthe

Name: Grave Digger
About: Get grounded this Halloween with a dessert cocktail that’s as disturbing as it is delicious. The Grave Digger is a simple twist on a Spanish Coffee with one spooky exception: It’s topped with crushed Oreo cookies and a tiny shovel to resemble a freshly dug grave—a nifty little trick we picked up from cocktail influencer Katie Stryjewski aka @garnish_girl.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a coupe. Top with whipped cream and crushed Oreo cookies (discarding cream in center). *Vanilla-infused brandy: Cut 2 fresh vanilla pods lengthwise and place into a 750 mL bottle of brandy. Let sit for 3 to 5 days shaking occasionally. Strain out pods and store.
Ingredients: Vanilla-infused brandy;Coffee liqueur;Grand Marnier;Espresso

Name: Millionaire
About: This traditional sour has been around since Prohibition. Ideal for fans of bourbon and those that like their cocktails on the stronger side the Millionaire includes pastis or absinthe for the extra kick and egg white for an unforgettable texture.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker and dry-shake (no ice) to let the egg white foam up. Add cubed ice and shake vigorously for about 5 seconds. Double-strain into a pre-chilled coupe glass. Grate nutmeg over the drink.
Ingredients: Bourbon;Grand Marnier;Fresh lemon juice;Grenadine;Absinthe or pastis;Egg white

Name: Rum & Smoke
About: On the surface the Rum & Smoke looks like little more than a winterized rum Negroni. But slip it underneath a glass cloche with a flamed rosemary sprig and you’ve got a cocktail that’s sexy smoky and cinematic.
HowToMake: In a mixing glass add all ingredients with ice and stir until chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a flamed rosemary sprig. Cover with a glass dome and let sit for 1-2 minutes or until the cocktail is well smoked before drinking. *Smoked-rosemary simple syrup: In a saucepan over medium heat combine ½ cup sugar ½ cup water and zest from 1 orange and stir until just under boil. Remove from heat. With a kitchen torch or lighter flame one rosemary sprig until it begins to smoke on all sides. Drop smoking sprig into saucepan and let steep covered for 20 minutes. Strain out solids and store in refrigerator up to one week.
Ingredients: Aged rum;Oloroso sherry;Tempus Fugit Gran Classico bitter liqueur;Smoked-rosemary simple syrup

Name: Witches’ Brew
About: So many Halloween cocktails sacrifice balance for boo! Not the case with the Witches’ Brew a smoky scotch sour doused with fino sherry and beet juice which bubbles violently when served in a glass pipe with dry ice. But if special effects in your drink give you the heebie-jeebies skip them. This Halloween cocktail is just as much of a treat without the tricks.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the beet juice into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a glass pipe or rocks glass over fresh ice. Top with the beet juice. *Dry ice: For the full Halloween effect drop a small cube of dry ice into the glass using tongs or sturdy gloves. Never use bare hands. Wait for the smoking to stop and the ice to completely melt before drinking your cocktail. Never ingest dry ice.
Ingredients: Islay scotch;Fino sherry;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup;Beet juice

Name: Kiwi Bird
About: Backbar bar manager Carlo Caroscio (who spent six years at chef Bryan Voltaggio’s flagship fine-dining restaurant Volt) keeps things relaxed but never dumbed-down. Bartender Joseph Habib’s Kiwi Bird arrives on a tray of ice with a cute kiwi bird gazing into a barrel glass. Scotch is bolstered by vodka then goes tart and lush with kiwi coconut cream lime and orange bitters. This recipe originally appeared as part of “10 Scotch Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a Tiki mug over crushed ice. Garnish with a kiwi slice and freshly grated nutmeg. Serve with a straw. *Coconut cream: Combine 2 parts Coco Lopez and 1 part coconut milk. **Kiwi syrup: Combine 1 part Perfect Purée kiwi purée with 1 part simple syrup.
Ingredients: Compass Box Great King Street Artist’s Blend scotch;Broken Shed vodka;Coconut cream;Kiwi syrup;Regans’ Orange Bitters No. 6

Name: Smoke Break
About: Jake Larowe the bar manager at Birds & Bees in Los Angeles says he wanted to do a decadent cocktail in a playful way. This Manhattan riff is added to a decanter that’s smoked with cherrywood. It reminds him of waiting tables in college and taking that quick cigarette break outside after the rush is over. “We wanted to create the cocktail that you look forward to after a long day at work” he says.This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Smart Ways to Smoke Your Bourbon Cocktails.”
HowToMake: Using a smoking gun and the cherrywood chips add smoke to a glass decanter then cover top of decanter to capture smoke. Add remaining ingredients and ice into a mixing glass and stir until well-chilled. Strain into prepared decanter cap and serve in a rocks glass over a large ice cube. Garnish with a tray of dark chocolate and dried black cherries.
Ingredients: Cherrywood chips;W.L. Weller Special Reserve bourbon;Cream sherry;Carpano Antica Formula vermouth;Woodford Reserve spiced cherry bourbon-barrel-aged bitters;Angostura bitters

Name: Butter & Smoke
About: Smoking a cocktail glass using a lit sprig of a stalky herb like thyme rosemary or lavender not only adds flavor but is a fun parlor trick for a cocktail party. “This combination is perfect because the homemade pumpkin butter adds depth and richness to the bourbon along with a touch of fall spice” says Zachary Gross the beverage director at Sen Sakana in New York City. “This whole combination is completed by smoking the cocktail with thyme which is another essential fall flavor.This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Smart Ways to Smoke Your Bourbon Cocktails.”
HowToMake: Light a thyme sprig using a kitchen torch place it inside a rocks glass and set the rocks glass upside down on a granite countertop or other fireproof surface. Add remaining ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into prepared glass over a large ice cube and swirl to incorporate smoke. Garnish with a thyme sprig and cranberries. *Pumpkin-butter-infused fat-washed bourbon: Add 2 15-oz cans of pumpkin purée 2/3 cup coconut sugar or organic brown sugar 1/4 cup Grade A maple syrup 1/2 cup unsweetened apple juice 1 tbsp fresh lemon juice 2 1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spice 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon and a pinch of sea salt to a large saucepan or pot over medium-high heat and stir to combine. Once the mixture begins to bubble reduce heat to low and simmer for 20 minutes stirring occasionally. Remove from heat let cool completely and transfer to a large glass container. (Keeps in refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.) Spread the pumpkin butter out on a large pan with a high rim. Pour a 750 mL bottle of bourbon on top cover and let it infuse for an hour. Place the pan in the freezer to allow the alcohol to separate. Strain out solids and put it in a container.
Ingredients: Thyme;Pumpkin-butter-infused fat-washed bourbon;Tempus Fugit Gran Classico bitter apéritif;Fee Brothers cranberry bitters

Name: Revenant
About: John Filkins the beverage director at Officina and Masseria in Washington D.C. wanted to do a richer version of a Boulevardier including adding a whiff of smoke. He boils Fee Brothers. Aztec chocolate bitters and cardamom bitters taking advantage of the fact that since they’re both glycerin-based they smoke but don’t burn the way those made from alcohol would. A snifter is filled with smoke and covered with a coaster and the drink is then poured tableside from a carafe. “Chinato is a great replacement for vermouth and adds an herbal complexity [while] dry curaçao helps to lift it” says Filkins. “The smoke adds a wow factor when it goes to the table and chocolate and cardamom bring aromatic complexity and warm baking spices.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Smart Ways to Smoke Your Bourbon Cocktails.”
HowToMake: Heat an empty Turkish coffeepot. When it begins to steam add both bitters. When it begins to smoke fill a chilled snifter with the smoke and cover with a coaster. Add remaining ingredients and ice into a mixing glass and stir until well-chilled. Remove coaster from prepared glass and strain drink into it.
Ingredients: Fee Brothers Aztec chocolate bitters;Fee Brothers cardamom bitters;Blanton’s bourbon;Pierre Ferrand dry curaçao;Cocchi Barolo chinato

Name: Bourbon Toscano
About: This Old Fashioned riff at popular restaurant TMACS in the heart of Walla Walla in Washington state’s wine country gets its smoky notes from a double dose of ice made with water that has been smoked with cherrywood chips. The cubes are stirred with the other ingredients to chill and dilute the drink and the concoction is also served over a smoky cube. “As the smoke flavor from the aromatic infusion dissipates the cocktail slowly infuses with the water from the smoked ice and maintains the prominence of smoke throughout the entirety of the cocktail experience” says owner Logan Thies. The orange flavor comes from Aperol which replaces the orange rind in the original. “The brightening that the citrus oil introduces is beautiful but I wanted to make the drink more defined and complex while staying true to its nature” he says.This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Smart Ways to Smoke Your Bourbon Cocktails.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into an Old Fashioned glass over the smoked ice cubes. Garnish with a dehydrated rosemary sprig and dehydrated orange wheel. *Smoked ice cubes: Fill a smoker with cherrywood chips (or add a smoker box filled with cherrywood chips to a grill). Fill metal containers with water set inside the smoker or grill and close the lid. Smoke for 30 minutes or until desired flavor is achieved. Freeze the smoked water in ice cube trays.
Ingredients: Four Roses Kentucky straight bourbon;Aperol;Addition rosemary cocktail spice bitters;Smoked ice cubes

Name: The Ultimate Chocolate Martini
About: A great dessert cocktail shouldn’t include any added sugar or artificial flavors. Simply mix all-natural Mozart chocolate cream liqueur and vodka for an elegant and mouthwatering take on the classic Chocolate Martini.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake well. Strain into a cocktail glass.
Ingredients: Mozart chocolate cream liqueur;Mamont vodka

Name: No-So-Basic PSL
About: Pumpkin spice lattes announce the arrival of fall even better than the leaves changing color. Skip the trip to the coffee shop and try this spiced-up and boozy take on the classic. The irresistible mix of Mozart pumpkin spice and dark chocolate liqueur spiced rum and chile pepper is far from basic.
HowToMake: Add the liqueurs and rum into a mug. Add the cinnamon and pour in the espresso. Top with the whipped cream. Sprinkle a dash of chile powder over top. Garnish with a cinnamon stick.
Ingredients: Mozart pumpkin spice liqueur;Mozart dark chocolate liqueur;STROH 160 rum;Cinnamon;Deadsled spellbound espresso;Whipped cream to top

Name: Souled Out
About: Jasmine Garcia developed this stunning twist on the Tequila Negroni for Tales of the Cocktail in New Orleans. She wanted to pay tribute to the French Quarter with Aveze Gentian and Royal Combier two French liqueurs. She then used piri piri to capture some of the Cajun spice of the city. The delicious cocktail also serves as a great showcase for Azuñia black 2-year extra aged special reserve añejo tequila.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice. Garnish with an orange twist and palm leaf.
Ingredients: Azuñia black 2-year extra aged special reserve añejo tequila;Aveze Gentian liqueur;Royal Combier liqueur;Only Bitters piri piri cocktail spice

Name: Divided Sky
About: Chef’s Special Cocktail Bar in Chicago’s Bucktown has a dive bar spirit outdoor seating and American-Chinese cuisine like king crab fried rice or spicy clams over rice noodles. General manager Chase Bracamontes pours local beers natural wines and crushable cocktails. This drink amps up bourbon and fernet with vanilla lemon and a colorful dose of hibiscus resulting in a toasty herbal and tart cocktail. This recipe originally appeared as part of “9 Bourbon (and Other Whiskey) Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a skewered maraschino cherry. *Hibiscus honey syrup: Combine 300 g honey 25 g hibiscus flowers and 200 g hot water and let cool for 5 minutes. Strain out flowers and let fully cool. Bottle and keep refrigerated up to 6 weeks. Makes 1 cup.
Ingredients: Rowan’s Creek bourbon;Tempus Fugit crème de cacao;Combier;Hibiscus honey syrup;Fresh lemon juice;Fernet-Branca

Name: La Organica Sangrienta
About: This recipe has a lot in common with a traditional Margarita. There’s tequila agave syrup and lime juice. But Joey Binas the bar manager of Bootlegger in San Diego uses organic tequila from Azuñia and adds blood orange liqueur to turn La Organica Sangrienta into a uniquely refreshing cocktail.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. Shake well and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice. Garnish the rim with Tajin and a lime wedge.
Ingredients: Pur Likor spice blood orange liqueur;Azuñia organic agave syrup;Fresh lime juice

Name: Perfect Penicillin
About: If you’re looking to make the most delicious version of the Penicillin you’ll need to start with a crisp and richly fruity Speyside single malt and top it off with a smoky peated whisky. Luckily BenRiach has expressions that fit the description. Just combine them with lemon juice and homemade honey ginger syrup to complete the Perfect Penicillin. Buy a bottle of BenRiach so you can make the Perfect Penicillin Cocktail at home.
HowToMake: Add the Speyside whisky lemon juice and honey ginger syrup into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Top with the Curiositas whisky. Garnish with candied ginger or lemon zest. *Honey ginger syrup: Combine 1 cup honey 1 6-inch piece of ginger (peeled and thinly sliced) and 1 cup water to a saucepan over high heat and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to medium and simmer for 5 minutes. Chill overnight then strain and keep refrigerated for up to one month.
Ingredients: Fresh lemon juice;Honey ginger syrup

Name: Angostura Rum Punch
About: There are a couple of factors that can turn a typical punch into something special. First you need to choose the right mix of juices. Most important you need to mix them with a delicious premium rum. It’s safe to say that Angostura Rum Punch easily meets that criteria.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a Hurricane glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a brandied cherry.
Ingredients: Angostura five-year-old rum;Pineapple juice;Orange juice;Fresh lime juice;Grenadine

Name: Gin Sonic
About: “This cocktail is best enjoyed in a highball glass since it evolved from both the whiskey highball cocktail and the Gin & Tonic” says Victoria Vera of San Francisco’s Tsunami Panhandle. “What makes it so refreshing is that extra soda water and tonic water which a shorter rocks glass would not be able to carry.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “Is the Gin Sonic Even Better Than the Gin & Tonic?”
HowToMake: Combine all ingredients in a highball glass over ice. Garnish with a yuzu twist.
Ingredients: Roku gin;Club soda;Tonic water

Name: Hailey’s Comet
About: After Hailey Coder the lead bartender at The Park Bistro & Bar at the Lafayette Park hotel in Lafayette Calif. topped some fresh local peaches with a big dollop of Chantilly cream the bar team began brainstorming ingredient combinations from almond vanilla and honey to lemon juice and blackberries. Coder mingles all of them in this decadent summer sipper that thankfully can be more frequent an indulgence than Halley’s Comet its similarly named astronomical occurrence. “Peaches are in season toward the end of summer and partner perfectly with bourbon” she says. “You can imagine peaches blackberries almond and cream combining to make a perfect dessert so why not a cocktail?” It’s easily scalable and batchable for backyard barbecues or summer soirees.This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Frozen Bourbon Cocktails for the Last (Official) Days of Summer.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a blender with 1 cup of ice. Pour into a stemmed beer glass or Collins glass and top with a heaping spoonful of orgeat-chantilly cream. Garnish with 3 fresh peach slices. Serve with a straw. *Peach-infused bourbon: Wash and remove the skins and pits from 3 ripe peaches and cut peaches into large segments. Pour 750 mL bottle of bourbon into a plastic container add peaches and let rest at room temperature for 24 to 48 hours. (The longer the better but peach flavor extraction will cease after 48 hours.) Strain out solids through a cheesecloth and store in refrigerator for up to several weeks. **Orgeat-chantilly cream: Combine 1 cup heavy whipping cream 1/2 tsp vanilla extract and 1/2 cup Giffard orgeat in a bowl or stand mixer. Whip with a whisk or use a hand beater until stiff peaks form.
Ingredients: Peach-infused bourbon;Pimm’s blackberry and elderflower liqueur;Giffard orgeat;Fresh lemon juice;Organic honey

Name: Tennessee Summertide
About: Sarah Turbett the bar manager at Oak Steakhouse in Nashville came up with the idea for her brain-freeze-inducing creation thinking about her favorite flavors of summer and fall growing up in Tennessee. “Tennessee whiskey summer peach and vinegar notes brighten up fall spices orange peel and licorice transporting your palate from the warm end of summer to the early crisp autumn breeze” she says. “Light enough to enjoy during the heat but complex enough to hold up to a piece of pumpkin pie this cocktail is the perfect drink for the end of summer. Imagine sipping on this frozen cocktail on your porch in a great wooden rocking chair watching the sun go down in a golden sky over amber fields.” Sounds just peachy. This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Frozen Bourbon Cocktails for the Last (Official) Days of Summer.”
HowToMake: Blend all ingredients and 1 cup of ice in a blender. Pour into a rocks glass over crushed ice. Garnish with a skewered slice of pickled peach. *Pickled peaches: Boil 3 1/2 cups white vinegar 3 cups white sugar 1/2 cup diced lemongrass 1 large piece of peeled ginger 1 1/2 tbsp ground mace 1/2 tbsp allspice 4 whole cloves and 2 cinnamon sticks. Remove from heat strain mixture over sliced peaches and let cool.
Ingredients: Chattanooga 1816 Cask unfiltered barrel-proof whiskey;Amaro Montenegro;St. George absinthe verte;Pickled peach juice;Simple syrup

Name: Sugar Baby
About: HomeMakers Bar in Cincinnati’s Over-the-Rhine neighborhood is named for both the watering hole’s welcoming feel and its midcentury design inspiration. This frozen concoction is an elevated version of the high school party trick of upending a bottle of vodka in a watermelon. “By freezing the watermelon and its ingredients we can preserve and hang on to summer as long as we want” says co-founder and manager Catherine Manabat. “Nothing says summer more than watermelon.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Frozen Bourbon Cocktails for the Last (Official) Days of Summer.”
HowToMake: Cut the watermelon in half and use a melon baller to scoop out the flesh then place in a shallow container with a lid. Strain out excess liquid from container. Slowly add the bourbon and fennel-infused Cocchi Americano into the container allowing the liquid to be absorbed before adding more. (The liquid should eventually be completely soaked up by the melon.) Put a lid on the container and freeze for 3 to 4 hours. Scoop out into coupe or bowl. Garnish with sea salt black pepper and chopped basil. *Fennel-infused Cocchi Americano: Add 1/2 cup chopped fennel fronds and a 750 mL bottle of Cocchi Americano to a jar. Seal and refrigerate for 24 hours then strain out solids. Store in the refrigerator for up to several weeks.
Ingredients: Large seedless watermelon;Bourbon;Fennel-infused Cocchi Americano

Name: Miamian’s Julep
About: Guests at Villa Azur in Miami experience dining drinks entertainment music and art in a distinct space that combines the atmosphere of South Beach with that of Mediterranean France’s La Côte d’Azur. Bar manager Carlos Ramos’ fresh take on a Julep was inspired by the tropical vibes culture and eternal summer of Miami. “The bourbon complements the refreshing mint flavor to give you something that stimulates the senses and quenches your bourbon craving” he says. This recipe originally appeared as part of “4 Frozen Bourbon Cocktails for the Last (Official) Days of Summer.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a blender with 1 cup of ice and blend until smooth. Pur into a copper Julep mug. Garnish with bourbon-flambéed banana slices a mint sprig and powdered sugar. *Bourbon-flambéed banana slices: Sauté banana slices in a pan add a little whiskey then ignite to burn off alcohol. Alternatively use a kitchen torch on sugar-coated banana slices for more caramelized flavor.
Ingredients: Woodinville bourbon;Coconut cream;Crème de banane;Fresh lime juice;Mint

Name: Cabana Club
About: Yael Vengroff the beverage director at The Spare Room in The Hollywood Roosevelt and the 2018 Spirited Awards American Bartender of the Year created this coconut-sherry liquid sunshine as a one-off for the “Evening of Tiki” series she hosts at the bar every May through September. This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Drink of Summer Has Arrived. Barely in Time.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a blender and blend with crushed ice. Pour into a coconut. Garnish with shredded coconut grated nutmeg and an edible orchid. Serve with a cocktail umbrella and crazy straw. *Cinnamon syrup: Add 2 ceylon cinnamon sticks (crumbled and toasted in a pan) 4 cups sugar and 2 cups water to large pan. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Remove from heat and cover. Let sit 20 minutes then strain and chill.
Ingredients: Amontillado sherry;Fresh coconut water;The Perfect Purée coconut;Coco Lopez cream of coconut;Pernod absinthe;Cinnamon syrup

Name: Holy Water
About: Seaworthy beverage director Matt Ray created the Holy Water as the restaurant’s flagship cocktail served tableside in a custom tarot glass from local shop Flambeauxs. He steeps Hamilton Jamaican gold rum with golden raisins orange peels vanilla bean cinnamon clove nutmeg and other spices. Shaken with Maison rouge cognac lemon lime and grapefruit juices the drink gains yet more spice from a float of Angostura bitters. A half-lime garnish filled with Green Chartreuse and a sugar cube is then lit tableside caramelizing the sugar and releasing aromas of citrus herbs and spice. This recipe originally appeared as part of “10 Rum Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the bitters and Chartreuse into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a highball glass over crushed ice. Float the bitters over top to fill. Juice half a lime and place lime on top of drink to garnish. Pour the Chartreuse into the lime. Place a sugar cube in the lime and light with a match or lighter to flame. Serve with a straw. *Infused rum: In a 750 mL bottle of Hamilton Jamaican gold rum or El Dorado five-year-old rum steep 1/4 cup golden raisins 1 vanilla bean (scraped out) 1 tbsp cloves 1 whole cinnamon stick 3 crushed cardamom pods and 1 tbsp allspice berries for 48 hours then strain. Alternately you can just use El Dorado spiced rum.
Ingredients: Infused Hamilton Jamaican gold rum or El Dorado five-year-old rum;Maison rouge cognac;Orgeat;Fresh lime juice;Fresh lemon juice;Grapefruit juice;Angostura bitters to float;Green Chartreuse

Name: Banana Daiquiri
About: The Banana Daiquiri means different things to different people. To some it’s an icy-tall blender drink beloved as much for its fruitiness as its frothiness. To others it’s a classic shaken Daiquiri accented with a hint of banana. This recipe belongs to the latter. To get the most of your Banana Daiquiri try a few different rums as the range in styles and flavors will affect the sweetness and balance of the cocktail.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a banana slice.
Ingredients: Aged rum;Tempus Fugit crème de banane liqueur;Fresh lime juice;Demerara simple syrup

Name: Amanyara Mojito
About: This blended riff on the Mojito eliminates the need for all that labor-intensive muddling and also prevents pieces of mint from getting stuck in your teeth. It’s the best-selling cocktail at Amanyara resort on the Turks & Caicos island of Providenciales and was created to reflect the property’s elegance and sense of design.This recipe originally appeared as part of “A Mojito Like You’ve Never Tried Before.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except Champagne into a blender with ice and blend until smooth. Pour mixture through a fine strainer into a rocks glass over crushed ice. Top with Champagne. Garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel and 2 mint sprigs.
Ingredients: Bacardí Superior light rum;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup;Mint;Chilled champagne to top

Name: Honeysuckle
About: Sipping Angostura seven-year-old rum is the best way to appreciate its complex and full-bodied flavor. But you can also mix it with lime juice and honey syrup to make this refreshing and refined tropical cocktail.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with a lime wheel.
Ingredients: Angostura seven-year-old rum;Fresh lime juice;Honey syrup;Angostura orange bitters

Name: Rum Punch
About: Rum and fruit juice are as perfect a pairing as you’ll find in the cocktail universe. This single-serving Rum Punch mixes two types of rum with pineapple and orange juice plus a touch of lime juice to cut through the tropical sweetness. Entertaining a crowd? Simply scale up the measurements to fit your punch bowl and add a few slices of fresh fruit for a Rum Punch that keeps on giving.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a Hurricane glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a brandied cherry.
Ingredients: Light rum;Dark rum;Pineapple juice;Orange juice;Fresh lime juice;Grenadine

Name: Forefathers
About: This cocktail by bartender Weisi Basore at Bar Cleeta a casual small-plates eatery she co-owns with her husband Trae Basore in Bentonville Ark. is liquid tribute to the South––one that incorporates the region’s most beloved summer refreshment sweet tea and its prime summer fruit peaches. “The oleo saccharum brings a hint of citrus to the sweet tea syrup and rounds out this version of an Old Fashioned” she says.This recipe originally appeared as part of “This Is How to Sweet-Tea Your Old Fashioned Cocktail.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until cold. Strain into an Old Fashioned glass over a 2-inch ice cube. Garnish with an orange peel. *Sweet tea oleo saccharum: Peel 4 lemons and 2 oranges. Transfer the peels to a sealed bag and add 2 cups sugar. Toss peels and sugar to coat. Press bag to remove all air and seal to close. Let bag sit at room temperature for 24-48 hours until the citrus’ oils have dissolved the sugar. Open bag and pour mixture and into a saucepan. Add 1 1/2 cups unsweetened chilled Red Diamond tea. Cook over medium-low heat for 10-15 minutes until sugar dissolves into tea and syrup forms. Pour mixture through strainer to remove peels. Cool and reserve until ready to use.
Ingredients: Evan Williams 1783 bourbon;Sweet tea oleo saccharum;Free Brothers peach bitters

Name: Nu Mai Tai
About: At tropical-themed bar Esotico in the heart of Miami’s arts and entertainment district this Mai Tai riff is co-owner and beverage director Daniele Dalla Pola’s tribute and gratitude to Don the Beachcomber and Trader Vic’s. It’s poured served in a Kahiko Mai Tai glass he designed. “There’s ‘lilikoi’ (‘passion’ in Hawaiian) in my Nu Mai Tai as in passion and passion fruit” he says. “That’s what made it new [or] as I like to say ‘What’s old is Nu.’”This recipe originally appeared as part of “6 Riffs on the Mai Tai to Drink in Bars Now.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Pour unstrained into a Tiki glass or mug over crushed ice. Garnish with a mint sprig. *Dan’s Mix #9: Mix 13 oz real ginger syrup 1 lb marzipan 1/2 cup simple syrup and 1 3/4 oz Alamea pimento liqueur in a blender. Store in refrigerator for up to a few weeks.
Ingredients: Rum blend (equal-parts Martinique rhum agricole Jamaican rum and spiced rum);Fresh lime juice;Orange curaçao;Passion fruit purée;Dan's Mix #9

Name: Nightcap
About: An avid coffee geek Daniel Moik the head bartender at Yours Truly in Hamilton Bermuda has had his fair share of Espresso & Tonics which was the starting point for this cocktail. The rum has a butterscotch and vanilla note but finishes dry. Maple syrup adds sweetness Angostura bitters lend complexity and orange zest matches the tonic’s citrus notes. “A Rum & Tonic is like the two friends you have and you can’t figure out why they’re so close until you really spend time with them” says Moik. “This drink is a great summertime pick-me-up as the sun is setting and you need that little boost to keep the party going.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “It’s Time to Give the Rum & Tonic Its Due.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the tonic into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a highball glass over large ice cubes. Top with the tonic and stir gently. Garnish with an orange peel.
Ingredients: Gosling’s Gold Seal rum;Cold-brew coffee;Grade A maple syrup;Zest of 1 orange;Angostura bitters;San Pellegrino tonic water to top

Name: Rum & Tonic
About: “I love a Rum & Tonic during the summer” says Ashwin Vikhu the co-owner of Saffron in New Orleans. “It’s a great alternative to a G&T because it’s light and refreshing all the while having depth of flavor.” This drink is served Spanish-style in a large wine goblet garnished with a lot of the ingredients whose aromas and flavors either compliment or coax out those in the rum.This recipe originally appeared as part of “It’s Time to Give the Rum & Tonic Its Due.”
HowToMake: Combine the rums in a large wine glass over ice. Top with the tonic and stir gently. Garnish with a fennel frond star anise pods a cinnamon stick a mint leaf an orange wheel a lime slice and a slice of peeled ginger.
Ingredients: Old Port East Indian rum;Paranubes Oaxaca rum;Fever-Tree Premium Indian tonic water to top
Garnish: Fennel frond;Star anise pods;Cinnamon stick;Mint leaf;Orange wheel;Lime slice;Ginger slice

Name: Summer Tonic
About: Elana Abt the wine director at Otto in New York City wanted to add a rum-based cocktail to the menu but keep the classic gin refresher in mind. “Rum just feels like summer and my guests typically order more rum cocktails this time of year” she says. “I thought Why not create a cool rum version of the classic G&T.’”This recipe originally appeared as part of “It’s Time to Give the Rum & Tonic Its Due.”
HowToMake: Combine all ingredients in a large snifter over ice. Garnish with a rosemary sprig.
Ingredients: Mount Gay rum;Borgia herbal bitters;Fever-Tree aromatic tonic water;Fresh lemon juice

Name: Grey Goose Magnifique
About: This easy-to-make recipe is centered around a couple of delicious ingredients: Grey Goose vodka and coconut water. All you need is a pinch of salt and a dash of orange blossom water to turn that refreshing pair into a magnificent—or magnifique to use Grey Goose’s native tongue—cocktail.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a highball with ice and stir until well-chilled. Garnish with a lime wedge.
Ingredients: Grey Goose vodka;Coconut water;Sea salt;Orange blossom water

Name: Bacardi Piña Colada
About: The original Cuban Piña Colada is a mellow cocktail that is best made with fresh coconut water and pineapple to remain true to its heritage which goes all the way back to 1922.
HowToMake: Place the pineapple chunks into a cocktail shaker and muddle lightly. Add the pineapple juice coconut water and sugar and stir to dissolve the sugar. Add the rum and cubed ice and shake until it’s frosted. Strain into a Hurricane glass over crushed ice. Garnish with a pineapple slice and pineapple leaf.
Ingredients: Bacardí Superior rum;Fresh coconut water;Fresh pineapple juice;Fresh pineapple;Caster sugar

Name: Frozen Margarita
About: Some Margarita purists insist that the classic cocktail should only be enjoyed on the rocks. After one sip of the Frozen Margarita you might find that argument ridiculous.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a blender and fill with ice just above the liquid line. Blend until the drink is a uniform consistency. (Add more ice to blender if you want a thicker consistency.). Pour into a coupe. Garnish with lime and lemon wheel.
Ingredients: Patrón silver tequila;Patrón Citrónge orange liqueur;Agave syrup;Fresh lime juice;Orange juice

Name: Bombay Mule
About: Prefer the flavor of gin to vodka? Then this is the Mule for you. Bombay Sapphire adds flavor without making the iconic summer cocktail any less refreshing.
HowToMake: Add the gin ginger beer and lime juice into a Moscow Mule mug or large rocks glass over ice and stir. Squeeze the lime wedges over the drink and stir again.
Ingredients: Bombay Sapphire gin;Ginger beer;Fresh lime juice;Lime wedges

Name: Angostura Mai Tai
About: There’s no need to mess with the formula that made the Mai Tai the quintessential Tiki cocktail. But you can lend it the classic notes of chocolate spice and toasted oak simply by using Angostura five-year-old rum.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a rocks or Tiki glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a mint sprig and lime wedge.
Ingredients: Angostura five-year-old rum;Orange curaçao;Pineapple juice;Fresh lime juice;Orgeat;White cane sugar;Vanilla syrup (optional)

Name: Oaks Lily
About: The Oaks Lily is the official cocktail of the Bluegrass State’s other big horse race the Kentucky Oaks. Light and refreshing the vodka drink takes its inspiration from the Cosmopolitan the pink hue a nod to the stargazer lilies placed on the race’s winning filly.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a highball fill with ice and stir. Garnish with a lemon wheel and 2 skewered blackberries.
Ingredients: Vodka;Orange liqueur;Simple syrup;Fresh lemon juice;Cranberry juice

Name: Palo Santo Gimlet
About: This Gimlet riff by Alex Kratena at his Tayēr + Elementary in East London is infused with Peruvian palo santo wood. It was inspired by a trip he took to the Amazonian jungle. “We have reworked the concept of the Gimlet and this way we keep it within the [context of] what is recognized but still with an interesting twist” he says. This recipe originally appeared as part of “The World’s Most Important Gimlet.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass filled with ice and stir. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. *Palo santo cordial: Combine 1/3 oz palo santo extract 5 cups sugar 1/4 cup malic acid 5 tsp citric acid and 5 cups water in a Thermomix and process for 5 minutes at 75 degrees Fahrenheit. Reserve until ready to use. (For those without a Thermomix add all ingredients into a medium-sized pot and cook gently. Don’t let the mixture simmer or boil-over low heat to dissolve sugar.).
Ingredients: Tayer X Hepple gin;Lillet blanc;Tio Pepe fino sherry;Palo santo cordial

Name: Massimo Bond
About: Manuel Mora the bar supervisor at Torno Subito in Dubai devised a cocktail list that leans heavily on Italian ingredients such as a blend of olive oils he uses in this riff on the classic Dry Martini that calls for Bottura’s very own Villa Manodori Taggiasca extra-virgin olive oil. This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Best Dirty Martini You’re Never Going to Actually Be Able to Drink.”
HowToMake: Add the sage leaves into a mixing glass and crush slightly with a muddler. Add the olive oil gin vermouth salt solution and ice and stir. Strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a skewered Taggiasca olive and 3 sage leaves. *Olive oil gin: Combine 750 mL gin and 200 mL extra-virgin olive oil (such as Villa Manodori Taggiasca extra-virgin olive oil) in a Mason jar with a seal-proof lid. Shake mixture then leave at room temperature for 7-9 hours to allow flavors to infuse. Place jar in the freezer overnight to solidify fats. The next day use a knife to break up coagulated fat at top of jar and strain spirit through a coffee filter or a cheese cloth. Strain again as desired to remove any leftover fat. Reserve in bottle until ready to use. **Pink Himalayan salt solution: Add 1/2 cup pink Himalayan salt and 1/2 cup water into a small bowl. Stir until salt dissolves and reserve.
Ingredients: Olive oil gin;Mancino secco vermouth or Martini extra dry Italian vermouth;Pink Himalayan salt solution;Sage

Name: Spicy Margarita
About: The Spicy Margarita succeeds where so many of its siblings seem to fail. That is to say it refocuses the classic tequila cocktail without losing what’s essential to its success: that timeless blend of sweet sour and earthy flavors. The key is to use fresh jalapeño. Two muddled coins with seeds removed yields a conservatively spicy drink. But for a spicier Spicy Margarita throw in a third coin. It’s the perfect cocktail to fire up your summer.
HowToMake: Rub the rim of a rocks glass with a lime wedge dip in salt to coat and set aside. Add the jalapeño coins into a shaker and gently muddle. Add remaining ingredients and ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into prepared glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a jalapeño coin.
Ingredients: Lime;Jalapeño coins (seeds removed);Blanco tequila;Fresh lime juice;Orange liqueur;Agave syrup

Name: Kentucky River
About: The opulent art deco vibe at Rosina inside The Palazzo at The Venetian hotel in Las Vegas draws you in but the dedicated Old Fashioned menu keeps you there. This cocktail just one of seven riffs includes crème de cacao and a few dashes of peach bitters to add a bit more sweetness. This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 New Takes on the Old Fashioned.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients and a large 2-inch ice cube into a double Old Fashioned glass and stir. Garnish with a lemon twist.
Ingredients: Buffalo Trace bourbon;Tempus Fugit crème de cacao;Peach bitters

Name: Brandy Old Fashioned
About: This cocktail aka the Wisconsin Old Fashioned is practically the official Wisconsin state drink and takes brandy instead of whiskey.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients except for the brandy to an Old Fashioned glass and muddle. Add ice to fill the glass add the brandy then top with the 7Up/Sprite (or seltzer or sour soda). Garnish with a skewered brandied or maraschino cherry and an orange slice.
Ingredients: Orange slices;Brandied or maraschino cherries;Angostura bitters;Sugar cube;7Up/Sprite seltzer or sour soda (sour mix and soda water);Brandy

Name: Tamarind Margarita
About: Isn’t it time you got a little more adventurous with your Margaritas? Try using smoky tequila tamarind purée and cinnamon agave syrup to experience the classic in a bold and delicious new way.
HowToMake: Rim a rocks glass with Tajín seasoning and set aside. Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake well. Strain into prepared glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a lime wedge.
Ingredients: Gran Patrón smoky tequila;Tamarind purée;Cinnamon agave syrup;Fresh lime juice;Angostura bitters

Name: Sea Blues
About: This cocktail was created at Honolulu’s Hilton Hawaiian Village Waikiki Resort to celebrate the hundredth birthday of Harry Yee the legendary Oahu bartender who came up with the recipe for the Blue Hawaii in 1957 at the resort when it was Kaiser Hawaiian Village. This version uses vodka from Maui that’s distilled with organic sugar cane and deep ocean water and served over a coconut ice sphere. As it melts it morphs both the flavor and texture of the libation.This recipe originally appeared as part of “Meet the Updated Blue Hawaii. It’s a Drink You Should Know.”
HowToMake: Rub the lemon wedge on the outside of a double Old Fashioned glass coat in toasted coconut flakes and set aside. Add remaining ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into the prepared glass over the coconut ice sphere (or a large ice sphere or cube). Garnish with an edible orchid and pineapple wedge. *Coconut ice sphere: Freeze a sphere mold of half coconut water and half cream of coconut.
Ingredients: Ocean vodka;Malibu coconut rum;Bols blue curaçao;Fresh lemon juice;Fresh pineapple juice;Lemon wedge for rimming;Coconut ice sphere

Name: Blue Hawaii
About: The Blue Hawaii cocktail was born at Honolulu’s Kaiser Hawaiian Village (now Hilton Hawaiian Village Waikiki Resort). In 1957 a sales representative of Dutch distiller Bols asked legendary bartender Harry Yee to design a drink that featured its blue color of curaçao liqueur. After experimenting with several variations Yee settled on a version somewhat different than the most popular version today but with the signature blue color pineapple wedge and cocktail umbrella. It was Yee who named the cocktail that shares its name with the 1961 Elvis Presley film.”There are numerous variations of this recipe such as the Blue Hawaiian which uses crème de coconut. But this is the authentic recipe.This recipe originally appeared as part of “Meet the Updated Blue Hawaii. It’s a Drink You Should Know.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. (Or blend all ingredients with ice in a blender.). Strain into a Hurricane glass over crushed or pebble ice. (Or pour from blender into glass with no ice.). Garnish with a pineapple wedge and cocktail umbrella.
Ingredients: Vodka;Light rum;Blue curaçao;Pineapple juice;Sweet-and-sour mix

Name: Strangelove
About: San Francisco’s Beehive is a modernist escape with Sputnik lamps ’70s-style plateware fondue and snacks like honeycomb Chex mix and pigs in a blanket. Bar manager Milo Salehi and the team always have a couple boozy slushies on the menu including their fantastic Quimbara. But the Strangelove appeals to vodka amari and berry fans.This recipe originally appeared as part of “7 Great Frozen Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a blender with ice and blend. Pour into a highball glass. Garnish with 2 edible flowers. Serve with a straw.
Ingredients: Ketel One vodka;Riesling wine;Fresh lime juice;Small Hand Foods raspberry gum syrup;Amaro Montenegro;Cappelletti aperitivo

Name: Delete That Text
About: Patrick Cook the beverage director at Hyperion Public in Studio City Calif. uses vodka to even out this blackberry sour which seemed a little too ginny. “I was in love with the drink [but] it was almost too botanical and becoming unbalanced” he says. “I knew that I still wanted to have two ounces of spirit but maybe dial it back just a touch.” Tweaking the ratio to equal-parts gin and vodka did the trick. This recipe originally appeared as part of “Use Vodka to Boost the Flavor and Body of Your Cocktails. This Is How You Do It.”
HowToMake: Muddle the blackberries in a shaker. Add remaining ingredients and ice and shake until well-chilled. Double-strain into a double Old Fashioned glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a rosemary sprig and lemon peel.
Ingredients: Fresh blackberries;Vodka;Gin;Elderflower liqueur;Fresh lemon juice

Name: Cabana Boy
About: This cocktail by Will Piquette the principal bartender at Alcove in Boston uses vodka as the dominant spirit to avoid overwhelming the palate yet it’s moderated and given dimension with oloroso sherry for nutty depth coconut lemongrass syrup orange juice and rhum agricole which gives grassy notes to compliment the lemongrass. This recipe originally appeared as part of “Use Vodka to Boost the Flavor and Body of Your Cocktails. This Is How You Do It.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. *Coconut-lemongrass syrup: Blend 15 oz coconut water 15 oz coconut cream 15 oz sugar and a chopped lemongrass stalk in a blender. Strain out solids. Store syrup in the refrigerator for up to a week.
Ingredients: Reyka vodka;Oloroso sherry;Rhum agricole;Coconut-lemongrass syrup;Orange juice

Name: Night Flights
About: This cocktail by Andra Johnson a bartender at Bresca in Washington D.C. and co-founder of DMV Black Restaurant Week is the lovechild of a Vesper and an Aviation. Using Salers instead of the Lillet in a Vesper lends a spicy note while vodka gives textural richness that offsets gin which can be astringent and lean. “By using a grain spirit that has more viscosity it coats the palate leaving behind a lingering finish instead of a quick dry one” says Johnson.This recipe originally appeared as part of “Use Vodka to Boost the Flavor and Body of Your Cocktails. This Is How You Do It.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a skewered brandied cherry and half-moon lemon peel.
Ingredients: Opihr gin;Republic Restoratives Civic vodka;Salers gentian apéritif;Crème de violette;Lemon bitters

Name: Dickel Whisky Sour
About: George Dickel No. 12 has enormous depth and a smooth finish making it the gold standard for Tennessee whisky. Those qualities also explain why it’s the perfect base for a Whisky Sour.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake well. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a cherry.
Ingredients: George Dickel No. 12 whisky;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup

Name: Mexican Chardonnay
About: Mexican Chardonnay is another name for Tequila Cazadores. It earned that nickname because it’s just as smooth and sippable as any wine.
HowToMake: Pour the tequila into a wine glass.
Ingredients: Tequila Cazadores reposado

Name: Life in Venice
About: This tricked-out Bellini adds Grey Goose L’Orange vodka and pink peppercorns to the classic combo of prosecco and white peach pureé. It’s enough to make any occasion feel like a lazy afternoon in Venice.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the prosecco into a shaker and stir until frothy. Wait for froth to settle then gently pour into a Champagne flute. Top with chilled prosecco. Garnish with three whole pink peppercorns.
Ingredients: Grey Goose L’Orange vodka;White peach pureé;Grenadine;Peach bitters;Pink peppercorn powder (ground pink peppercorns);Prosecco to top

Name: Sunday Morning Sour
About: Texture is often the difference between a standard Whiskey Sour and an exceptional one. Erica Long doubled-down on the silky and creamy texture by complementing the egg white with coconut milk and Tennessee clover honey.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with 4-6 one-inch ice cubes and shake vigorously until cold. Strain out ice and dry-shake until no ice remnants can be heard. Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with a sprig of lavender. *Earl Grey�"infused Gentleman Jack whiskey: Add one bag of Earl Grey tea to a 750 mL bottle of Gentleman Jack whiskey and let sit overnight. **Acid-adjusted citrus: Combine 5 oz fresh lemon juice with 5 oz fresh lime juice. Add 1/2 oz dry curaçao to the juice.
Ingredients: Earl Grey-infused Gentleman Jack whiskey;Tennessee clover honey;Acid-adjusted citrus;Coconut milk;Egg white

Name: The Suffragette
About: Elevate the traditional Martini by using small-batch gin. The touch of elderflower turns this cocktail into something truly special.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a Martini glass. Garnish with a stem of widow’s breath (optional).
Ingredients: Oxley gin;Noilly Prat dry vermouth;St-Germain

Name: Cazadores Loaded Michelada
About: This recipe is more balanced than your typical Michelada. Rather than the beer being the focus it starts with a premium tequila base. Of course you should still load it up with plenty of hot sauce and seasonings.
HowToMake: Rim a pint glass with salt or Tajín seasoning and set aside. Add all ingredients except the lager into the prepared glass over ice. Top with the lager.
Ingredients: Cazadores blanco tequila;Sweet-and-sour mix;Fresh lime juice;Tapatio or Valentina hot sauce;Tajín seasoning;Mexican style lager to top

Name: Bacardi & Cola
About: Rum & Cola can be a surprisingly complex and delicious drink. Of course that’s only the case when you make it with a rum as complex and delicious as Bacardí Superior.
HowToMake: Add ingredients into a highball glass with ice and give it a gentle stir. Drop a lime wedge into the drink.
Ingredients: Bacardí Superior rum;Cola chilled

Name: Bacardí Cuatro Airmail
About: A traditional Airmail cocktail is often garnished with a postage stamp. But it’s a couple of other subtle touches that make this take on the classic especially good—Bacardí Añejo Cuatro rum and orange blossom honey syrup.
HowToMake: Add the first three ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a champagne flute and top with prosecco. Garnish with an orange zest.
Ingredients: Bacardí Añejo Cuatro rum;Honey;Hot water;Simple syrup;Lime juice;Martini & Rossi prosecco to top

Name: Bacardi Ocho Old Fashioned
About: Bartenders have experimented with different versions of the Old Fashioned throughout the cocktail’s long history. But this latest iteration showcasing Bacardí Reserva Ocho rum might be the best one yet.
HowToMake: Add ingredients into an Old Fashioned glass over ice and stir until well-mixed and very cold. Garnish with an orange twist.
Ingredients: Bacardí Reserva Ocho rum;Simple syrup;Angostura bitters

Name: Cazadores con Cerveza
About: Any ice-cold Mexican lager goes well with Tequila Cazadores reposado. Enjoy your favorite beer alongside a shot of the bold and smooth tequila.
HowToMake: Pour the tequila into a shot glass. Serve alongside your favorite Mexican lager with lime.
Ingredients: Tequila Cazadores reposado;Mexican lager

Name: Frontier Old Fashioned
About: The Old Fashioned’s traditional mix of bourbon simple syrup and bitters is as simple as it seems. But it results in a complex and refreshing cocktail when you use bourbon as good as Bulleit.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into an Old Fashioned glass with ice and stir gently until the level of the ice and liquid are the same. Zest an orange peel over the glass and add the peel to the drink as a garnish.
Ingredients: Bulleit bourbon;Simple syrup;Angostura bitters

Name: Tennessee Tuxedo
About: The Tennessee Tuxedo is the kind of recipe you pull out for special occasions. A splash of amaro and pear liqueur along with a hint of smoked maple syrup all serve to showcase the gold standard of Tennessee whisky George Dickel No. 12.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.
Ingredients: George Dickel No. 12 whisky;Amaro;Pear liqueur;Smoked maple syrup;Peach bitters

Name: Peppered Peach Tea Tom Collins
About: There’s nothing wrong with a traditional Tom Collins. But a splash of peach iced tea and pinch of black pepper turns the classic cocktail into an irresistible and strikingly original drink.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the club soda into a highball glass with ice and stir for 30 seconds. Add more ice and top with the club soda. Garnish with a peach slice.
Ingredients: Bombay Sapphire gin;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup;Peach iced tea;Black pepper;Club soda

Name: Perfect Paloma
About: How do you improve the refreshing and fizzy Paloma? Adding agave syrup and freshly squeezed lime juice helps. But the most important upgrade is using Patrón reposado as the base.
HowToMake: Rim a highball glass with equal parts sugar and salt and set aside. Add all ingredients except the sparkling water into a shaker with ice and shake well. Strain into the prepared glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a grapefruit wedge.
Ingredients: Patrón reposado tequila;Fresh grapefruit juice;Fresh lime juice;Agave syrup;Sparkling water

Name: Alpenglow Aspro
About: Stephen Wood set out to create a Whiskey Sour inspired by flavors near and far. “Tennessee whiskey meets a bittersweet fruity herbal and slightly smoky amaro from the Italian alps” he says. “The flavor of local Concord grapes from the Northeast U.S. and delicate jasmine flowers pair beautifully with the bright acidity of fresh lemon juice.” These diverse flavors add up to a sour unlike any you’ve tried before.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with a large ice cube and shake to emulsify and chill but be careful not to over dilute. Strain into a highball glass. Garnish with a brandied Concord grape skewered by a young pine tip. *Concord grape and jasmine syrup: Combine 4 cups Concord grape juice an 8-inch sprig of fresh rosemary and a dried 1-1/2-square-inch cube crystallized ginger in a saucepan. Reduce mixture for 1 hour over medium-low heat. When mixture has reduced by half add 1 tsp balsamic vinegar and continue cooking until mixture has reduced by half again for about 10 minutes. Add 1 handful of fresh jasmine flowers and remove from heat. Let cool for 30 minutes. Strain and store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.
Ingredients: Gentleman Jack whiskey;Pasubio vino amaro;Fresh lemon juice;Concord grape and jasmine syrup;Vanilla scented egg white;Orange bitters

Name: Tepiatl Sour
About: Every take on the Whiskey Sour relies on the classic mix of citrus sweetness and spirit. The best new versions of the classic cocktail such as Cesar Perez’s Tepiatl Sour make unexpected and delicious choices for each of these three categories. Perez uses acid-adjusted pineapple juice for the citrus house-made cinnamon-piloncillo syrup for the sweetness and Gentleman Jack for the spirit.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with a large ice cube and shake. Strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with edible pineapple art printed on glycerin ink on rice/potato paper (optional). *Cinnamon-piloncillo syrup: Add 1 3- to 4-inch cinnamon stick to 1 1/2 cup water and simmer for 45 minutes. Strain and blend the cinnamon tea with equal-parts piloncillo sugar. Mix well and refrigerate in an airtight container. **Acid-adjusted pineapple juice: Blend 1 3/4 oz acid powder (equal-parts citric malic and tartaric) with 34 oz pineapple juice.
Ingredients: Gentleman Jack whiskey;Cinnamon-piloncillo syrup;Acid-adjusted pineapple juice;20% saline solution;Scrappy’s Firewater tincture bitters

Name: Cosmopolitan
About: The easiest way to make a better Cosmopolitan is by using Patrón Citrónge. The delicately blended orange liqueur gives the iconic cocktail the subtle sweetness it needs.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with an orange twist.
Ingredients: Ultimat vodka;Patrón Citrónge orange liqueur;Fresh lime juice;Cranberry juice;Simple syrup

Name: Bacardi Lime & Cranberry
About: The tart flavor of cranberry juice is the perfect match for the natural zest of Bacardí lime. The Bacardí Lime & Cranberry is super easy to make so you can be enjoying this subtly sour drink in no time.
HowToMake: Pour ingredients into a highball glass filled with ice. Garnish with a lime wheel.
Ingredients: Bacardí Lime rum;Cranberry juice

Name: Rock Da Boat
About: Egg white might be missing from the Rock Da Boat but Upshaw’s house-made mesquite-smoked orgeat gives it the texture you expect from a classic Whiskey Sour. Adding that to the already-irresistible mix of Gentleman Jack banana liqueur and lemon and pineapple juice leads to a bold and original cocktail.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker and dry-shake (no ice) for 10 seconds. Add ice and shake again for 10 more seconds. Fine-strain into chilled coupe glass. Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel soaked in Angostura bitters. *Mesquite-smoked orgeat: Toast 8 oz almonds at 350 degrees Fahrenheit on baking sheet in the oven. Remove from oven and blend and soak in 16 oz hot water for 10 minutes. Blend again and strain through cheesecloth. Add 1/4 oz cognac 1/4 oz amaretto 1/8 tsp orange blossom water for every 12 oz “almond milk” made.
Ingredients: Gentleman Jack whiskey;Banana liqueur;Fresh lemon juice;Mesquite-smoked orgeat;Fresh pineapple juice

Name: Bombay Sapphire & Tonic
About: Why settle for the standard Gin & Tonic when you can enjoy a premium version of the classic drink by mixing Bombay Sapphire gin with your favorite tonic.
HowToMake: Add ingredients into a highball glass with ice and stir briefly. Garnish with a lemon peel.
Ingredients: Bombay Sapphire dry gin;Premium tonic water

Name: Bacardi Coco & Pineapple
About: Want to save yourself the trouble of making a classic Piña Colada? Get the tropical flavors you crave by simply mixing Bacardí Coconut rum and fresh pineapple juice.
HowToMake: Fill a highball glass with ice. Add the rum and pineapple juice and stir. Garnish with a pineapple slice cut into a triangle.
Ingredients: Bacardí coconut rum;Pineapple juice

Name: Cazadores Sangrita Recip
About: Following a shot of tequila with a shot of Sangrita is an age-old practice. But you don’t have to go out to a bar to enjoy the delicious one-two punch. Make your own Sangrita and pair it with a worthy tequila like Cazadores añejo or extra añejo tequila.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a pitcher with a tight-fitting lid close the pitcher and shake vigorously. The Sangrita can be kept refrigerated for up to 4 days. Serve one shot of Cazadores añejo or extra añejo tequila with one shot of your homemade Sangrita.
Ingredients: Tomato juice;Orange juice;Salt;Dry pasilla chile (dried chilaca pepper);Ground pepper;Worcester sauce;Maggi sauce (optional);Valentina hot sauce;Grenadine;Fresh lime juice

Name: East 8
About: The inspired pairing of pineapple and passion fruit is what immediately stands out about this refreshing cocktail. Premium vodka and bitter liqueur give the East 8 its signature depth and complexity.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a rocks glass over large ice cubes. Garnish with palm leaves.
Ingredients: Grey Goose vodka;Pineapple juice;Aperol;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup;Passion fruit syrup

Name: Bombay Sapphire Negroni
About: Exceptionally smooth Bombay Sapphire gin strikes the perfect balance with bitter liqueur. Round that pair of ingredients out with some vermouth and you have a mouthwatering Negroni.
HowToMake: Add ingredients into a rocks glass with large ice cubes and stir briefly. Garnish with an orange peel.
Ingredients: Bombay Sapphire gin;Martini & Rossi bitter liqueur;Martini & Rossi rosso vermouth

Name: Gentleman and a Scholar
About: The Gentleman and a Scholar is the perfect synthesis of Ian McLaughlin’s bartending skills and environmental consciousness. He takes ingredients that would typically be thrown away—unused lime wheels overflowing beer and more—and adds them to house-made ingredients like strawberry beer syrup and aquafaba. The resulting cocktail is not just an eco-friendly take on the Whiskey Sour; it’s delicious enough to earn him a trip to the finals in the Gentleman Jack Whiskey Sour Classic.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker and dry-shake (no ice) for 30-45 seconds. Add ice and shake again for another 20-30 seconds. Double-strain into a cocktail glass and let sit for 5-10 seconds so the whip can gain form. Mist with the bitters twice. Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel. *Strawberry beer syrup: Add 1 qt beer 1 qt strawberry pureé and 1/2 to 1 cup sugar (preferably palm sugar) to a pot. Heat over stove until it’s reduced to 1 1/2 qts syrup. **Aquafaba: Take the water used to cook white legumes for hummus and boil until it’s reduced by half. Remove from heat and place into a container and refrigerate.
Ingredients: Gentleman Jack whiskey;Fresh lemon juice;Strawberry beer syrup;Aquafaba;Angostura bitters

Name: Bombay Sapphire Martini
About: The most important part of making an exceptional Martini is choosing the right gin. And there’s no better choice than Bombay Sapphire
HowToMake: Add ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir for 45 seconds. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.
Ingredients: Bombay Sapphire gin;Martini & Rossi dry vermouth

Name: Añejo Old Fashioned
About: The secret to a standout Old Fashioned is using a base spirit you would enjoy sipping on its own. And Patrón añejo more than meets that goal.
HowToMake: Express the oil from 2 orange peels into an Old Fashioned glass. Add tequila simple syrup and bitters to the glass. Add large ice cubes to glass and stir. Garnish with an orange twist.
Ingredients: Oil of 2 orange peels;Patrón añejo tequila;Simple syrup;Fresh lime juice;Angostura bitters

Name: Salty Dog
About: Isn’t it time you upgraded to a better breed of Greyhound? Mix the finest French vodka with freshly squeezed pink grapefruit juice for the best version of the classic drink.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Pour into a salt-rimmed Mason jar (or Collins glass). Garnish with a lime wheel grapefruit wedge and rosemary sprig.
Ingredients: Grey Goose vodka;Fresh pink grapefruit juice

Name: Five Island Flamingo
About: The Rum & Cola gets all the attention but mixing rum with grapefruit soda is even more refreshing. All the proof you need is in the Five Mile Flamingo.
HowToMake: Pour all ingredients into a Collins glass over ice. Garnish with a lime wedge.
Ingredients: Banks 5 Island rum;Fresh lime juice;Pink grapefruit soda

Name: The Original Bacardi Mojito
About: A cocktail as classic as the Mojito should only be made with the definitive rum: Bacardí. But the rum’s iconic status is far from the only reason to use it here. Bacardí Superior rum adds smooth and subtle notes of vanilla and almond to the recipe. It’s a flavor that doesn’t dominate or disappear which is perfect for any refreshing cocktail especially the Mojito.
HowToMake: Squeeze the lime wedges into a highball glass. Add the sugar and gently mix it with the lime juice. Bruise the mint leaves by clapping them between your palms. Rub the leaves on the rim of the glass and drop them in. Fill the glass half way with crushed ice add the Bacardí Superior rum and stir. Top with crushed ice and soda water. Garnish with a mint sprig.
Ingredients: Lime wedges;Extra fine sugar;Fresh mint leaves;Bacardí Superior rum;Soda water

Name: Hermosa Paloma
About: Instead of grapefruit soda try topping your Paloma with blackberry- and cucumber-flavored LaCroix. The way it mixes with Tequila Cazadores is beautiful—or hermosa.
HowToMake: Combine all ingredients except the sparkling water in a mixing glass with ice and stir. Pour into a highball glass over fresh ice.  Top with the sparkling water. Garnish with 2 cucumber slices.
Ingredients: Tequila Cazadores blanco;St-Germain;Fresh lime juice;LaCroix mure pepino sparkling water

Name: Jalisco Mule
About: The fizz and citrus of a classic mule are even more crisp and refreshing when paired with premium tequila. Grab a bottle of Patrón silver tequila and treat yourself to the Jalisco Mule.
HowToMake: Combine the tequila and lime juice in a chilled Moscow Mule mug filled with crushed ice. Top with the ginger beer and stir. Garnish with a lime wedge.
Ingredients: Patrón silver tequila;Ginger beer;Fresh lime juice

Name: Dickel Rye Manhattan
About: Only the rye from George Dickel is finished in the chilled charcoal-mellowed style. That leads to a spicy flavor and smooth finish that shines in spirit-forward cocktails like the Manhattan.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a cherry.
Ingredients: George Dickel rye whisky;Sweet vermouth;Angostura bitters

Name: Bourbon Lemonade
About: Light long and refreshing—the Bourbon Lemonade is a tangy and sweet combination that highlights the spicy notes of Bulleit’s high-rye bourbon.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a highball glass with ice. Garnish with a lemon wedge.
Ingredients: Bulleit bourbon;Lemonade

Name: Bombay Spritz
About: Why settle for the same old spritz? Try a better version of the summer classic by starting with Bombay Sapphire gin and balancing bitter liqueur with lemon juice and honey syrup then simply add some bubbles and enjoy.
HowToMake: Add first four ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a wine glass over fresh ice. Top with the prosecco and club soda. Garnish with half an orange wheel. *Honey syrup: Add 1/2 cup honey and 1/2 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for one month in the refrigerator.
Ingredients: Bombay Sapphire gin;Martini & Rossi Riserva Speciale bitter liqueur;Fresh lemon juice;Honey syrup;Prosecco;Club soda

Name: Bucket List
About: It’s no wonder this fresh and floral cocktail is named the Bucket List. Because everyone should get to experience how herbal liqueur and a splash of citrus and sweetness can make the finest French vodka even better.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a coupe. Garnish with a rosemary sprig.
Ingredients: Grey Goose vodka;Génépi herbal liqueur;Fresh lemon juice;Honey syrup

Name: St. Catherine’s Sound
About: Kyle Law’s riff on the Whiskey Sour is also a crash course in cocktail history. He uses Jerry Thomas’ classic sour template from 1862. In 1922 London barman Robert Vermeire wrote “A few drops of egg improves all sours.” Law followed this suggestion by milk-washing his house-made sour mix. That ingredient also reflects major bartending trends from the past 40 years. He uses freshly squeezed juice—a practice that became common in cocktail bars in the 1990s—to make a sour mix which was a staple of the 1980s. But you don’t need to know any of the history to appreciate the subtle and delicious St. Catherine’s Sound.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with 3 2-inch ice cubes and shake 6-10 times to chill and aerate the cocktail with minimal dilution. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube. Garnish with a dehydrated strawberry. *Acid-adjusted sour mix (milk-washed): Create an oleo with 10 grapefruit peels 10 lemon peels and 4 orange peels and let it sit overnight. Combine the oleo with 9 oz grapefruit juice 9 oz lemon juice and 4 1/2 oz orange juice until sugar dissolves. Bring 18 oz whole milk to a boil and slowly pour into sour mixture. Allow to sit and curdle for no less than 6 hours. Lastly pour mixture through a mesh strainer several times (use the same milk-curdle-filled strainer) until mixture is relatively clear.
