Add ascorbic acid to taste then bottle. Can be refrigerated for no longer than 15 days.
Ingredients: Gentleman Jack whiskey;Acid-adjusted sour mix (milk-washed);Braulio herbal liqueur;Creme de fraise des bois

Name: Sea Breeze
About: The tart flavors of grapefruit and cranberry juice are expertly balanced by amazingly smooth Grey Goose vodka. When you can’t make it to the beach pouring yourself a Sea Breeze is the next best thing.
HowToMake: Add the vodka and grapefruit juice into a highball glass with ice and stir. Top with cranberry juice. Garnish with a lime wheel.
Ingredients: Grey Goose vodka;Fresh grapefruit juice;Cranberry juice to top

Name: Tequila Cazadores Jalapeño Margarita
About: Punch up your Margarita with a little help from the jalapeño pepper. Its spicy flavor pairs well with the traditional mix of premium tequila triple sec lime juice and agave nectar.
HowToMake: Salt the rim of a rocks glass and set aside (optional). Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into prepared rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a lime wedge and jalapeño slice.
Ingredients: Cazadores blanco tequila;Premium triple sec;Agave nectar;Fresh lime juice;Jalapeño pepper

Name: Bacardi Hotel Nacional
About: You can get an idea of the Bacardí Hotel Nacional’s refreshing flavor simply by scanning the list of ingredients. But you need to taste this tropical cocktail to fully appreciate how aged rum pineapple juice apricot liqueur and lime juice elevate one another.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a pineapple leaf.
Ingredients: Bacardí Reserva Ocho rum;Pineapple juice;Apricot liqueur;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup

Name: Santorini Sour
About: In retrospect it might seem obvious that Greece a coastal country in the heart of the Mediterranean could inspire a refreshing spin on the Whiskey Sour. But pairing Gentleman Jack and citrus with Greek yogurt and pistachio syrup is an unexpected choice that really pays off.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except bitters into a shaker and dry-shake (no ice) for 15-20 seconds. Add ice and shake again for 10-15 seconds. Strain into a coupe glass. Add the bitters. Garnish with a lemon tree leaf. *Pistachio syrup: Add 4 oz whole pistachios (no shell) 1 oz chopped pistachios 3 cups water and 1/2 cup sugar to a pot and bring to a boil. Turn off heat and let sit for 10 minutes. Strain out the nuts add 2 cups sugar and stir until fully dissolved. Add 1/4 oz rose flower water 1/4 oz orange blossom water and 2 oz cognac. Seal and refrigerate.
Ingredients: Gentleman Jack whiskey;Fresh lemon juice;Pistachio syrup;Greek yogurt;Angostura bitters

Name: Bacardi Cuba Libre
About: Sometimes it’s the simplest drinks that are the most refreshing. That’s certainly true of the Bacardí Cuba Libre with its irresistible mix of gold rum cola and lime.
HowToMake: In a highball glass filled with ice squeeze the two lime wedges and add them to the glass. Add the rum and cola and gently mix with a bar spoon. Garnish with a lime wedge.
Ingredients: Bacardí Gold rum;Cola;Lime wedges

Name: Tequila Cazadores Classic Paloma
About: The best Palomas are the ones that let the tequila shine. This recipe proves that all you need to complement Cazadores blanco tequila is a splash of lime a pinch of salt and a bit of grapefruit soda.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the grapefruit soda into a highball glass over ice and stir. Top with grapefruit soda. Garnish with a lime wheel.
Ingredients: Cazadores blanco tequila;Fresh lime juice;Salt;Grapefruit soda to top

Name: Bacardi Cuatro Highball
About: Whisky is great and all but this rum highball is paradise in a glass. The Caribbean flavors of Bacardí Añejo Cuatro go perfectly with ginger ale.
HowToMake: Add ingredients into a highball glass over ice. Garnish with a lime wheel.
Ingredients: Bacardí Añejo Cuatro rum;Ginger ale;Aromatic bitters

Name: Island Tea Time
About: You don’t often find black tea listed as an ingredient in a tropical cocktail. After you experience how well it goes with rum orange curaçao lime juice and simple syrup you’re going to wonder why it doesn’t show up more often.
HowToMake: Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with a lemon twist.
Ingredients: Chilled black tea;Banks 5 Island rum;Orange curaçao;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup

Name: French Press Sangria
About: Rather than using a French press to coax out flavor from coffee beans Jasmine Jernberg a bartender at Blue Bohème in San Diego layers batches of her Sangria that’s pressed tableside. “This preparation really brings out the brightness of the fruit and blends it into the drink beautifully” she says. “It’s a mainstay on our patio during social hour because it’s thirst-quenching and easy to drink yet still packs enough of a punch to take the edge off a long hot day.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “6 Delightful Sangrias to Drink in Bars Now.”
HowToMake: Serves 7. In a large bowl combine everything except the fruit slices. Layer the orange lime and lemon slices along the base of a French press. For each serve pour the mixture to fill a French press and press. Pour into a wine glass over ice. Garnish with an orange slice and sprig of basil.
Ingredients: Red wine;White wine;Cognac;Grand Marnier;Agave syrup;Raspberry purée;Orange thinly sliced;Lime thinly sliced;Lemon thinly sliced

Name: Darkside
About: This cocktail in Derek Brown’s book “Spirits Sugar Water Bitters: How the Cocktail Conquered the World” was created by Washington D.C. bartender Adam Bernbach at now-closed Bar Pilar where he ran a “unique program” called Cocktail Sessions according to Brown in his book. “Guests could cozy up to the bar and order a cocktail tasting where Adam would fix three original cocktails using twists on classics” says Brown. Chinato is historically considered an aromatized wine like vermouth. It includes quinine bark the same ingredient found in tonic that gives it a bitter edge.This recipe originally appeared as part of “Inside the One Important City That’s Influence Was Ignored During the Cocktail Renaissance.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until cold. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.
Ingredients: Dry gin;Barolo chinato;Peychaud’s bitters

Name: Triple Berry Chamomile Frosé
About: “Frosé has been done over and over so the true inspiration was finding a way to incorporate new flavors and offer our guests a new experience” says Gary Wallach the director of food and beverage at A.R.T. SoHo at the Arlo SoHo hotel in New York City. “The berries pull out all the fruit notes in the rosé making it a well-rounded cocktail.” The Kelvin mix is made with organic peach and strawberry juice and no artificial colors or corn syrup.This recipe originally appeared as part of “Bring On the Brain Freeze with These Vodka Slushie Recipes.”
HowToMake: Serves 2. Add all ingredients into a blender with 2-3 cups ice and blend until smooth. Pour into a large wine glass. Garnish with a mint sprig and a skewered strawberry blueberry and raspberry. *Triple berry shrub: Add 1 cup strawberries 1 cup blueberries 1 cup raspberries 1 1/2 cups sugar and 1 cup water into a large pot and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for 20 minutes stirring occasionally until liquid has reduced by a third. Add 1 1/2 cups apple cider vinegar and simmer on low for 5 minutes. Remove from heat allow to cool strain into a glass bottle and store in refrigerator.
Ingredients: Chapoutier Côtes du Rhône rosé;Absolut vodka;Kelvin frosé mix;Triple berry shrub;Brewed chamomile tea;Blueberry

Name: Sgroppino
About: Pietro Caldarelli the beverage director at Feroce at the Moxy Chelsea hotel in New York City mixes this cocktail tableside and says making it is just about as fun as drinking one. “The cliffs of Amalfi and village[s] on water cities of Italy are about as picturesque as summer can get” he says. “This regional Italian frozen cocktail derived from Venice is the ultimate summer refresher.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “Bring On the Brain Freeze with These Vodka Slushie Recipes.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a chilled bowl and whip until foamy and velvety. Pout into a white wine glass.
Ingredients: Sorrento lemon sorbet;Valdo prosecco chilled;Tito’s Handmade vodka

Name: Montego Mule
About: Justin Golash’s homage to drinking on the beach in Jamaica uses a recipe for ginger beer that was his introduction into craft bartending. “It’s a great summer slushie because the heat from the ginger and ancho powder contrasts against the bright acidity of the lime juice giving a very refreshing flavor” says the lead bartender of Washington D.C.’s DNV Rooftop Lounge at The Kimpton Donovan hotel. “Plus it’s based on the Moscow Mule which is a summertime classic.” To prevent waste Golash freezes leftover lime juice after service to use for the drinks.This recipe originally appeared as part of “Bring On the Brain Freeze with These Vodka Slushie Recipes.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a blender with 12 oz dry crushed or pebble ice and blend. Pour into a 12 oz Collins glass. Garnish with a cocktail umbrella. *Ginger juice: Using either a centrifugal or masticating juicer juice 3 oz peeled and washed ginger pieces. Filter it through a chinois. Let sit overnight. **Spice syrup: Add 1 L water 1 L demerara sugar the zest of 2 medium oranges 1/2 g crushed green cardamom pods 5 g black peppercorns 5 g coriander 2 1/2 g ancho powder and 1 g eucalyptus into a pot. Bring to a boil and simmer for 20 minutes to extract flavors then filter through a chinois.
Ingredients: Vodka;Ginger juice;Spice syrup;Fresh lime juice

Name: Platinum Blond
About: A grapefruit and rosemary infusion is citrusy and herbal and works perfectly in this sour riff by Adam Gamboa of Denver’s Il Posto. “Don’t limit yourself—you can create almost any flavor profile imaginable with a bottle of vodka and a sous vide” he says. This recipe originally appeared as part of “Infusing Your Own Flavored Vodka Through Science. It’s Easier Than You Think.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a rosemary sprig. *Grapefruit-rosemary-infused vodka: Add 1 L vodka 1 peeled and sliced grapefruit and 2 sticks of rosemary into a Mason jar and sous vide for 2 hours at 130 degrees Fahrenheit starting the timer once the bath hits the desired temperature. (Make sure you place the Mason jar in the bath before starting the sous vide otherwise the rapid heating could break the jar.) Strain once the jar is cool enough to handle. Store in the refrigerator for up to a few weeks.
Ingredients: Grapefruit-rosemary-infused vodka;Elderflower liqueur;Fresh grapefruit juice;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup

Name: Elder Greene Blues
About: This recipe by Adam Gamboa of Denver’s Il Posto employs two different infusions made sous vide at the same time. Here both cucumber and fresh basil leaves lend different herbal flavors to the spirit.This recipe originally appeared as part of “Infusing Your Own Flavored Vodka Through Science. It’s Easier Than You Think.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Pour into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a lemon wheel and a few cracked peppercorns. *Cucumber-basil-infused vodka: In a Mason jar add 1 L vodka 1/3 of a cucumber (sliced) 10 basil leaves 5 Fresno peppers (or sweet peppers if you don’t want spice) and 2 thyme sprigs and set aside. In a second Mason jar add 2 cups white table sugar and 2 cups very hot water shake to dissolve most of the sugar then add 25 basil leaves. Place both jars into a sous vide bath for 2 hours at 130 degrees Fahrenheit. Let cool then strain out solids. Add an additional 15 basil leaves to the second Mason jar chill for about 2 hours in the refrigerator then strain out solids.
Ingredients: Cucumber-basil-infused vodka;Grand Marnier;Infused basil syrup;Fresh lime juice

Name: Coco Curry Colada
About: Sure the mouthwatering mix of curry and coconut is more common in Southeast Asian restaurants than cocktail bars. But the Coco Curry Colada proves that savory flavor is just as welcome in a summer cocktail. This recipe originally appeared as part of “10 Classic Cocktails Ready for a Refreshing Summer Makeover.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a chilled Old Fashioned glass over fresh ice. Garnish with mint and a dehydrated lime wheel. *Madras-curry-infused Azuñia reposado organic tequila: Weigh 30 g Madras curry and 300 g tequila on a scale and combine in a sealable plastic bag. Sous-vide at 130 degrees for 90 minutes. Strain and store for up to 2 weeks.
Ingredients: Madras-curry-infused Azuñia reposado organic tequila;Stolen overproof rum;Coconut milk (full fat);Coco Reàl cream of coconut;Fresh pineapple juice;Fresh lime juice

Name: Hennessy Ginger
About: This simple mix of Hennessy and ginger ale is perfect for any hour. Pour one for yourself to experience how the spice of the ginger ale brings out the natural spice in Hennessy V.S.
HowToMake: Pour cognac into a double Old Fashioned glass. Add ice cubes until glass is filled. Top with ginger ale. Garnish with a lime wedge and skewered fresh slices of ginger.
Ingredients: Hennessy V.S. cognac;Ginger ale

Name: Verano en Valencia
About: Technically you only need to mix a spirit with tonic water or club soda to make a highball. But why stop there? Go above and beyond by utilizing premium tequila and bringing in refreshing ingredients like apricot liqueur port wine and lemon juice. This recipe originally appeared as part of “10 Classic Cocktails Ready for a Refreshing Summer Makeover.”
HowToMake: Combine all ingredients except the tonic water in a wine glass over fresh ice. Top with the tonic water. Garnish with fresh thyme sprigs and a dehydrated lemon wheel.
Ingredients: Azuñia reposado organic tequila;Taylor Fladgate dry white port;Giffard apricot liqueur;Fresh lemon juice;Fever-Tree Mediterranean tonic water

Name: Blueberry Mojito
About: Nothing against the classic Mojito but using premium cognac and adding blueberries to the mix leads to an even more refreshing cocktail.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except soda water into a shaker with ice and shake until blueberries are bruised. Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice. Top with soda water. Garnish with a mint sprig and blueberries.
Ingredients: Hennessy V.S.O.P Privilège cognac;Simple syrup;Fresh lime juice;Blueberries;Soda water to top

Name: Mango Basil Lemonade
About: This simple and refreshing recipe brings together Hennessy V.S. cognac with an exotic pair of ingredients: mango and basil. It’s good for any summer occasion. But try multiplying the recipe and making a pitcher for a party on the patio.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except soda water into a shaker and shake. Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice. Top with soda water. Garnish with a basil leaf and lemon wheel.
Ingredients: Hennessy V.S. cognac;Fresh lemon juice;Mango purée;Simple syrup;Soda water to top

Name: Hennessy Jalapiña
About: As the name would suggest the Jalapiña is a seamless mix of jalapeño and pineapple. But it’s Hennessy V.S. that anchors this irresistible balance of spicy and sweet.
HowToMake: Muddle jalapeño in a shaker. Add the cognac pineapple juice and ice and shake. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a pineapple slice and leaf.
Ingredients: Jalapeño;Hennessy V.S. cognac;Pineapple juice

Name: Pink Peppercorn Botanical Gimlet
About: The peppery notes of this Gimlet offset all the spirit’s floral and fruit notes.This recipe originally appeared as part of “On the Fence About Gin? Try 3 Ways to Use 3 Gin-Like Vodkas.”
HowToMake: In a cocktail shaker lightly muddle the pink peppercorns until crushed. Add remaining ingredients with ice and shake until well-chilled. Double-strain into a highball glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a lime wheel and a few peppercorns.
Ingredients: Square One Botanical vodka;Fresh lime juice;Agave nectar;Pink peppercorns

Name: Wormhole Warrior
About: This stirred libation is similar to a citrusy Martini.This recipe originally appeared as part of “On the Fence About Gin? Try 3 Ways to Use 3 Gin-Like Vodkas.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir for 12 seconds. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a mint sprig and lemon peel.
Ingredients: Cocalero Clásico Herbal Spirit Vodka;Dry vermouth;Tempus Fugit Gran Classico bitter;Orange bitters

Name: Botanical Bee's Knees
About: The traditional Bees’ Knees gets a heady upgrade as chamomile tea and peach and orange blossom vodka lend a delicate quality to honey and lemon. This recipe originally appeared as part of “On the Fence About Gin? Try 3 Ways to Use 3 Gin-Like Vodkas.”
HowToMake: Brew the tea bags in 4 oz hot water according to package directions. Remove tea bags and let cool. Add the vodka lemon juice honey and tea into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with 2 lemon slices.
Ingredients: Chamomile tea bags;Ketel One Botanical Peach & Orange Blossom vodka;Fresh lemon juice;Honey

Name: Life on Mars
About: Ponyboy bar manager Ryan Goodman and his team’s easy-drinking cocktails keep it fun in Oklahoma City like with this drink by bartender Erin Heatly named after David Bowie’s song. Light and refreshing it sips like spring with acid (citric lactic and malic) and a sweet-and-sour profile from Grey Goose La Poire vodka Pomp & Whimsy gin liqueur and a house lavender lychee syrup. This recipe originally appeared as part of “9 Great Vodka Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake briefly. Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice. Top with the soda water. Garnish with orange and lemon peels cut into lightning bolts. *Lavender-lychee syrup: Drain syrup from 16 oz can of lychees. Bring syrup to a boil over medium heat and add 5 g dried lavender. Remove from heat and steep 10 minutes. Strain solids add 5 oz granulated sugar and stir to combine. Refrigerate and store. Will last 4 weeks in refrigerator.
Ingredients: Grey Goose La Poire vodka;Pomp & Whimsy gin liqueur;Fresh lemon juice;Lavender-lychee syrup;Soda water

Name: South Mint 75
About: Since the chef at Bardo in Charlotte N.C. is fond of using Asian ingredients head bartender Amanda Britton likes to mirror that in the glass and see how they translate into a cocktail. “This French 75 variation has depth and the addition of lemongrass kicks up the refreshing factor” she says.This recipe originally appeared as part of “7 Variations on the French 75 to Drink in Bars Now.”
HowToMake: Add the gin lemon juice lemongrass syrup and 6 smacked/expressed mint leaves into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Double-strain into a coupe glass. Top with brut cava. Garnish with a mint leaf that has been smacked between your hands to express the oil. *Lemongrass syrup: Combine 1 cup sugar 2 peeled lemongrass stalks (sliced) and 1 cup water in a small saucepan. Bring to a simmer and continue to simmer for 10 minutes or until desired flavor is achieved. Remove from heat cool and strain out solids. Store in the refrigerator for up to one week.
Ingredients: Sutler’s gin;Lemongrass syrup;Fresh lemon juice;Mint leaves;Brut cava to top

Name: Smoked Rosemary Negroni
About: The Negroni with its holy trinity of ingredients is the Mr. Potato Head of classic cocktails. Simply mix and match your spirit bitter liqueur and vermouth to create something fun and original. This version calls for mezcal and rosemary-infused Campari which lends the drink a smoky herbaceous backbone. Dial up the smoke even more with a flamed rosemary garnish—optional but highly recommended.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Express oil from a grapefruit peel over the drink and discard. Garnish with a rosemary sprig. (Optional: Using a kitchen torch flame the rosemary until it smokes and extinguish before serving.). *Rosemary-infused Campari: In a large Mason jar combine 12 oz Campari and 4 rosemary sprigs and seal. Let sit at room temperature for 24 hours shaking occasionally. Strain out solids and keep in the refrigerator for up to one month.
Ingredients: Mezcal;Sweet vermouth;Rosemary-infused Campari

Name: 1928 Sea Breeze
About: This version of a Sea Breeze by David Moo the owner of Quarter Bar in Brooklyn is a mashup of the old and new: gin equal-parts house-made grenadine and fresh ruby-red grapefruit juice. This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Inside Story of the Sea Breeze Cocktail.”
HowToMake: In a highball glass add the gin and grenadine and stir. Add ice and top with pink grapefruit juice. *Homemade grenadine: Add equal-parts pomegranate juice and sugar into a saucepan on low heat and simmer until sugar dissolves. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with lid. Will keep in refrigerator for one month.
Ingredients: Gordon’s gin;Homemade grenadine;Fresh pink grapefruit juice to top

Name: Sea Breeze Cooler
About: This gin-based cocktail can be found in Harry Craddock’s 1930 “The Savoy Cocktail Book.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Inside Story of the Sea Breeze Cocktail.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except soda water into a highball glass over ice. Top with soda water. Garnish with a mint sprig.
Ingredients: Dry gin;Apricot brandy;Grenadine;Juice of 1/2 a lemon;Soda water to top

Name: Peach Me
About: “Peach goes well with orange ginger and vanilla to complement these flavors and bring out the fruitiness” says Jason Shullo the corporate director of beverage for Golden Entertainment which operates casinos and resorts in Nevada and Maryland. It works well in bourbon-based drinks like Smashes Cobblers or Juleps. In his nuanced version of an Old Fashioned the bourbon plays up the liqueur’s peach notes while bitters temper its sweetness.This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with This? Peach Schnapps. What It Is and How to Use It.”
HowToMake: Muddle the cherry orange slice and bitters in a mixing glass. Add the bourbon schnapps and ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice sphere. Garnish with a dehydrated or fresh orange slice.
Ingredients: Luxardo maraschino cherry;Orange slice;Angostura orange bitters;Woodford Reserve bourbon;Peach schnapps

Name: Tea of Two
About: This drink by Amy Wong the lead bartender at King Tide Fish & Shell in Portland Ore. is a take on a Philadelphia Fish House Punch. It includes half a cup of peach schnapps where it sweetens and adds fruitiness to Jamaican rum and cognac. “Peach schnapps pairs best with fruit-forward spirits” she says. “Vodkas won’t fight the flavors of [it] but it’s not as dimensioned and wouldn’t be my first choice.” This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with This? Peach Schnapps. What It Is and How to Use It.”
HowToMake: Serves 12 6-oz pours. Peel the lemons juice and set juice aside. Add the peels to the sugar stir to combine and let macerate for several hours to form an oleo saccharum then remove and discard the peels. In a large punch bowl combine the oleo saccharum rum cognac peach schnapps tea and lemon juice and add a large ice block. Garnish with thin lemon wheels and peach slices.
Ingredients: Lemons peeled and reserved;Sugar;Jamaican rum;Cognac;Peach schnapps;Brewed black tea;Fresh lemon juice from reserved lemons

Name: Mule
About: “I enjoy sweet liqueurs in something that has a little spice such as a Mule with fresh ginger and soda” says Jeremy Allen the general manager of MiniBar in Los Angeles. “Peach schnapps is surprisingly versatile and you can use almost any liquor as the base” he says. Any base spirit would work well but he prefers rum vodka tequila mezcal or gin with his Mule.This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with This? Peach Schnapps. What It Is and How to Use It.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a Collins glass over ice. Top with ginger beer. Garnish with a lime wedge.
Ingredients: Dark rum vodka tequila mezcal or gin;Peach schnapps;Ginger juice;Fresh lime juice;Fentimans ginger beer to top

Name: Brandy Sangaree
About: Dating back to the late 1700s this single-serving punch is the perfect open-ended drink. At its simplest it’s sweet spicy and low on alcohol. But add a shot of your favorite brandy and things get even more interesting.
HowToMake: Add the sugar and water into a mixing glass and stir until sugar is dissolved. Add the brandy port wine and ice and stir. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.
Ingredients: Sugar;Water;Brandy;Port wine

Name: Definite Maybe
About: Daniel Osborne the beverage director at Portland Ore.’s Abigail Hall in the Woodlark hotel has fun with agave pulling inspiration from the orange creamsicle for this cocktail. Banhez mezcal and Dolin génépy get a citrus kick from fresh orange and lemon juices unfolding with minty intrigue from a mint simple syrup that enhances the smoke of the mezcal. This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Tequila and Mezcal Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Double-strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with an orange peel.
Ingredients: Banhez mezcal;Dolin génépy;Orange juice;Fresh lemon juice;Mint simple syrup;Angostura bitters

Name: Grey Goose Blood Orange Sangria
About: Sangria may hail from Spain but nothing elevates the recipe quite like premium vodka and French pinot noir. A hefty dose of fresh pomegranate juice rounds out the subtly tart twist on the classic cocktail.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a wine glass over ice and stir well. Garnish with a blood orange slice.
Ingredients: Grey Goose vodka;French pinot noir;Fresh lemon juice;Fresh pomegranate juice;Fresh blood orange juice;Orange cut into wedges;Lemon wheels;Powdered clove

Name: Santa Teresa 1796 Old Fashioned
About: A good Old Fashioned will always require three elements: sweetness bitters and a high-quality base spirit. But who says the base spirit needs to be whiskey? Try making this classic cocktail with Santa Teresa 1796 rum. Its dry smooth and balanced flavor is exactly what you need to make a delicious Old Fashioned.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir for 30-40 seconds. Strain into an Old Fashioned glass over fresh ice. Garnish with an orange twist.
Ingredients: Santa Teresa 1796 rum;Demerara syrup;Angostura bitters

Name: Grey Goose Green Fairy
About: Limes melon schnapps and green apple syrup are all the same color but that’s not the only thing they have in common. They all mix wonderfully with Grey Goose Le Citron vodka. Need proof? Try the Grey Goose Green Fairy.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake well. Strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with a fresh mint leaf.
Ingredients: Grey Goose Le Citron vodka;Fresh lime juice;Melon schnapps;Monin pomme verte syrup

Name: Tequila Sunrise
About: Nathan Elliott the head bartender at Portland Ore.’s Bacchus Bar in Kimpton Hotel Vintage keeps the Tequila Sunrise on regular rotation on his menu. “When this cocktail is made properly with fresh ingredients and a high-quality tequila it can be a true thing of wonder” he says.This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Tequila Sunrise Is So Much Better Than It Needs to Be.”
HowToMake: Add the tequila and juice into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a highball glass over fresh ice. Carefully pour the grenadine down the inside of the glass to allow the drink to layer creating a "sunrise." Garnish with a dehydrated orange wheel and maraschino cherry. *Spiced grenadine: Bring 2 cups POM Wonderful 100% pomegranate juice to a boil then reduce heat. Stir in 2 cups sugar 2 oz pomegranate molasses 1 tsp orange blossom water 4 star anise 1 tbsp whole allspice 1 tsp whole pink peppercorn and 1/4 tsp sea salt. Allow spices to steep for 15-20 minutes. Strain and bottle. Allow to cool in the fridge before using.
Ingredients: Espolón reposado tequila;Fresh Cara Cara orange juice;Spiced grenadine

Name: Jeez Louise
About: This modern take on a Sour at Revel Cafe & Bar in New Orleans uses amaro for the base spirit. Feel free to substitute other brands but bartender and drink creator Chris McMillian has found the best ratio to get just the right amount of bitterness to be a three-to-one ratio of Averna to Cynar. This recipe originally appeared as part of “Is One Relatively Unknown Drink in New Orleans the Perfect Drink for 2019?”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the soda water into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice. Top with the soda water. Garnish with an orange wheel. Serve with a straw.
Ingredients: Averna amaro;Cynar;Cointreau;Fresh lime juice;Soda water to top

Name: Whiskey Sour
About: For the current standard of sour at New York City’s Ward III Kenneth McCoy finds the soft caramel notes of Heaven Hill bourbon can take a little extra sour so he tarts it up a bit from his standard equal-parts citrus-sweet with a little extra lemon juice and a red wine float as in a New York Sour. This recipe originally appeared as part of “6 Things You Should Know About the Whiskey Sour.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the wine into a shaker with ice and shake. Double-strain into a chilled rocks glass over fresh ice. Gently drizzle the wine over the top. Garnish with a skewered maraschino cherry and orange wheel.
Ingredients: Heaven Hill bourbon;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup;Egg white;Chianti red wine float

Name: Sussex 75
About: Give the French 75 a British makeover by replacing Champagne with Ridgeview English sparkling wine. It’s an improvement considering that the Sussex-based winery was named 2018 Winemaker of the Year at the International Wine & Spirit Competition. Keep it British all the way through by using exceptionally smooth Hendrick’s gin. It’s the perfect time to enjoy the Sussex 75 considering the Duchess of Sussex just gave birth. Make one today and toast the new royal baby Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor.
HowToMake: Add the gin and lemon juice into a flute. Top with sparkling wine. Garnish with a lemon twist.
Ingredients: Hendrick’s gin;Fresh lemon juice;Ridgeview English sparkling wine to top

Name: 101 Old Fashioned
About: The Old Fashioned has been delighting drinkers for more than 200 years and its formula hasn’t really changed over the centuries. It’s still a mouthwatering trinity of whiskey sugar and bitters. Some argue that it’s the first recorded cocktail recipe dating back to the dawn of the 19th century. It would certainly make the name appropriate. But you’re looking for a cocktail recipe not a history lesson. Start by using a whiskey you enjoy sipping neat or on the rocks; the Old Fashioned isn’t the kind of cocktail that masks the flavor of the spirit. Wild Turkey 101 is an excellent choice for its higher proof and rye content. All you need to finish it off is some simple syrup bitters and an orange peel.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into an Old Fashioned glass over fresh ice. Express the oil of an orange peel over glass and garnish with the peel.
Ingredients: Wild Turkey 101 bourbon;Simple syrup;Angostura bitters

Name: Volcanico
About: Some purists might think the best way to enjoy Flor de Caña 12-year-old rum is neat or on the rocks. But a little coffee liqueur chile liqueur and smoke can add hints of bitterness and spice to the full-bodied and Fair Trade Certified rum. It’s a unique smooth flavor you really need to try. When you choose Fair Trade Certified Flor de Caña rum you’re voting with your dollar—supporting income sustainability worker empowerment community development and environmental stewardship.
HowToMake: Using a kitchen torch light a 2”-long piece of applewood (or other wood of your liking) over a nonflammable surface until the top smolders and begins to smoke. Place a jar or carafe over the wood until it fills with smoke (for about 15 seconds) then seal immediately. In a mixing glass add all ingredients with ice and stir until chilled. Strain into the smoke-filled jar and seal. Gently swirl the contents aerating the liquid with smoke. (The longer you swirl the smokier the cocktail will be.). Pour into a snifter.
Ingredients: Flor de Caña 12-year-old rum;Cold-brew coffee liqueur;Ancho Reyes chile liqueur;Orange bitters

Name: Grey Goose Leafy Green
About: This floral and fizzy vodka cocktail is pretty much a garden in a glass. Whether it’s spring or summer—or you just want to pretend it is—you’ll appreciate the way the elderflower cordial celery and lime juice perfectly complement Grey Goose.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the soda water into a shaker with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into a highball glass over fresh ice. Top with soda water. Garnish with a celery stick.
Ingredients: Grey Goose vodka;Elderflower cordial;Fresh lime juice;Celery juice;Chartreuse;Soda water to top

Name: Blue Hawaiian Recip
About: Not to be confused with the Harry Yee classic the Blue Hawaii the Blue Hawaiian is little more than a Piña Colada with an added splash of blue curaçao. Tall teal and aggressively tropical it’s the type of drink you’d imagine sipping by the swimming pool another cocktail du azure.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a Hurricane glass over pebble ice. Garnish with a pineapple wedge cherry and cocktail umbrella. into glass.
Ingredients: Light rum;Blue curaçao;Pineapple juice;Creme de coconut;Fresh lemon juice

Name: Bebbo
About: Put summer’s blood oranges to good use in this light citrusy gin drink from Ted Haigh’s 2004 book “Vintage Spirits and Forgotten Cocktails.”
HowToMake: Pour ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake for 30 seconds. Fine-strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist.
Ingredients: London dry gin;Honey syrup (equal parts honey and water);Fresh lemon juice;Fresh blood orange juice

Name: Patrón Margarita
About: Take your Margarita to another level by using Patrón silver tequila and Patrón Citrónge orange liqueur. Once you taste this Margarita you’ll discover what a difference a couple of premium ingredients can make.
HowToMake: Salt half the rim of a rocks glass and set aside (optional). Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into the prepared glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a lime wedge.
Ingredients: Patrón silver tequila;Patrón Citrónge orange liqueur;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup

Name: Summer Serve Copa
About: This elevated take on the classic Gin & Tonic doubles down on flavor and freshness without complicating the recipe. It’s all the proof you need that Portobello Road gin pairs perfectly with tonic.
HowToMake: Fill a large red wine glass with ice and add the gin. Slowly top with tonic water. Slice off a thick peel of pink grapefruit and twist over the glass to release the oils from the skin then place twist in the drink. Sprinkle six to eight juniper berries on top.
Ingredients: Portobello Road gin;Tonic water to top

Name: Flørodoro
About: The cocktails by Liam Deegan the bar director at Longway in New Orleans lean mostly classic but the Flørodoro is a simple but delightful mix of The Botanist gin fino sherry lime Giffard crème de framboise (raspberry) lime and ginger beer. Bright fruity subtly spiced and floral the fino imparts a dry backbone. This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Gin Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain over ice into a Collins glass over fresh ice. Top with ginger beer.
Ingredients: The Botanist gin;Valdespino Inocente fino sherry;Fresh lime juice;Giffard crème de framboise liqueur;Simple syrup;Ginger beer to top

Name: Macaulay Culkin
About: David Velasco the beverage manager at The Lanes at The Howard in Oshkosh Wisc. deems amaretto a “very versatile ingredient with a lot of missed potential” and especially likes the way it plays with chocolate red and dark fruits and spices like cinnamon nutmeg and vanilla. This tequila sour gets some deep cocoa tones from chocolate bitters.This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with This? Amaretto: What It Is and How to Use It.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker and dry-shake (no ice). Add ice and shake again until well-chilled and a smooth froth forms. Strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a rosemary sprig.
Ingredients: Blanco tequila;Amaretto;Fresh lemon juice;Fresh lime juice;Agave syrup;Egg white;Chocolate bitters

Name: Spiced Margarita
About: Joan Villanueva the beverage curator at BO-beau kitchen + caché in San Diego sees a lot of application for amaretto with bold and spicy flavors like mezcal tequila and rye. In this Margarita version amaretto stands in for orange liqueur and muddled jalapeño slices lend a touch of lip-tingling heat.This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with This? Amaretto: What It Is and How to Use It.”
HowToMake: Rub half of the outside of a rocks glass with a lime wedge dip in salt to coat and set aside. Add the jalapeño wheels into a shaker and gently muddle. Add the tequila amaretto lime juice and ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into the prepared glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a lime wheel.
Ingredients: Lime;Jalapeño;Blanco tequila;Amaretto;Fresh lime juice

Name: Amaretto French 75
About: For this twist on the classic French 75 swapping out simple syrup for amaretto lends a “lush toasty note” says Ryan Ward the beverage director at Momofuku CCDC in Washington D.C. He prefers Nikka Coffey gin which has lots of citrus and green pepper botanicals from sansho peppers a relative of the Szechuan peppercorn. “Amaretto isn’t just almond; it has notes of vanilla citrus and some baking spice.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with This? Amaretto: What It Is and How to Use It.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the sparkling wine into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a coupe glass. Top with the sparkling wine. Garnish with a lemon curl.
Ingredients: Nikka Coffey gin;Amaretto;Fresh lemon juice;Brut sparkling wine chilled

Name: Finlandia Oaks Lily
About: The refreshing mix of vodka sweet-and-sour mix triple sec and cranberry juice is perfect for an outdoor occasion on a spring day. No wonder it’s the official vodka cocktail of the Kentucky Derby.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a speared blackberry and lemon twist.
Ingredients: Finlandia vodka;Triple sec;Cranberry juice;Sweet-and-sour mix

Name: Flor Sparkling
About: Flor de Caña 18-year-old rum is typically enjoyed neat. But a little sparkling water can turn the full-bodied rum into a refreshing drink. Just don’t add more than a splash—you still want to savor the ultra-premium rum’s full-bodied flavor.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into an Old Fashioned glass over ice. Garnish with an orange twist.
Ingredients: Flor de Caña 18-year-old rum;Premium sparkling water
Brands: Flor de Caña;Flor de Cana Rum

Name: Jack Daniel’s Brooklyn
About: The Brooklyn cocktail adds maraschino liqueur to the Manhattan giving the classic drink a little more complexity and sweetness. This recipe includes another upgrade: Jack Daniel’s Tennessee Rye whiskey. It brings the smoothness you expect from Jack and rye’s uniquely bold and spicy flavor to the Brooklyn cocktail.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.
Ingredients: Jack Daniel’s Tennessee Rye whiskey;Dry vermouth;Amer Picon;Maraschino liqueur

Name: Jack Daniel’s Brunswick
About: Claret adds more than a striking look to this cocktail. (Although floating it does look pretty cool.) The wine brings an extra level of complexity and depth to the refreshing trinity of rye whiskey lemon juice and simple syrup.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the wine into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Float the wine on top. Garnish with an orange slice and 2 cherries.
Ingredients: Jack Daniel’s Tennessee Rye whiskey;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup;Claret red wine

Name: Jack Daniel’s Sazerac
About: Great rye whiskey can turn a standard Sazerac into something incredible. That’s why this recipe specifically calls for Jack Daniel’s Tennessee rye which is made with Jack’s signature charcoal mellowing process and a 70 percent rye grain bill. It’s the only way to make a Sazerac this spicy and smooth.
HowToMake: Rinse a chilled rocks glass with absinthe discarding any excess and set aside. Add remaining ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into the absinthe-rinsed glass. Twist a lemon peel over the surface of the glass to express the oils. Drop the lemon twist into the glass to garnish.
Ingredients: Absinthe to rinse;Jack Daniel’s Tennessee Rye whiskey;Simple syrup;Peychaud’s bitters

Name: Earl Grey MarTEAni
About: This original twist on the Gin Sour comes by way of one of the pioneers of the modern cocktail movement Audrey Saunders of New York City’s Pegu Club.
HowToMake: Take a chilled coupe glass half-rim it with sugar and set aside. Pour all ingredients into a shaker without ice and dry-shake vigorously (at least 10 seconds). Add ice and shake again. Strain into prepared coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist. *Earl Grey tea-infused Tanqueray gin: Add 4 tbsp Earl Grey tea leaves into a 750 mL bottle of Tanqueray gin (or other high-proof dry gin) cap and shake. Let sit at room temperature for at least 2 hours. Strain the infused gin through a coffee filter into a separate container. Rinse out bottle to remove loose tea and pour gin back into clean bottle. Can be stored indefinitely if refrigerated.
Ingredients: Earl Grey–tea-infused Tanqueray gin ;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup;Egg white

Name: Trash Tiki Citrus Stock
About: Trash Tiki is a pop-up and online platform dedicated to reducing waste across the bar industry globally. And its citrus stock recipe which was conceptualized by co-founder Kelsey Ramage and partner Iain Griffiths alongside Ryan Chetiyawardana in London bar Dandelyan’s juicing room is a simple yet effective 30-minute process of pressure-cooking spent citrus husks (pulp and all) in water then straining and adjusting with acid and sugar to produce a liquid that essentially acts as a juice substitute or volume enhancer. It’s a waste-reduction and resource-doubling technique that offers something the usual suspects (oleo saccharum cordials preserves dehydrating for garnishes and the like) do not. This recipe originally appeared as part of “Repurpose Your Citrus with This Waste-Reducing Hack.”
HowToMake: Add the water and husks to a large pot and let boil for 5 minutes. Remove the husks (your stock will go bitter if you leave any longer) giving a quick squeeze back into the mixture as you pull them out. Remove the liquid from heat quickly and measure. (Accounting for some loss in heat evaporation and absorption from the husks it should be 44 fluid oz give or take). Place back on high heat until liquid is reduced by 50 percent then add the sugar. Add the citric and malic acid according to ratio based on citrus type.*. Remove from heat filter bottle and refrigerate. *Acid ratios by based on citrus varieties: Lemon and lime: 3% citric 2% malic Orange and grapefruit: 2% citric 1% malic Mandarin etc.: 1% citric 2% malic. Note: This recipe can easily be scaled up or down based on how much supply you’re working with or the volume you’re aiming to produce. Citrus stock can be kept fresh for three days or frozen for one month.
Ingredients: Water;Citrus husks (halved and juiced);Large strainer (such as Superbag or chinois);White sugar;Citric acid;Malic acid

Name: Peeping Tom
About: Peeps those oddly addictive marshmallow candies that look like conjoined chicks with a staring problem are usually the last thing left in the Easter basket. This holiday turn them into a cocktail garnish with this festive riff on the Aviation.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a coupe. Garnish with 2 Peeps marshmallow candies.
Ingredients: Old Tom gin;Crème de violette;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup

Name: Irish Affogato
About: The Irish Coffee is one of the most popular drinks in the cocktail canon and now you can have it for dessert. This boozy twist on the traditional affogato made with coffee ice cream cold-brew coffee Irish whiskey and Baileys brings two great ideas together. Want to scale back the dairy and ramp up the buzz? Skip the whipped cream garnish and add another half ounce of whiskey.
HowToMake: In a Georgian Irish Coffee mug add all ingredients. Garnish with whipped cream and chocolate shavings.
Ingredients: Irish whiskey;Baileys Irish cream;Coffee ice cream;Cold-brew coffee

Name: Manhattan
About: “Creating a beautifully balanced cocktail with Chartreuse can be challenging as few spirits stand up to its bold profile” says Adam Gamboa the lead bartender at Il Posto in Denver. It works well with lots of different herbs as well as anise coffee and vanilla he says. “But for those not interested in all that tomfoolery this simple variation of the classic Manhattan or Tipperary cocktail should do the trick” he adds. Depending on your taste for sweetness you may want to eliminate the simple syrup altogether.This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with This? Green Chartreuse: What It Is and How to Use It.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir for 20 seconds. Using a julep strainer strain into a cocktail glass. Express the oil from an orange peel over the drink then discard peel.
Ingredients: Buffalo Trace bourbon;Carpano Antica Formula sweet vermouth;Green Chartreuse;Simple syrup;Regan’s Orange Bitters No. 6;Angostura bitters;Orange peel oil

Name: Brother Hal
About: “Chartreuse is not classically used in rum cocktails; however the herbaceous character can play well with sugar-cane-based distillates” says Scott Woodworth the lead bartender at 12@Madison in Denver. His drink with white rum mezcal falernum and fresh citrus “provides the perfect balance of sweet savory and citrus” he says. It can also show that Green Chartreuse is not a one-trick pony of medicinal licorice flavors.This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with This? Green Chartreuse: What It Is and How to Use It.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a Tiki glass over fresh crushed ice. Serve with a straw.
Ingredients: Matusalem platino rum;Banhez mezcal;Green Chartreuse;John D. Taylor’s Velvet falernum;Fresh lime juice;Fresh orange juice

Name: Bonpland
About: This Sazerac variation from Jules Elkovich a sommelier at Michael Jordan’s Steak House at Mohegan Sun Casino & Resort in Uncasville Conn. is an homage to Aimé Bonpland the French botanist who explored Mexico between 1799 and 1805 with Alexander von Humboldt and who created the country’s first maps. “Reposado tequila has the perfect marriage of spice baking spice green grass and fresh herbaceous notes that play so well with Green Chartreuse” she says. “And the name seemed an appropriate hat tip to the marriage of Mexican and French influences.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with This? Green Chartreuse: What It Is and How to Use It.”
HowToMake: Rinse a coupe glass with the Green Chartreuse and set aside. Add the tequila bitters lime juice and sugar cube into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into the prepared glass. Garnish with a lime twist.
Ingredients: Green Chartreuse;Clase Azul reposado tequila;Bittermens Xocolatl Mole bitters;Fresh lime juice;Sugar cube

Name: Chrysanthemum
About: Don’t go looking for gin or whiskey in this century-old classic. Vermouth lands the starring role in a drink that’s light and herbal with a touch of absinthe to sharpen the edges.
HowToMake: Pour ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until cold. Strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist.
Ingredients: Dry vermouth;Bénédictine;Absinthe

Name: Blackberry Punch
About: This classic cocktail is more than a provocative name. It’s a refreshing mix of tropical juices peach schnapps and vodka. And the best version is made with Absolut.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice. Garnish with a lime wheel and cherry.
Ingredients: Absolut vodka;Light orange juice;Cranberry juice;Peach schnapps

Name: Lime Mule
About: The Moscow Mule is a delicious mix of vodka lime juice and ginger beer. Make it even more flavorful and refreshing by using Absolut Lime.
HowToMake: Fill a Moscow Mule mug with ice cubes. Add vodka and lime juice. Top up with ginger beer and garnish with lime wedges.
Ingredients: Absolut Lime vodka;Lime juice;Ginger beer to top

Name: Bay Breeze
About: This delightful summer cocktail balances tartness from cranberry juice and sweetness from the pineapple juice. These complementary flavors are elevated by extra-smooth Absolut.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice. Garnish with a pineapple and lime wedge.
Ingredients: Absolut vodka;Cranberry juice;Pineapple juice

Name: Hanna Wallbanger
About: What makes the Hanna Wallbanger different from her more famous brother Harvey? This cocktail uses passion fruit juice instead of orange. It might be a bit more obscure but it complements Absolut vodka and Galliano just as well.
HowToMake: Fill a highball glass with ice and add Absolut vodka and top with passion fruit juice. Float the Galliano and garnish with a grapefruit slice.
Ingredients: Absolut vodka;Galliano liqueur;Passion fruit juice to top

Name: Absolut Lime Soda
About: You don’t need a complicated recipe to turn Absolut Lime into a refreshing cocktail. Just mix it with some lime juice and soda water and you’re all set.
HowToMake: Add vodka and lime juice to a rocks glass filled with ice. Top with soda water and garnish with lime wheels.
Ingredients: Absolut Lime vodka;Lime juice;Soda water

Name: Absolut Mudslide
About: Looking for a dessert you can drink? You’re not going to find many recipes more indulgent than this mouthwatering mix of Absolut vodka and cream and coffee liqueur.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice cubes.
Ingredients: Absolut vodka;Cream liqueur;Kahlúa coffee liqueur

Name: Absolut French Martini
About: There are countless types of flavored Martinis. But you’ll have a hard time finding one to match the subtle and delicious Absolut French Martini with its use of pineapple juice and raspberry liqueur.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a cocktail glass and garnish with a pineapple leaf.
Ingredients: Absolut vodka;Pineapple juice;Raspberry liqueur

Name: Absolut Citron Gimlet
About: A traditional Gimlet is made with gin simple syrup and lime juice. But here’s a secret: Simple syrup and lime juice go better with Absolut Citron. Make this at home and you’ll see why.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with a lime twist.
Ingredients: Absolut Citron;Simple syrup;Lime juice

Name: Absolut Vodka Gimlet
About: Don’t like gin? That shouldn’t keep you from enjoying a recipe as good as the Gimlet. Discover how you can make the classic cocktail with a vodka base.
HowToMake: Fill a rocks glass with ice cubes and add all the ingredients. Garnish with a lime wedge.
Ingredients: Absolut vodka;Lime cordial

Name: Espresso Old Fashioned
About: Serious whiskey drinkers know that a complex and flavorful Old Fashioned starts with rye. What’s more surprising is how well the light floral and citrus notes of Redemption Rye are complemented by a bitter espresso flavor. Experience it for yourself with the Espresso Old Fashioned.
HowToMake: Rinse an Old Fashioned glass with the absinthe and set aside. Add remaining ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into the prepared glass over ice. Express the oil from a lemon twist and drop in as a garnish.
Ingredients: Redemption rye whiskey;Espresso or cold-brew coffee;Simple syrup;Peychaud's bitters;Absinthe to rinse

Name: Grapefruit Drop
About: Lemon juice triple sec and simple syrup are greater—and more refreshing—than the sum of their parts. Shake it up with Absolut Grapefruit and you’ll have the ideal cocktail for summer or any other time you want to cool down.
HowToMake: Rim a coupe glass with sugar (optional). Pour all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a coupe. Garnish with grapefruit peel.
Ingredients: Absolut Grapefruit vodka;Lemon juice;Triple sec;Simple syrup

Name: The Swedish Paloma
About: Replace tequila with vodka to take the Paloma cocktail to new heights. Better yet use Absolut Grapefruit to double down on the citrus flavor.
HowToMake: Fill a shaker with ice vodka grapefruit juice and lime juice. Shake and strain into a highball glass with fresh ice.  Top with soda water and garnish with a grapefruit wedge.
Ingredients: Absolut Grapefruit vodka;Red grapefruit juice;Lime juice;Soda water to top

Name: Herb Ginger Julep
About: Bourbon is typically used as the base of Julep cocktails but the baking-spice backbone of rye is uniquely suited to stand up to the inherent sweetness of the drink. This recipe also uses a basil-ginger-mint syrup to highlight the herbaceous notes and mint finish of Redemption rye whiskey. It will be hard to go back to the traditional Julep after trying this.
HowToMake: Rub 7 mint leaves firmly along the interior of a Julep mug. Add ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain over crushed ice into the mug. Garnish with a mint leaf and basil leaf. *Basil-ginger-mint syrup: Blanche 1 oz fresh mint and 1 oz fresh basil and add to blender with 2 oz fresh grated ginger and 2 cups simple syrup. Blend and strain out solids.
Ingredients: Redemption rye whiskey;Basil-ginger-mint syrup;Angostura bitters;Mint

Name: Absolut White Cosmopolitan
About: Lemon juice triple sec and simple syrup are greater—and more refreshing—than the sum of their parts. Shake it up with Absolut Grapefruit and you’ll have the ideal cocktail for summer or any other time you want to cool down.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice. Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with an orange twist.
Ingredients: Absolut Citron vodka;Triple sec;Lime juice;White cranberry juice

Name: Absolut Vodka Martini
About: There’s no need to radically reinvent the vodka Martini. Just use extra-smooth vodka and you’ll have a refreshing take on the elegant classic.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice. Stir and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a lemon twist and olive.
Ingredients: Absolut vodka;Dry vermouth

Name: Half Moon Bay
About: Fever-Tree’s Half Moon Bay is the rare drink in which the mixer is made with the same care if not more than the base spirit. Don’t use anything other than Fever-Tree Spiced Orange ginger ale made with cold-pressed South African clementines and steam-distilled cinnamon from Sri Lanka. Simply combine it with Lillet blanc for a delightfully refreshing apéritif.
HowToMake: Pour the liqueur into a highball glass and add ice. Top with the ginger ale. Garnish with an orange wedge.
Ingredients: Lillet blanc liqueur;Fever-Tree Spiced Orange ginger ale

Name: Blackberry Punch
About: This is the kind of punch you’ll want to keep sipping long after summer is over. It has citrus sweetness and a little fizz from the champagne.
HowToMake: Add vodka Chambord lemon juice and simple syrup to a shaker with ice. Shake and strain into a highball glass filled with crushed ice. Top with champagne. Garnish with a few blackberries.
Ingredients: Absolut vodka;Chambord liqueur;Lemon juice;Simple syrup;Champagne to Top

Name: Absolut Peppar Bloody Mary
About: Here it is: The template for the perfectly balanced Bloody Mary. Not only doesn’t it have the right ratio of heat citrus and spices. It gets extra flavor from the vodka by using Absolut Peppar.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice. Garnish with a celery stick and lemon wedge.
Ingredients: Absolut Peppar vodka;Tomato juice;Hot sauce;Worcestershire sauce;Lemon juice;Lime juice;Ground black pepper;Salt

Name: Absolut Mimosa
About: There’s a reason why the mimosa has become a brunch favorite: Champagne and orange juice is a delicious combination. But the drink is even better when you mix in a little Absolut vodka.
HowToMake: Pour Absolut vodka and orange juice into a champagne flute. Top with champagne.
Ingredients: Absolut vodka;Orange juice;Champagne to Top

Name: Grapefruit Mule
About: The Moscow Mule is already a beloved and refreshing cocktail. But you can bring it to a whole new level with one subtle tweak: Replace your usual vodka with Absolut Grapefruit.
HowToMake: Add Absolut Grapefruit and lime juice to a mule mug filled with ice. Top with a splash of ginger beer. Garnish with a grapefruit wedge.
Ingredients: Absolut Grapefruit;Lime juice;Splash of Ginger beer

Name: Shamrock Shot
About: There are two rules to fixing a St. Patrick’s Day drink: It should be green and shootable. This festive minty chocolate shot checks both boxes. Does it have anything to do with the patron saint of Ireland? Nope. Is it the perfect boozy sugar rush to keep you fueled between pints of Guinness? If you’re lucky.
HowToMake: Serves 2. Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a shot glass. Top with whipped cream. Garnish with an Andes crème de menthe thin.
Ingredients: Vanilla vodka;Crème de menthe;Chocolate bitters;Heavy cream

Name: Local Old Fashioned
About: Japan has incredible skiing but après-ski culture is just making its way to the Land of the Rising Sun. “Ski holidays were made super popular during the Japanese boom (the late ’80s and ’90s) by the film ‘Watashi Wo Ski Ni Tsuretete’ (loosely translated to ‘Take Me Skiing’)” says Hisashi Watanabe the founder and bartender of Bar Gyu+ aka The Fridge. Bar Gyu+ is one of the oldest bars in town its entrance an unassuming fridge door almost buried under snow. The Local Old Fashioned consists of a blend of Nikka whiskies including locally distilled Yoichi as well as citrus sourced from southern Japan. “It’s a bit strong at first” he says. “But you can sit with it and let the ice melt while you talk over your day on the slopes.” This recipe originally appeared as part of “Bartenders Recommend the Best Après-Ski Drinks in the World.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass muddle to break down the sugar and stir briefly. Fill with ice and stir again. Strain into an Old Fashioned glass over fresh ice. Garnish with an orange peel. *Nikka Japanese whisky blend: Combine equal parts Nikka Taketsuru Nikka Black Deep Blend and Nikka Black Rich Blend Japanese whisky.
Ingredients: Nikka Japanese whisky blend;White sugar;Angostura bitters

Name: Rumplesnuggler
About: Nothing can compare to a warm boozy cocktail to reheat your frozen bones après-ski. The Rumplesnuggler is made with hot chocolate Baileys and Rumple Minze peppermint schnapps plus whipped cream on top if you want it. “It tastes like winter in your mouth” says Grace Rainwater a bartender at Caliente in Lake Tahoe’s Kings Beach in Calif. “And it definitely screams Lake Tahoe. Rumple Minze is one of the top sellers in the area as is Baileys for coffee in the morning.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “Bartenders Recommend the Best Après-Ski Drinks in the World.”
HowToMake: Pour all ingredients into a warmed Irish Coffee mug. Top with whipped cream.
Ingredients: Baileys Irish cream liqueur;Rumple Minze peppermint schnapps;Hot chocolate

Name: Porter's Old Fashioned
About: Xania Woodman a bartender at O.P. Rockwell in Park City Utah says this is the cocktail to sate your après-ski thirst. “It’s strong sweet and simple—perfect for post-exertion and easing into the evening” she says. “Alpine Traveler’s Rest American single-malt whiskey is 90-proof which is perfect for standing up to the smoky aromatic bitters and malty beer syrup. Combined with good ice—hopefully the only ice one has seen all day—this Old Fashioned riff hits all the right notes.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “Bartenders Recommend the Best Après-Ski Drinks in the World.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into an Old Fashioned glass over 3 or 4 ice cubes. Express the oil from an orange peel and drop in to garnish. *Polygamy porter syrup: Pour 1 can of Wasatch Polygamy nitro porter into a saucepan and gently warm (do not allow to boil). Add an equal or slightly greater amount of cane sugar and stir to dissolve completely. Let cool.
Ingredients: Wasatch Polygamy porter syrup;Bitters Lab Charred Cedar & Currant bitters;Angostura bitters

Name: Flinn’s Après Steazy
About: “The days of après everywhere are over compared to 20 to 30 years ago” says Jimmy Yeager the owner of Jimmy’s. He says that high-speed lifts and other technologies have shortened the ski day causing skiers to wrap up on the mountain earlier. Yeager’s favorite après cocktail is the Flinn’s Après Steazy (created by Flinn Pomeroy). “I chose it because it’s delicious and balanced. The amaro is fortified by the rye whiskey and balanced by the bitter and sweet of the Campari and St-Germain.” The drink evokes the surrounding area perfectly. “Like Aspen this cocktail is highly cultured and at the same time very approachable.” This recipe originally appeared as part of “Bartenders Recommend the Best Après-Ski Drinks in the World.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube. Express the oil from a lemon peel and drop in to garnish.
Ingredients: Lucano amaro;Woody Creek rye whiskey;Campari;St-Germain;Fresh lemon juice

Name: Cache Stash
About: “This cocktail was originally designed for our annual Blueberry Festival in August” says Heather Ruhle the beverage manager at Alyeska Resort in Girdwood Alaska. “The Valley of Girdwood explodes with amazing blueberries every year so we wanted to celebrate that and incorporate it in a cocktail. The drink comes out a beautiful deep purple. It was so popular we decided to keep it year round at Bore Tide Bar at the top of the mountain.” Plus blueberries are an antioxidant superfood so technically it’s healthy. This recipe originally appeared as part of “Bartenders Recommend the Best Après-Ski Drinks in the World.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a highball filled with ice. Top with the soda water. Garnish with a lemon wedge.
Ingredients: Bulleit rye whiskey;Blueberry purée;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup;Lemonade;Soda water to top

Name: Yard Sale
About: In ski jargon a “yard sale” is when you wipe out on the mountain and your stuff (poles skis goggles) goes everywhere. “What I want after skiing all day is something that goes straight to the face” says Stephen Gill the bar manager at Horn & Cantle Saloon at Lone Mountain Ranch in Big Sky Mont. “The whole premise of the drink is that it’ll give you the confidence to get back up after you yard-sale.” To make his high-octane concoction more Montana Gill barrel-ages the finished cocktail for about three weeks. It’s served at the resort saloon but he says “it’s like a secret-menu kind of deal.” This recipe originally appeared as part of “Bartenders Recommend the Best Après-Ski Drinks in the World.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube. Garnish with a skewered lemon twist and Luxardo maraschino cherry. Optional: Barrel-age the entire completed cocktail for 3 weeks.
Ingredients: Bourbon;Rye whiskey;Calvados;Carpano Antica Formula vermouth;Angostura bitters;Simple syrup
BaseSpirit: Bourbon / American Whiskey;Calvados;Liqueurs;Rye Whiskey;Vermouth / Aperitif Wine;Whiskey

Name: Toblerone
About: Advice for anyone looking to mix a dynamite dessert cocktail: Start with a dynamite dessert and work backward. This rich after-dinner drink is inspired by the iconic Swiss chocolate Toblerone and is just as nutty creamy and decadent.
HowToMake: Place chocolate syrup in a small shallow bowl or rimmed plate. Dip the rim of the cocktail glass in the chocolate and chill to set. Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into the prepared glass. Garnish with Toblerone chocolate bar shavings.
Ingredients: Kahlúa;Frangelico;Baileys Irish cream;Honey syrup;Heavy cream

Name: Apple Chai G&T
About: Using a smooth American dry gin such as Bluecoat works well with this delicate Gin & Tonic by Canyon Shayer of Philadelphia Distilling. The apple chai syrup proves not too sweet with nuances light enough that you don’t want a strong spirit to overpower them. It’s warm refreshing and boozy all at once and almost too easy to drink. If you want more of a chai punch try steeping the tea in the cider overnight or doubling up on the amount. Serve at happy hour or as a fun brunch cocktail.This recipe originally appeared as part of “6 Gin Drinks Perfect for Sipping by the Fireplace.”
HowToMake: Fill a Collins glass with ice and add the gin and syrup. Top with the tonic. Garnish with a star anise. *Apple chai syrup: Simmer 1 cup apple cider with 2 tbsp loose chai for 3 minutes. Strain out tea. Mix in 1 cup demerara sugar until dissolved.
Ingredients: Bluecoat American dry gin;Apple chai syrup;Tonic to top

Name: Curiosity Killed the Cat You Know
About: “This cocktail celebrates the roads less traveled and the curious flavors you find through the high mountains of Germany France and Italy” says McLain Hedges of Morin and RiNo Yacht Club in Denver. “The Macvin du Jura [liqueur wine] is floral and honeyed with light tannin that helps to carry the cocktail. The génépy is herbal and sweet lifting and adding depth at the same time. The gin is powerful yet balanced and has layers upon layers of aromatics and textures.” It’s like a classic Hot Toddy but smooth sophisticated and perfectly balanced. This recipe originally appeared as part of “6 Gin Drinks Perfect for Sipping by the Fireplace.”
HowToMake: Fill a coffee mug with hot water and set aside. Add all ingredients except the tea into a mixing glass. When the mug is warm to the touch discard the hot water and pour the mixture from the mixing glass into the mug. Top with the tea. Garnish with a lemon twist.
Ingredients: Monkey 47 gin;Alpe génépy;Macvin du Jura liqueur wine;Honey syrup;Fresh lemon juice;Chamomile tea heated

Name: French Harvest
About: To adapt this classic French 75 for the colder months give it a cider kick. The floral Nolet’s silver dry gin works so well with this slightly funky and refined cidre from France it’s enough to make you forget the traditional Champagne version. You can swap out the cider and gin with other brands—just make sure the former is dry.This recipe originally appeared as part of “6 Gin Drinks Perfect for Sipping by the Fireplace.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the cider into a shaker with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into a Champagne flute. Top with the cider. Garnish with a lemon peel.
Ingredients: Nolet’s silver dry gin;Simple syrup;Fresh lemon juice;Le Brun organic cidre (or dry sparkling cider) to top

Name: Golden Purl
About: A purl is an old-school English drink classically involving hot ale with or without warming spices and a nice dollop of gin. In this recipe the ale is replaced with warm sparkling cider. Sound weird? On the contrary the fizz adds a refreshing essence and works well with the booze. The maple adds a hefty buttery quality to the mix. You may sip this drink and think it’s laden with citrus but save for the bitters and garnish there’s none. If you want something with a little less oomph opt for nonalcoholic cider. This recipe originally appeared as part of “6 Gin Drinks Perfect for Sipping by the Fireplace.”
HowToMake: Heat up the cider until hot and stir in the maple syrup until dissolved. Pour into a glass mug and add the gin. Stir again and top with the bitters. Garnish with an orange peel.
Ingredients: Cider;Runamok bourbon-barrel-aged maple syrup;Leopold’s American small-batch gin;Orange bitters

Name: Coffee & Cigarettes
About: It’s time to stop thinking about the Gin & Tonic as a basic two-ingredient recipe. Case in point is this coffee-laced cocktail by Alan Berger of Denver’s Ultreia which marries the bitterness of java with the sweet tang of tonic. Berger uses a Colorado gin with its notes of cardamom and cinnamon as well as coffee liqueur. The result is smoky sweet warm and herbal all at once—perfect for the cold weather.This recipe originally appeared as part of “6 Gin Drinks Perfect for Sipping by the Fireplace.”
HowToMake: Add the gin and coffee liqueur into a wine glass over ice. Top with the tonic water. Garnish with 4 coffee beans and 1/4 tsp cocoa nibs.
Ingredients: The Block Autumn gin;The Block coffee liqueur;Q tonic water

Name: Forest Sprite
About: This whimsical pine-laced gin cocktail tastes like someone folded up the forest floor and put it in a glass. Using a floral juniper-forward gin works well with heavy pine syrup which you can make yourself by harvesting new fronds from that tree outside. Drink this after tromping through the woods by the fire or whenever you want a winter drink that’s also refreshing. This recipe originally appeared as part of “6 Gin Drinks Perfect for Sipping by the Fireplace.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the seltzer into a mixing glass with ice and stir well. Strain into a Collins glass over ice. Top with the seltzer and bitters. Garnish with a lemon twist and pine sprig. *Pine syrup: In a medium pot add 1/4 cup roughly chopped conifer tips to 1 cup boiling water and 1 cup granulated sugar. Stir until sugar dissolves remove heat and let cool for 30 minutes. Strain into a sealable container and refrigerate. Good for up to 2 weeks.
Ingredients: Citadelle gin;Fresh lemon juice;Pine syrup;Seltzer to top;Cocktailpunk Alpino cocktail bitters

Name: Painkiller
About: If you’re going to name your cocktail the Painkiller it better pack a punch. Hailing from the British Virgin Islands where it was invented sometime in the early 1970s this twist on the Piña Colada does precisely that. Jammed full of fruity tropical flavors the Painkiller was later claimed by Pusser’s Rum whose trademarked recipe tilts heavy on the pineapple juice. This version dials back the P.J. and ups the rum a half ounce for a more boozy balanced drink.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a large snifter filled with pebble ice. Garnish with grated nutmeg and a skewered pineapple leaf and preserved cherry.
Ingredients: Dark or navy-strength rum;Pineapple juice;Orange juice;Cream of coconut

Name: Bitter Hearts Know Better
About: Cupid might know the way to your heart but he’s got crummy taste in adult beverages. Valentine’s Day drinks tend to be sweet and sticky more candy than cocktail. Not so with this simple pinkish spin on a Gimlet made with hibiscus gin and California amaro to give it a light herbal bitterness. Finally a Valentine’s Day cocktail worth loving!
HowToMake: Coat the rim of a coupe in sugar and set aside. Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into the prepared coupe. *Hibiscus-infused gin: In a large container combine 1 750 mL bottle of gin with 1/4 cup dried hibiscus flowers and let sit for 8 hours. Strain back into bottle.
Ingredients: Hibiscus-infused gin;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup;Lo-Fi gentian amaro

Name: Pisco Sour
About: English Bar at Country Club Lima hotel in Peru boasts one of the country’s most sought-after Pisco Sours. The recipe features a hefty four-ounce pour of pisco as bar manager Luiggy Arteaga finds that this offers the perfect balance between the other ingredients.This recipe originally appeared as part of “How to Drink a Pisco Sour in Its Arguable Homeland of Peru.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake vigorously for 10 seconds. Strain into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a drop of Angostura bitters.
Ingredients: Pisco quebranta;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup;Egg white

Name: Cobbler
About: For this Cobbler variant from Azrhiel Frost the bar manager at The Gage in Chicago the sweetness of Chambord is offset by light and dry fino sherry and a touch of lemon juice. For more citrus flavor she suggests adding an orange slice. This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with Chambord? These 3 Ideas Will Help.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a highball glass over crushed ice. Garnish with a mint sprig.
Ingredients: Fino sherry;Chambord;Fresh lemon juice

Name: Pisco Bramble
About: “Chambord is great to float on top of cocktails and can layer nicely” says Kevin King the bar manager at Husk in Savannah Ga. “I love to us it in Brambles with gin or pisco.” This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with Chambord? These 3 Ideas Will Help.”
HowToMake: Add the pisco lime juice and simple syrup into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over crushed ice. Using a bar spoon gently float the Chambord over the cocktail. Garnish with a mint sprig and 2 skewered Chambord-soaked raspberries.
Ingredients: Pisco;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup;Chambord

Name: She's No Gentleman
About: “The vanilla notes of Chambord pair well with smoky flavors like scotch or mezcal and funky flavors like rum or pisco” says Julia Ebell the creative director at The Gibson in Washington D.C. “The honey loves bourbon and high-tannin teas.” This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@! Do I Do with Chambord? These 3 Ideas Will Help.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Double-strain into a chilled coupe. Express the oil from a lemon peel on top then discard peel. *Earl Grey syrup: Brew 1 Earl Grey tea bag in 1 cup almost-boiling water according to package directions. Add 1 cup sugar while tea is still hot and stir to combine. Store tightly covered in the refrigerator for up to 1 month. Discard if it becomes cloudy.
Ingredients: Black Bottle blended scotch;Chambord;Earl Grey syrup;Cream

Name: Hot Blooded
About: Hot sauce and whiskey might sound like strange cocktail bedfellows but here they blend nicely with blood orange juice and and chile liqueur for a warming drink of a different stripe.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a coupe. Garnish with skewered heart-shaped blood orange and lime peels.
Ingredients: Rye whiskey;Ancho Reyes ancho chile liqueur;Fresh lime juice;Blood orange juice;Simple syrup;Hot sauce

Name: Suffering Bastard
About: So many classic cocktails are born in the bars of great hotels. Originally conceived as a hangover cure by the bar staff at Cairo’s Shepherd’s Hotel (before it burned to the ground in 1952) this bourbon- and gin-based drink has been around for 70 years. To adjust the potency—or get a jump on tomorrow’s hangover—simply increase or decrease the amount of ginger ale.
HowToMake: Add the bourbon gin lime juice and bitters into a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled (about 30 seconds). Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice. Top with the ginger ale. Garnish with a mint sprig.
Ingredients: Bourbon;London dry gin;Fresh lime juice;Angostura bitters;Ginger ale to top

Name: CBD Spritz
About: The latest hemp product to capture the imagination of chefs and bartenders CBD soda provides all of marijuana’s therapeutic benefits minus the stony side effects. Here it’s used to add mellow citrus notes to a classic French Spritz.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a double rocks glass over ice and stir. Garnish with a grapefruit slice.
Ingredients: Vodka;Aperol;Sparkling wine;Sprig CBD-infused zero-sugar sparkling citrus soda

Name: Picon Punch
About: This 19th-century sipper hails from Marseilles France by way of Bakersfield Calif. where it was mixed regularly for the local Basque population. The main ingredient a bitter French digestif called Amer Picon is no longer commercially available in the U.S. But that didn’t stop the bar team at San Francisco’s 15 Romolo whose recipe substitutes a trio of Italian amari to fill in the drink’s intense herbal character. This recipe originally appeared as part of “Picon Punch Is the Winter Drink You Never Knew You Needed.”
HowToMake: Pour the Amer Picon and grenadine into a Georgian Irish Coffee glass over ice and stir briefly. Fill almost to top with the soda water. Float the brandy on top. Garnish with a lemon peel. *Amer Picon: Because it’s not available in the U.S. as a substitute combine 2 parts Ramazzotti amaro 2 parts dry curaçao and 1 part gentian liqueur in an airtight bottle and shake. Refrigerate until ready to use.
Ingredients: Amer Picon;Grenadine;Soda water to top;Brandy

Name: Celery Sour
About: South African–inspired beef jerky bar Biltong in Atlanta uses fresh celery juice and toasted celery seeds to get max vegetal flavor for its Celery Sour. The celery mix is shaken with pineapple-infused gin cucumber bitters and Greek yogurt which does the emulsive work of egg whites but adds a tangier kick. “It takes a bit of convincing because people are thrown off when they see all those ingredients in the same sentence” says bar manager James Cramer. “But they come together in a way that’s bigger than the sum of its parts.”This recipe originally appeared as part of “The World’s Most Underrated Vegetable Tastes Great in Cocktails.”
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a coupe. Garnish with a pineapple leaf. *Pineapple-infused gin: Remove the ends and skin of a small pineapple and cut the rest into 1-inch-thick wheels. Combine the pineapple with 1 L London dry gin in a vacuum bag and seal. Cook sous vide for 2 hours at 155 degrees Fahrenheit then ice-bath until cold and fine-strain through a coffee filter. **Celery syrup: Add 3/4 cup sugar 3/4 cup water and 2 coarsely chopped celery stalks to a small saucepan and bring to a simmer for 5 minutes over medium heat. Let cool then strain into a sealable jar. Keep refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.
Ingredients: Pineapple-infused gin;Licor 43;Celery syrup;Fresh lemon juice;Greek yogurt;Cucumber bitters

Name: Lounge Chair Afternoon
About: “Pink port has lovely hints of fresh berries and a light natural sweetness and makes for very sessionable cocktails” says Lulu Martinez director of events for Liquid Productions in Aston Pa. Straddling somewhere between a white and a ruby this style works with everything from gin and vodka to tequila and rum. “Port’s lower alcohol levels with vibrant flavors add a fantastic component for playing off other spirits.” This recipe originally appeared as part of “What the #$@!
