Cook in a water bath set at 158 degrees F for 2 hours. Strain the liquid several times through a chinois and coffee filter until clear and stir in remaining agave syrup to taste. Cut with water (roughly 1 part tonic syrup water to 4 parts water) and carbonate in an iSi siphon.
Ingredients: Gin;Sous vide tonic water

Name: Vida Paloma
About: At new Chicago restaurant Fat Baby Tacos
HowToMake: Rim half of a rocks glass with chile piquin. Add the mezcal juices and syrup to a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into the prepared glass over fresh ice. Top up with the club soda. Garnish with a grapefruit quarter wheel cilantro sprig and jalapeño round.
Ingredients: Del Maguey Vida mezcal;Fresh grapefruit juice;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup;Club soda
Garnish: Chile piquin rim;Grapefruit quarter wheel;Cilantro sprig;Jalapeño round

Name: Palomita
About: Paloma means “dove” in Spanish which means this drink’s name translates to “little dove.” This Paloma
HowToMake: Rim a Collins glass with vanilla-flecked salt. Add the vodka and lime juice to a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into the prepared glass over fresh ice. Top with the soda. Garnish with a lemon peel.
Ingredients: Vodka;Fresh lime juice

Name: Mourning Doves
About: This Paloma at Nashville’s Pinewood Social
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a rocks glass over a large chunk of ice. Garnish with a lemon wheel.
Ingredients: El Jimador reposado tequila;Maple syrup;Fresh grapefruit juice;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup

Name: Freek's Mill Paloma
About: This tasty Paloma
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients except the cava to a Collins glass with ice and stir. Top with the cava. Garnish with a mint sprig and grapefruit peel.
Ingredients: Tequila;Pamplemousse liqueur;Fresh lime juice;Contratto bitter;Drops of Saline;Cava or other sparkling wine to top

Name: Vice Royalty
About: Beverage director Taha Ismail wanted to do a seasonal riff on a Pisco Sour
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients except the rosé to a shaker and dry-shake (no ice). Add ice and shake until chilled. Add the sparkling rosé to a Collins glass and strain the cocktail on top. Top with fresh ice and garnish with a mint sprig. *Mandarin cordial: In a blender combine 3 cups mandarin juice 2 ½ cups granulated sugar 1 ¼ oz Everclear 1 oz yuzu juice and ¼ tsp xanthan gum and blend until smooth.
Ingredients: Strega;Mandarin cordial;Fresh lime juice;Egg white;Peychaud’s bitters;Pere Ventura rosé

Name: Rosso Bellini
About: This cocktail at Las Vegas’ Lago by Julian Serrano
HowToMake: Muddle the raspberries in the bottom of a cocktail shaker. Add the vodka liqueur lemon juice raspberry syrup egg white and ice and shake until chilled. Double-strain into a white wine glass and top with the chilled prosecco. Garnish with a caramel nest and golden raspberry.
Ingredients: Fresh lemon juice;Raspberry syrup;Raspberries;Egg white

Name: Favola Bella
About: When SoBou’s executive chef Juan Carlos Gonzalez was ordering cases of perfectly in-season satsuma a Chinese seedless and easy-peeling orange bar chef Laura Bellucci felt she had to do a cocktail using the sweet fruit. “I really like working with Amaro Montenegro
HowToMake: Add the amaro juice and syrup to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a chilled flute and top with the chilled sparkling wine. Garnish with a satsuma slice or lemon peel. *Ginger syrup: Purée 2 cups peeled sliced ginger and 2 cups boiling water on high in a Vitamix. Add 4 cups light brown sugar and stir to combine. Let macerate for a day strain out solids and store syrup in the refrigerator.
Ingredients: Amaro Montenegro;Satsuma juice;Ginger syrup;Chilled Simonet sparkling rosé to top;Slice of satsuma or lemon peel for garnish

Name: Bit of Tongue
About: “I enjoy using grapefruit in a shrub because it allows the brightness and flavor of the grapefruit to come through and cuts down on the typical tartness of the grapefruit” says Nic Christiansen the beverage director at Lola. “Allowing the acid from the apple cider vinegar and the sugar to lift the grapefruit flavor [creates] a more complex grapefruit flavor.” Locally produced Copper & Kings Absinthe Superior
HowToMake: Add the aperol shrub and absinthe into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a chilled flute and top with the chilled cava. Garnish with an orange twist. *Grapefruit shrub: Combine 2 cups sugar 2 ½ cups grapefruit juice 1 cup apple cider a pinch of salt and the zest of the juiced grapefruits in a saucepan. Simmer ingredients over medium heat stirring for about 20 minutes. Remove from the heat strain out solids let cool and store in the refrigerator.
Ingredients: Aperol;Grapefruit shrub;Copper & Kings Absinthe Superior;Cava to top

Name: Mirabelle 75
About: Shake and strain.
HowToMake: Add the brandy vodka juice and syrup to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a chilled flute and top with the chilled sparkling wine. Garnish with a lemon peel.
Ingredients: Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup (1:1)

Name: Land of Happy
About: “Sweet herbaceous and acidic all at once this is a great pre-dinner cocktail before a nice glass of white wine” says 312 Chicago
HowToMake: Rub the lemon wedge on half of the outside of a coupe glass coat with the basil salt mixture and set aside. Add the gin and syrup to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Double-strain into the prepared coupe glass. Float the chilled prosecco on top. *Honeydew-basil-white-balsamic shrub: Cut off the rind and remove the seeds from 1 whole honeydew then cut the melon into chunks. Combine it in the blender with 1 cup fresh basil and blend until smooth. Pour the mixture into a saucepan add 4 cups white sugar and 4 cups cold water and simmer until the sugar has dissolved being careful not to overheat. Remove it from the heat and let it cool then strain through a chinois cloth. Add 1 ½ cups white balsamic vinegar and keep the shrub in the refrigerator for up to two weeks.
Ingredients: Honeydew-basil-white balsamic shrub;Prosecco to float;Lemon wedge to rim glass;Basil salt (chopped fresh basil combined with coarse salt) to rim glass

Name: Mrs. Robinson
About: For this cocktail at Portland Ore.’s Bacchus Bar
HowToMake: Add the gin syrup juices and bitters into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a chilled flute. Top with the chilled prosecco. *Pineapple syrup: Peel and core 1 whole pineapple then cut the meat into chunks. Add 1 cup white sugar toss to coat in a glass bowl and store covered in the refrigerator overnight. Combine 1 cup sugar and 1 cup water in a saucepan simmer until the sugar is dissolved and remove from the heat. Blend the macerated pineapple in a blender add the simple syrup and stir to combine. Strain out solids using a cheesecloth and store the syrup in the refrigerator.
Ingredients: Aviation American gin;Pineapple syrup;Fresh grapefruit juice;Fresh lime juice;Peychaud’s bitters;Dry prosecco

Name: Veronica Rose
About: This red-tinged cocktail by Erick Castro at San Diego’s Polite Provisions
HowToMake: Add the Aperol and syrup to a cocktail shaker with iice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a chilled flute glass top with the sparkling wine and stir gently. Garnish with a lemon twist. *Rose petal syrup: Add 4 cups hot water to 1 cup rose petals and steep 30 minutes. Squeeze out excess water from the rose petals then strain out solids. Add 1 tsp rose water top off with additional water to make 4 cups and add equal parts white sugar.
Ingredients: Aperol;Rose petal syrup;Chilled sparkling wine to top

Name: The Verbena
About: At The Chandelier bar at The Cosmopolitan hotel in Las Vegas chief mixologist Mariena Mercer has been experimenting with Szechuan buttons for years and this cocktail is one of the bar’s most popular signature drinks.
HowToMake: Combine the lemon verbena leaves and ginger syrup in a cocktail shaker and muddle. Add the remaining ingredients and ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a double rocks glass filled with fresh ice. Garnish with a Szechuan button. *Yuzu-calamansi sour mix: Combine 1 cup water and 1 cup sugar in a saucepan. Heat slowly stirring until sugar dissolves. Remove from heat and let cool. Combine with 1 cup freshly squeezed yuzu juice and 1 cup freshly squeezed calamansi juice. **Ginger syrup: Combine 1 cup water 1 cup sugar and ¼ pound ginger peeled and thinly sliced in a saucepan. Heat slowly stirring until sugar dissolves. Simmer for 30 minutes. Remove from heat let cool and strain out solids.
Ingredients: Herradura blanco tequila;Yuzu-calamansi sour mix;Ginger syrup;Lemon verbena leaves

About: Different single malts mingle in this spirit-forward cocktail. It’s a wonder that the peaty flavor still shines through all the other tasty elements.
HowToMake: Add the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake. Pour into a coupe glass. Express an orange peel over top. Garnish with the orange peel.
Ingredients: Aberlour 12-year-old scotch;El Dorado 8-year-old rum;Pedro Ximénez sherry;Don Ciccio walnut liqueur;Cherry cola syrup

Name: Speyside Smash
About: This cocktail takes single malt for a slightly tropical spin. And yes it’s as delicious as it looks.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake. Double-strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a skewered mint leaf.
Ingredients: Aberlour 12-year-old scotch;Pineapple rum;House sugar;Fresh lime juice;Mint leaves

Name: Traveling Riverside
About: This cocktail manages the impressive feat of using award-winning single malt in a light and refreshing cocktail. Make one for yourself to discover how cooling scotch can be.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a mixing tin and stir. Pour into a Highball glass over ice. Garnish with a mint leaf and lemon slice.
Ingredients: Aberlour 12-year-old scotch;Fresh lemon juice;Rhododendron honey

Name: No Country for Orange Men
About: This complex and spirit-forward cocktail is a showcase for award-winning single malt. And other delightfully unexpected ingredients elevate the scotch.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients into a mixing tin and stir. Strain into a snifter glass. Express a lemon peel over top.
Ingredients: Aberlour A’Bunadh scotch;Cream sherry;Pierre Ferrand dry curaçao;Demerara syrup;Mole bitters

Name: No Country for Orange Men
About: The combination of mezcal blood orange and fine single malt is as surprising as it is delicious. This refreshing and complex original cocktail is perfect for almost any occasion.
HowToMake: Prepare a rocks glass with a chocolate chipotle and sea salt powder rim. Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Fine-strain into the prepared glass. Garnish with a dehydrated blood orange wheel.
Ingredients: Aberlour 12-year-old scotch;Fresh blood orange juice with citric acid;Pistachio orgeat syrup;Luxardo aperitivo
Garnish: Dark chocolate–chipotle–sea salt powder;Dehydrated blood orange wheel

Name: Margarita Picante
About: This take on a Frozen Margarita at Coccoloba Bar & Grill at Kimpton Seafire Resort + Spa on the Grand Cayman incorporates the fresh juices of honeydew and lime and the subtle spice of cayenne pepper.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to blender with a cup of ice and blend. Pour into a rocks glass. Dust with cayenne pepper. *Spiced honeydew syrup: Add 1 cup diced honeydew 1 cup sugar and 1 cup water to a saucepan muddle then stir for 3 minutes over medium heat. Let cool and add ground cayenne pepper to taste.
Ingredients: Blanco tequila;Triple sec;Fresh honeydew juice;Spiced honeydew syrup;Fresh lime juice

Name: Django Reinhardt
About: This cocktail which appears in Kat Odell’s Day Drinking: 50 Cocktails for a Mellow Buzz
HowToMake: Combine all the ingredients in a shaker and muddle to break down the orange. Add ice cubes to fill the shaker three-quarters full cover and shake to chill for about 15 seconds. Strain over ice into a rocks glass. Garnish with an orange slice.
Ingredients: Vermouth;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup;orange slices

Name: Black Betty
About: At one of downtown Vancouver’s celebrated farm-to-table restaurants Royal Dinette bar manager Kaitlyn Stewart plays with kitchen ingredients and techniques in her cocktails. The Black Betty intrigues with its dark depths and dehydrated beetroot-sugar garnish dusted across a layer of egg white.
HowToMake: Combine all the ingredients into a mixing tin and dry shake to emulsify egg white. Add ice and shake again for 10 to 15 seconds. Fine-strain into small rocks glass but with no ice. Garnish with dehydrated beetroot sugar. *Black sesame orgeat syrup: Lightly toast 2 cups of black sesame seeds in a pan. Let cool then blend in a blender or food processor. In a separate saucepan bring 1 1/2 cups sugar and 1 1/4 cups water to a light simmer. Once the sugar has dissolved add the blended sesame seeds to the saucepan. Bring to a boil over medium heat then remove from heat and cool for 3 hours. Once the mixture has cooled strain through a fine-mesh strainer or cheesecloth until silky. Add 1 tsp orange blossom water and 1 oz vodka. Bottle and refrigerate. Can be stored for up to 3 months. **Dehydrated beet sugar: Juice 4 large beets take the pulp (or byproduct) and ring out excess juice using a kitchen towel or cheese cloth. Spread the pulp onto a tray and place the tray in a dehydrator or oven at 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Once the pulp is completely dry add it to a spice grinder or blender with 1/2 cup white sugar then blitz into a fine powder. Makes 1 cup.
Ingredients: El Jimador blanco tequila;Pressed lime juice;Black sesame orgeat;Egg white;Activated charcoal

Name: Jill Rose
About: This cocktail by Jason Huffman the bar manager at Coin-Op Game Room
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake. Strain over crushed ice into a rocks glass. Garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel.
Ingredients: La Pommière calvados;Bénédictine;House-made grenadine (or grenadine);Fresh lime juice

Name: Takumi's Aviation
About: In 2010 while in Athens judging the Diageo World Class bartender competition barman Gary “Gaz” Regan tasted the very best Aviation
HowToMake: Add the gin into a shaker and stir to release the aromas. Add ice and the remaining ingredients and shake. Fine-strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.
Ingredients: Tanqueray No. TEN gin;Marie Brizard Parfait Amour liqueur;Fresh lemon juice

Name: Golden Frog
About: This cocktail by Steve Schneider appears on the inaugural menu of Panama City’s The Strangers Club in honor of Panama’s national animal.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass with a few large ice cubes and shake vigorously. Strain in a chilled cocktail glass and add a few drops of Angostura bitters. *Falernum (by Bratislav Glisic):. Place 1 1/2 cups peeled almonds into a glass jar. Add 1 quart filtered water and rinse. Discard the water and add another 1 quart filtered water. Leave the almonds in the jar for 4 hours shaking them occasionally. In a large pan combine 3 tbsp allspice 1 tbsp whole cloves and 4 star anise over medium heat tossing for 1 minute. Then add the water and almonds from the jar to the pan along with 2 quarts white sugar and 1/2 cup peeled and cut ginger stirring continuously. When the mixture is about to boil reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes stirring frequently. Remove from heat and let the mixture to cool down add the zest of 1 lime and stir. Pour the mixture back into jar and place in the refrigerator overnight. The following day strain the mixture over cheesecloth. In a fresh jar combine the syrup and overproof rum: For every 5 oz syrup add 1 oz overproof rum. Stir well and store up to 2 weeks.
Ingredients: Vodka (bison-grass-infused if available);House-made falernum;Fresh lemon juice;Egg white

Name: Smiling Rabbit
About: This mezcal
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice and garnish with a pineapple leaf. *Pineapple-cinnamon syrup: Bring 1 cup sugar and 1 cup water to a boil and simmer until sugar is dissolved. Remove from heat add 1 cup fresh pineapple chunks and 4 cinnamon sticks and steep for 30 minutes. Remove solids and store in the refrigerator.
Ingredients: Espadín mezcal;Fresh lemon juice;pineapple-cinnamon syrup;Yellow Chartreuse

Name: Berry-Kissed Frozen Sangria Is a Grown-Up Trea
About: Wine fruit and booze—what’s not to love?
HowToMake: Add all the Ingredients to a blender and blend until smooth. Garnish with skewered berries and a basil sprig.
Ingredients: Drambuie;Triple sec;Chardonnay;Fresh orange juice;Fresh lime juice;honey;Frozen berries;Cherry bitters

Name: Coin-Operated Boy
About: From Perez Klebahn the bar manager at Baltimore’s Rye this cocktail is a tall on-the-rocks refresher that surprises. The drink unfolds with salty-sweet intrigue from a house-made caramel by bartender Steve Lamb.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a rocks glass over ice and garnish with a charred lemon wheel. *House-made caramel: In  heavy pot heat 1 quart white sugar 1 cup water and 1 oz lemon juice to a boil stirring with a wooden spoon until the sugar begins to turn dark brown and brushing down the sides with a pastry brush. Remove from heat slowly add 3 cups water and stir. Keeps refrigerated for a few weeks.
Ingredients: Old Overholt rye whiskey;Fresh lemon juice;House-made caramel;Absinthe

Name: Negroni
About: This three-ingredient Italian cocktail is as classic as a drink can get.
HowToMake: Measure all of the ingredients to an Old Fashioned glass and add a large ice cube. Stir until cold and garnish with an orange half-wheel.
Ingredients: Campari;Gin;Sweet vermouth

Name: This Blackberry Wine Slushy Is Like Boozy Magi
About: Now you have the perfect use for that bit of leftover wine.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients with 1 cup of ice to a blender and blend. Pour into a stemless wine glass. Garnish with 2 blackberries.
Ingredients: Vodka;Blackberries;Orange juice;Red wine;Agave

Name: Haiballer
About: At Washington D.C.’s Dram & Grain the latest menu was dubbed Dram & Global offering a series of drinks inspired from different cities across the world including this Tokyo-style highball.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients into a highball glass with ice and stir to chill. Garnish with a dried burdock root chip (or lemon wedge if burdock is unavailable). *Golden delicious soda: Wash and cut 9�"12 Fuji apples (enough for 36 oz of juice) avoiding the cores/seeds and juice in an extractor quickly (apples oxidize in seconds when sitting out). Halve 10 lemons (enough for 10 oz of juice) and juice. Pour each through a mesh strainer to remove solids. Once you have 36 oz apple juice and 10 oz lemon combine the juices and add 24 oz filtered water. Mix in 2 tbsp almond extract and pour everything over 130 grams brown sugar in a separate container. Stir until dissolved then carbonate with a SodaStream.
Ingredients: Mizu shochu;Suntory Toki whisky;Golden Delicious soda;Angostura bitters

Name: Canadian Manhattan
About: An all-Canada ingredients list makes this cocktail by Simon Ogden of Veneto in Victoria British Columbia extra nice.
HowToMake: Combine all the ingredients in a mixing tin and stir. Pour into a coupe.
Ingredients: Lot 40 Canadian whisky;Odd Society Bittersweet vermouth;Bittered Sling Kensington Aromatic bitters

Name: Whisky Contardo
About: With a little bit of care and thought the old-school Whisky Mac can be reimagined and turned into something worthy of our more particular modern cocktailing palates the Whisky Contardo from bartender Adam Bernbach at Washington D.C.’s 2 Birds 1 Stone.
HowToMake: Add the ingredients to a mixing tin with ice and stir. Strain into a coupe glass express a lemon peel and garnish with the peel. *Spiced Stone's Original Green Ginger Wine: Blend 8 oz Stone’s Original Green Ginger Wine 1 15-gram piece of fresh ginger and 1 gram white pepper and strain.
Ingredients: The Famous Grouse Smoky Black scotch;Spiced Stone's Original Green Ginger Wine;Yellow Chartreuse;Orange bitters

Name: Needful Things
About: More refreshing than your average Irish Coffee this drink from Drexl in Oakland Calif. packs a surprising and delightful mix of flavors.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a shaker and dry-shake. Add ice and shake hard. Double-strain into an Irish Coffee mug and add soda slowly to fill. Garnish with a dash of bitters.
Ingredients: Teeling small-batch whiskey;St. George NOLA coffee liqueur;Giffard Banane du Brésil liqueur;Tempus Fugit Crème de Noyaux liqueur;Fresh lemon juice;Egg white;Soda water

Name: Teeling Allspice Irish Coffee
About: An Irish Coffee is all about the ingredients. And this one by Mary Chojnacki of the Chicago Athletic Association features amazing coffee incredible whiskey and a pleasant dash of spice.
HowToMake: Warm a coffee mug with hot water and discard the water. Pour the coffee to fill 3/4 of the way up. Add a spoonful of brown sugar and add the whiskey. Slowly top with the heavy whipping cream and garnish with allspice powder.
Ingredients: Metropolis coffee;Brown sugar;Heavy whipping cream;Allspice

Name: Northern Exposur
About: This Irish Coffee from The Dawson is both soothing and luxurious. It’s an upscale cocktail you can make at home.
HowToMake: Add the whiskey liqueur and syrup to an Irish Coffee glass and top with the coffee. Whip the cream in a sealed container and slowly pour over the top of the cocktail. Garnish with a dusting of chai masala powder.
Ingredients: Kronan Swedish Punsch liqueur;Cinnamon syrup;Metric Le Corbusier French roast coffee;Heavy whipping cream

Name: Irish Goodbye
About: Say hello to this beer-centric update on the Irish Coffee by Matthew Frederick of EZ Inn in Chicago. And don’t worry you don’t have to be a beer lover to enjoy it.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients except the cream in a metal steaming pitcher. Let sit for a few seconds while the nitro from the beer dissipates. Steam with a milk steamer until the temperature reaches 170°F. Pour into an Irish Coffee mug and top with the whipped cream. Garnish with a cinnamon stick. *Coffee-infused Teeling Small Batch Whiskey: Mix 10 grams instant coffee with 750mL Teeling Small Batch Whiskey. **Brown sugar coffee syrup: Heat 2 cups water then add 2 cups dark brown sugar and 1 tbsp instant coffee.
Ingredients: Coffee-infused Teeling Small Batch Whiskey;Brown sugar coffee syrup;Half & half;Maplewood Fat Pug Nitro Milk Stout (or Guinness or any Nitro Milk Stout);Whipped cream

Name: Wake & Bake Julep
About: This Irish Coffee by Brian Tasch of Dusek’s Board and Beer in Chicago gets an iced makeover along with some welcome additions and tweaks to the traditional recipes.
HowToMake: Add the whiskey syrup and liqueur to a stainless steel cup and fill 3/4 of the way with crushed ice. Swizzle with a bar spoon agitate the ice and top with more crushed ice. Add the bitters and garnish with a few macadamia nuts and a mint sprig.
Ingredients: Cardamom-macadamia nut syrup;Brancamenta liqueur;Angostura bitters;Cold-brew coffee

Name: Butter & Scotch Irish Coffee
About: Good coffee great whiskey and a little sweetness turns this Irish Coffee by Allison Kave of Butter & Scotch into something special.
HowToMake: Add the whiskey and syrup into an Irish Coffee mug then fill with the coffee. Top with freshly whipped cream and a dusting of cocoa powd.
Ingredients: Simple syrup;Drip coffee;Freshly whipped cream

Name: August Laura Irish Coffee
About: A few unexpected ingredients and artisanal touches separate this cocktail by Alyssa Sartor of August Laura in New York City from your average Irish Coffee.
HowToMake: Add the whiskey allspice dram and syrup to an Irish Coffee mug and fill with the coffee. Top with the cream and dust with ground cinnamon.
Ingredients: St. Elizabeth allspice dram;Cinnamon simple syrup;Freshly brewed coffee;Heavy whipping cream

Name: Breakfast of Champions
About: Good coffee and great whiskey make this an unforgettable Irish Coffee riff by Natalie Streiter of Fools Gold in New York City and the perfect addition to any meal.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a shaker hard-shake and pour into a Collins glass.
Ingredients: NoFo coffee;Whole milk;Maple syrup;Bénédictine

Name: The Irish Cure
About: This Irish Coffee by Dave Buggy of The Copper Still in New York City hits all of the right fruity notes. It’s an Irish cure-all for bad coffee and cocktails.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients except for the cream to an Irish Coffee mug and stir. Add the cream to top and dust with cocoa powder.
Ingredients: Orange syrup;Cocoa syrup;Vanilla syrup;Fresh brewed coffee;Heavy whipping cream

Name: Between Tigris and Euphrates
About: This cocktail by Rob Giles the beverage director at Until Tomorrow in New York City would still be a soothing and subtle Irish Coffee without it but it’s not truly finished until you’ve added the whipped cream.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients except the cream to a shaker and dry-shake. Add the vanilla-tahini whipped cream to top. *Vanilla-tahini whipped cream: Add 1 barspoon of Giffard Vanille de Madagascar liqueur and 1 barspoon of tahini paste to 2 oz heavy whipping cream to a shaker and shake for 30 seconds.
Ingredients: Crème de cacao;Walnut liqueur;Medium-roast Colombian coffee;Vanilla-tahini whipped cream

Name: The Lark Irish Coffee
About: You probably don’t associate root beer syrup and nutmeg with Irish Coffee but that’s exactly why you have to try this recipe from The Lark in San Francisco.
HowToMake: Preheat an Irish Coffee glass with warm water and discard the water. Add the whiskey and syrup and top with the coffee and a float of fresh lightly whipped cream. Garnish with a dusting of grated nutmeg.
Ingredients: Root beer syrup;Freshly brewed coffee;Whipped cream

Name: The Shannon
About: The perfect Irish Coffee for a hot day this light and refreshing cocktail by Mike Di Tota the head bartender at The Bonnie in New York City features the right balance of fruitiness and earthiness.“As we’re moving into warmer weather we wanted to create a drink that’s more light and refreshing than a traditional Irish Coffee” says Di Tota. “It does contain actual cold brew but it’s more focused on pulling out the flavors of coffee through the other ingredients: earthiness and salinity from the Teeling whiskey fruitiness from the date syrup smoke from the sea salt and spice from the cardamom. It’s light in body but full of flavor.”
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to shaker and dry-shake (without ice) for 10 seconds. Add 3 or 4 ice cubes and shake very well. Strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with cinnamon and alderwood-smoked sea salt. *Spiced date syrup: Add 1 cup water and 1 cup turbinado sugar to a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the sugar is dissolved. Add 1 cup date molasses and stir until combined. Add 5 crushed cinnamon sticks and 5 crushed black cardamom pods and simmer for five minutes. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Keeps refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.
Ingredients: Zirbenz Stone Pine Liqueur of the Alps;Cappelletti Amaro Sfumato;Cold brew coffee;Spiced date syrup;Fresh lemon juice;Egg white;Grapefruit bitters

Name: Whisky Mac
About: This old timer’s whisky cocktail is shorthand for the Whisky Macdonald so named for a Colonel Hector MacDonald who first crafted the drink while serving during the British Raj in India. It’s a simple combination of blended scotch  and Stone’s Original Green Ginger Wine  a fortified wine described on the bottle as a “ginger flavored currant wine” with a 13.5 percent ABV.
HowToMake: Pour the ingredients over ice into a rocks glass and stir lightly.
Ingredients: Blended scotch;Stone's Original Green Ginger Wine

Name: Cynar Flip
About: Canadian whisky meets Italian aperitivo in this rich and creamy cocktail by Jayce Kadyschuk the head bartender at Clive’s in Victoria British Columbia. “The higher rye content works really well here” he says.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake. Strain and serve in a coupe. *Clove simple syrup: Bring cloves [to taste] to simmer in water. Turn off heat and mix in sugar at 1:1 ratio to water.
Ingredients: Alberta Premium Canadian whisky;Cynar;Cointreau;Clove simple syrup;Whole egg;The Bitter Truth Jerry Thomas’ Own Decanter bitters

Name: Toronto
About: A dash of fernet spices up this 416-style Manhattan by Simon Ogden of Veneto in Victoria British Columbia.
HowToMake: Combine all the ingredients in a mixing tin and stir. Pour into a coupe.
Ingredients: Alberta Premium Canadian whisky;Fernet-Branca digestif;Simple syrup;Angostura bitters

Name: Dublin Pick Me Up
About: This riff on an Irish Coffee swaps in espresso from Leo’s in San Francisco and balances those bold flavors with a little mint.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake. Dirty-dump into a chilled highball glass and top with the mint whipped cream. Garish with mint sprigs.
Ingredients: Teeling SmallBatch Whiskey;Caffè Borghetti espresso liqueur;Mint whipped cream;Single shot of espresso;Mint leaves

Name: She’s Leaving Home
About: The strong coffee flavor in this cocktail from Rusted Mule
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients except the soda water to a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into mixing tin and dry-shake for 1 minute. Strain into chilled Old Fashioned glass. Slowly add soda water until foam goes beyond the lip of the glass. Garnish with fresh coffee grounds and an orange twist.
Ingredients: St. George NOLA coffee liqueur;Simple syrup;Heavy cream;Egg white;Orange blossom water;Soda water

Name: Dr. Teeling's Pick-Me-Up
About: This whipped and iced cocktail from Devil’s Acre in San Francisco is a mouthwatering and complex take on the Irish Coffee. It’s just the pick-me-up you need.
HowToMake: Whip all of the ingredients with 4 ice cubes until the cubes are almost fully melted. Strain and shake-dry to further whip. Pour into a tall zombie glass and top with Mexican Coca-Cola. Add 2 ice cubes and spray the top of the drink with ammonia spirit.
Ingredients: Green Chartreuse;Vanilla syrup;Devil's Larder Rootbeer bitters;Lactart;Acid phosphate;Stumptown Cold Brew Coffee;Egg white;Mexican Coca-Cola;Ammonia spirit

Name: Moscow Mule Recip
About: “The Moscow Mule is a classic vodka-based cocktail for a reason. Speaking the name of the cocktail conjures up images of the sweating copper mug that’s the de rigeur vessel for the Moscow Mule. While said mug is preferred for serving it’s not necessary and shouldn’t deter you from making a Moscow Mule.The Moscow Mule was in born the 1950s during the heydey of vodka. And this organic version brings the legendary drink up to date while remaining true to its refreshing roots. Combining ginger beer lime juice and vodka the Moscow Mule is deceptively simple and incredibly easy to mix making it perfect for any season.”
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients intoto a Moscow Mule mug (or highball glass) over ice. Garnish with a lime wheel.
Ingredients: Vodka;Ginger beer;Juice of half a lime

Name: Mai Tai
About: The Mai Tai is perhaps the most famous Tiki cocktail for a good reason. Trader Vic’s is credited with inventing the drink and the first person to try it was said to cry out “Mai Tai!” which means “the best—out of this world” in Tahitian. The Mai Tai took a star turn by earning a prominent role in the Elvis film “Blue Hawaii.”The Mai Tai was created as a way to showcase the flavors of good-quality rum. It should never be neon-colored or overly sweet. A proper Mai Tai is a deep amber hue and allows the rum to shine through with the other ingredients.
HowToMake: Add the white rum curaçao juice and orgeat into a shaker with crushed ice and shake lightly (about 3 seconds). Pour into a double Old Fashioned glass. Float the dark rum over top. Garnish with a lime wheel and mint sprig.
Ingredients: White rum;Orange curaçao;Fresh lime juice;Orgeat;Dark rum

Name: Tequila Sunrise
About: The Tequila Sunrise with its bright striations of color evokes a summer sunrise. This simple classic has only three ingredients—tequila grenadine and orange juice—and is served unmixed to preserve the color of each layer.The Tequila Sunrise was created by Bobby Lozoff and Billy Rice in Sausalito Calif. The cocktail achieved notoriety after Mick Jagger began drinking it and The Rolling Stones dubbed their 1972 tour “the cocaine and Tequila Sunrise tour.” The drink has been a part of the cocktail canon ever since.
HowToMake: Add the tequila and then the orange juice to a chilled highball glass. Float the grenadine on top. Garnish with an orange slice and a cherry.
Ingredients: Blanco tequila;Fresh orange juice;Grenadine

Name: Long Island Iced Tea Recip
About: On paper the Long Island Iced Tea is one hot mess of a drink. Four different—and disparate—spirits slugging it out in a single glass along with triple sec lemon juice and cola? The recipe reads more like a frat house hazing than one of the world’s most popular cocktails. And yet somehow it works. That’s because the Long Island Iced Tea succeeds where so many of today’s refined cocktails fall short: It’s boozy AF—more than four ounces of alcohol against less than half that amount in mixers. Unless you’re a sailor on shore leave that’s a red-flag ratio rife with morning-after consequences. It’s also precisely what a person needs every now and then.Best then not to intellectualize the Long Island Iced Tea and simply love it for what it is: an easy-gulping one-and-done stiffy. If you’re looking to tame your tea a bit pull back the boozy parts from three-quarter ounce to half-ounce and lean in on the cola. The good people of Long Island won’t be offended.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the cola into a Collins glass with ice. Top with a splash of the cola and stir briefly. Garnish with a lemon wedge. Serve with a straw.
Ingredients: Vodka;White rum;Silver tequila;Gin;Triple sec;Simple syrup;Fresh lemon juice;Cola to top

Name: Mojito Recip
About: To many people the Mojito represents the perfect rum cocktail. The origins of the drink can be traced back to Cuba and the 16th-century Cuban cocktail El Draque named for Sir Francis Drake. Appropriately almost all of the ingredients in the Mojito are indigenous to Cuba. Rum lime mint and sugar (derived from cane juice) are mixed with soda water to create a refreshing classic cocktail.The Mojito is traditionally served over ice in a highball glass and often associated with summer. Like your cocktails with literary references? You’re in luck. The Mojito is said to have been a favorite of Ernest Hemingway. While the Mojito is slightly more labor-intensive than other cocktails because it involves muddling the mint the end result is a delicious refreshing cocktail that can be enjoyed any time of the year.
HowToMake: Lightly muddle the mint in a shaker. Add the rum lime juice simple syrup and ice and give it a brief shake. Strain into a highball glass over fresh ice. Top with the club soda. Garnish with a mint sprig and lime wheel.
Ingredients: White rum;Mint leaves;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup;Club soda to top

Name: Cadbury Creme Egg
About: Everyone’s favorite Easter candy gets transformed into a creamy chocolatey boozy treat. Need more sweet inspiration? Check out the five best cadbury creme egg cocktails.
HowToMake: Grate or chop the chocolate and place in a small shallow bowl or rimmed plate. Melt on low heat in the microwave. Dip the rim of the cocktail glass in the chocolate and chill to set. Combine the vodka Chartreuse crème de cacao and cream in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake well. Strain into the chocolate-rimmed glass. Grate additional chocolate curls over the top of the drink. Top with a Cadbury Creme Mini Egg cut open to reveal the "yolk."
Ingredients: Vanilla vodka;Yellow Chartreuse;White crème de cacao;Heavy cream
Garnish: 1 oz semisweet or dark chocolate;Shaved chocolate;Cadbury Creme Mini Egg

Name: Orange Sherbet Mimosa Punch
About: Joy Wilson aka Joy the Baker has created this perfectly springy and bubbly brunch drink found in her book Over Easy
HowToMake: Serves 8-10. In a large punch bowl gently stir together the Champagne orange juice and ginger ale. Add the orange sherbet in generous scoops. The sherbet will slowly melt into the punch. Ladle into rocks glasses (which are easier to ladle into than Champagne flutes).
Ingredients: Chilled dry Champagne (750 mL);Chilled fresh orange juice;Chilled ginger ale;Orange sherbet

Name: Volunteer
About: This cocktail served at Snackbar
HowToMake: In a mixing glass muddle the melon cucumber jalapeño cilantro lime juice grapefruit bitters and agave syrup. Add the tequila Cointreau and salt and shake. Strain into a rocks glass with ice. Garnish with a cucumber slice jalapeño slice and parsley leaf sprinkled with cumin seeds.
Ingredients: One-inch chunks of melon;Cucumber;Jalapeño;cilantro leaves;Fresh lime juice;Grapefruit bitters;Agave syrup;Cuestión tequila blanco;Cointreau;Salt;Cumin seed

Name: Pink Flamingo
About: This rhum agricole cocktail served at Over Proof
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe glass. *Tiki-Tivo apéritif: Combine 1 oz Campari
Ingredients: Rhum J.M;Fresh lime juice;Pineapple gum syrup;ABV’s Tiki-Tivo apéritif;Leopold Bros. Absinthe Verte

Name: Momisette
About: This classic French cocktail combines licorice and almond flavors.
HowToMake: Add the pastis and orgeat syrup into a Collins glass with ice top with sparkling water and stir.
Ingredients: Pastis;Orgeat Syrup;Sparkling water

Name: Bourbon Milk Punch
About: This classic brunch cocktail hails from New Orleans.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a rocks glass and garnish with grated nutmeg.
Ingredients: Bourbon;Whole milk;Simple syrup;Vanilla extract

Name: Port of Call
About: This gin cocktail by Tom Macy of Clover Club in New York City combines sweet and tart flavors.
HowToMake: Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain over crushed or cracked ice in a rocks glass. Garnish with a mint sprig and speared blackberry and raspberry. *Cinnamon syrup: Mix 1 cup sugar in 1 cup of water and boil until sugar is dissolved. Add 6 cinnamon sticks cover and let it sit overnight. Remove the cinnamon sticks. Keeps for 1 month in the refrigerator.
Ingredients: London dry gin;Ruby port;Fresh lemon juice;Cinnamon syrup;Cranberry preserves

Name: Green Tea Highball
About: Two of Japan’s most famous beverages get cozy in this uplifting cocktail.
HowToMake: Add the whisky and tea to a Collins glass with an ice spear and stir. Top with the soda water. Garnish with the maple leaf candy.
Ingredients: Japanese whisky;Brewed green tea cooled;Soda water

Name: Fallen Leaf
About: Brett Esler of Whisler’s in Austin created this intricate take on the Hot Toddy. It gets a nice spice from ginger liqueur a round sweetness from house-made honey syrup and plenty of spice from cinnamon and allspice. Keep in mind this tipple proves strong so it’s best to sip slowly.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except for the cinnamon-lemon-infused hot water into a small Toddy mug. Top with the infused hot water. Garnish with a lemon wheel and grated nutmeg. *Honey syrup: Add .5 cup honey and .5 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. (You can experiment and decide how much of a honey flavor you want in your syrup. The more honey you use the thicker the syrup and stronger in flavor it will be.) Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator. **Cinnamon-lemon-infused hot water: Boil 1 cup water 1 lemon peel and 1 cinnamon stick for 5 minutes discard the peel and stick and let cool.
Ingredients: Elijah Craig small-batch bourbon;Lustau Solera Reserva brandy de Jerez;Domaine de Canton ginger liqueur;St. Elizabeth allspice dram;Fresh lemon juice;Honey syrup;Cinnamon-lemon-infused hot water

Name: Make It Count
About: Pamela Wiznitzer of Seamstress in New York City thinks that if you have just one drink you might as well Make It Count. This lovely red-hued cocktail takes the bitterness of Campari and mellows it out with a little honey syrup and sweet blood orange. It gets a little sparkle from soda water and proves perfectly refreshing on hot day or as an after-dinner treat.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients to a highball glass with ice and stir gently. Garnish with an orange chip. *Honey syrup: Add .5 cup honey and .5 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. (You can experiment and decide how much of a honey flavor you want in your syrup. The more honey you use the thicker the syrup and stronger in flavor it will be.) Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator.
Ingredients: Campari;The Perfect Purée of Napa Valley blood orange concentrate;Honey syrup;Splash of soda water

Name: Eau de Lavender
About: Sexy and smooth this tequila cocktail has a hint of lavender and a dash of sweet honey syrup. It’s spring in a cup but since the floral flavors come from bitters you can sip it all year round.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker and dry-shake (without ice). Add ice and shake again to emulsify thoroughly. Strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with a lavender sprig. *Honey syrup: Add 1/2 cup honey and 1/2 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. (You can experiment and decide how much of a honey flavor you want in your syrup. The more honey you use the thicker the syrup and stronger in flavor it will be.) Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator.
Ingredients: Tequila;Fresh lemon juice;Honey syrup;Egg white

Name: Tequila Honey Bee
About: Bartender Nick Korbee the executive chef and beverage director at Egg Shop in New York City uses honey in his tequila  cocktail with a touch of smokiness thanks to a mezcal  wash which goes brilliantly with the sweet nectar and tart lemon.
HowToMake: Rinse a highball glass with the mezcal coating the inside of the glass with a thin layer and dumping out whatever doesn’t stick. Add the tequila syrup and lemon juice to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Pour into the prepared glass and add 2 dashes of the bitters. Garnish with a lemon peel. *Honey syrup: Add 1/2 cup honey and 1/2 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. (You can experiment and decide how much of a honey flavor you want in your syrup. The more honey you use the thicker the syrup and stronger in flavor it will be.) Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator.
Ingredients: Espolón reposado tequila;Del Maguey mezcal rinse;Honey syrup;Fresh lemon juice;Angostura bitters

Name: Color Changing Martini
About: This cocktail from Public Belt at the Hilton New Orleans Riverside changes color from light purple to deep purple to a bright fuschia.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients except for the lemon juice into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a Martini glass and add the lemon juice to change the color.
Ingredients: Gin;Ginger liqueur;Simple syrup;Dropper of b’Lure butterfly pea flower extract;Fresh lemon juice

Name: Bone & Bacon
About: Those who can’t resist a smoky cocktail or order the first drink on the menu promising a garnish of cured meat should stir up this four-ingredient bacon-flavored bourbon drink by Dylan Holcomb of Denver’s Beatrice & Woodsley and Mario’s Double Daughter’s Salotto served on some seriously meaty rocks.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass. Add the broth ice cubes and stir approximately 30 times. Strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a baby back rib bone. *Osso Good bison bone broth ice cubes: Combine the broth with equal parts water chill in the refrigerator for 12 hours skim off the fat layer that floats to the top and place into large ice cube trays to freeze.
Ingredients: Ol' Major Bacon bourbon;Averna amaro;Black walnut bitters;Osso Good bison bone broth ice cubes

Name: Duck Hunt
About: Ambitious home cooks who want to add some fancy French flavors to their cocktail glasses should try this duck-stock-based drink by Eric Rivera the executive chef at Seattle’s The Bookstore Bar & Café that will seriously impress dinner guests.
HowToMake: In a small saucepan warm the duck stock. In a small bowl combine the egg white and cold water then stir that mixture into the warm stock. Bring to a simmer. Remove pan from heat and let stand for 5 minutes. (As the egg white cooks it will coagulate and trap fine particles from the stock.) Pour the stock through cheesecloth into a small clean bowl to strain out the particles and egg white. Add the salt and smoked pepper. Pour the seasoned stock Génépy and absinthe into a rocks glass. Garnish with toasted juniper berries whole caraway seeds and a rosemary sprig.
Ingredients: Duck stock strained;Half egg white;Cold water;Maldon sea salt;Smoked black pepper;Dolin Génépy des Alpes liqueur
Garnish: Toasted juniper berries;Whole caraway seeds;Rosemary sprig

Name: Chicken Soup Hot Toddy
About: This riff on the traditional Hot Toddy by Johnny Swet of JIMMY at The James hotel in New York City plays up chicken soup’s savory flavors by adding carrot and celery. And who doesn’t want a good snack-like garnish in any drink?
HowToMake: Pour all ingredients into a snifter. Garnish with a carrot stick celery stick and parsley.
Ingredients: NOLET’S gin;Celery bitters;Freshly squeezed lemon juice;Chicken stock heated

Name: Chicken & Apple Wassail
About: Those who seek comfort from slowly slurping a bowl of chicken soup can enjoy the savory flavors of chicken broth paired with autumnal apple in any season. This elegant chilled chicken cocktail by Christy Pope of consulting and catering company Cuffs & Buttons and Dallas’ Midnight Rambler Bar turns your sick day into a party in the best way possible.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with add ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a coupe glass. Grate fresh nutmeg on top of the drink for garnish.
Ingredients: Laird’s applejack;Swanson organic free-range chicken stock;Apple cider;Simple syrup;Freshly squeezed lemon juice;Angostura bitters

Name: Sweet & Sour Chicken Toddy
About: Warm chicken soup may be your go-to on a sick day but why not take it up a notch with some gin and juice? This chicken-stock-based Hot Toddy by Christy Pope of Cuffs & Buttons and Dallas’ Midnight Rambler Bar  turns your sick day into a party in the best way possible.
HowToMake: In a small pot on the stove combine all ingredients except the gin over medium heat. Once the liquid starts to steam add the gin and remove from the stove. Pour the heated cocktail into a Toddy glass. Garnish with star anise.
Ingredients: Swanson organic free-range chicken broth;Pineapple syrup;Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice;Sriracha;Beefeater gin

Name: Marzipan Old Fashioned
About: Beverage director Cody Pruitt melts De La Rosa peanut marzipan candies into a marzipan syrup to sweeten this mezcal– and tequila-based Old Fashioned. A touch of oloroso sherry echoes the nutty flavors from the peanut-studded candy.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a double rocks glass over a large ice cube. *Marzipan syrup: Simmer 3 cups crushed De La Rosa peanut marzipan candies and 3 cups water until the sugar is dissolved and only the peanut pieces are left floating. Strain through a chinois and bottle. Keeps for up to 6 days refrigerated.
Ingredients: Los Amantes joven mezcal;Espolón reposado tequila;Lustau oloroso sherry;Marzipan syrup

Name: DIY Pink Gin
About: Adapted from the 1939 classic cocktail book The Gentleman’s Companion by Charles H. Baker the original cocktail nods to the drink’s Navy roots suggesting that the excess bitters “go back in the bottle on the floor or out the porthole or window depending upon who where and what we are.”
HowToMake: Dash the bitters into a chilled coupe. Gently tip the glass and rotate it to coat the inside of the glass. Pour out the excess bitters. Stir the gin in a mixing glass with ice then strain into the prepared glass. Garnish with a curl of lime peel.
Ingredients: London dry or Old Tom gin

Name: Diamond Claret Cup
About: Red wine gets a boost from raspberry brandy in this eau-de-vie cocktail from John Codd of San Francisco’s Tradition.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the Champagne water into mixing tin with ice and shake briefly. Strain into a Collins glass over ice and top with the sparkling wine. Garnish with a mint sprig.
Ingredients: St. George raspberry brandy;Red wine;Fresh lemon juice;Small Hand Foods gum syrup;Small Hand Foods grenadine;Sparkling wine

Name: Pomelo Cream Fizz
About: Pomelos—large thick-skinned citrus fruits—are easy to find in Asian markets. But grapefruit works just as well in this refreshingly fizzy drink. Brad Goocher the beverage director at Charleston S.C.’s Le Farfalle also makes a mocktail version of the drink with three ounces of juice and one ounce each of honey and cream.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients except the seltzer to a blender with 1 cup of ice and pulse until smooth. Pour into a highball glass or Mason jar and fill to the top with the chilled seltzer.
Ingredients: Gin;Freshly squeezed pomelo juice;Heavy cream;honey;Seltzer to top

Name: Carrot Thing
About: New York City’s Saxon + Parole plays with plenty of fresh produce on its drink menu which means that (depending on the season) guests often request “that watermelon thing” or “that pumpkin thing.” This time head bartenders Maxime Belfand and Masa Urushido stayed one step ahead and named their heirloom-carrot-packed winter drink accordingly.
HowToMake: Prepare a rocks glass with a half-rim of smoked Maldon sea salt. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain over fresh ice into the prepared glass and garnish with a carrot chip.
Ingredients: Great King St. Glasgow Blend scotch;Del Maguey Vida mezcal;Liqor 43;Heirloom carrot juice (purple orange and yellow);Agave syrup;Freshly squeezed lemon juice

Name: Plain Killer
About: At James Beard Award winner Tory Miller’s pan-Asian restaurant Sujeo in Madison Wis. a duo of fresh pineapple and orange juices round out a Tiki-style libation (modeled on the classic Painkiller) built for two thirsty revelers.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Pour with the ice into a Tiki mug and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.
Ingredients: El Dorado 15-year-old rum;Freshly squeezed pineapple juice;Freshly squeezed orange juice;Coco Lopez coconut cream

Name: Calafia
About: Newly opened in December 2016 from Top Chef alum Ryan Scott the cocktail menu at San Francisco’s Finn Town boasts plenty of fresh juices—cucumber ginger etc. But fennel’s not one you see on the drink menu very often. This drink by bartender Anthony Parks lends freshness and subtle anise to a tequila-forward sipper.
HowToMake: Combine all of the ingredients except the soda water into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Pour over fresh ice into a Collins glass and top with the soda water. Garnish with fennel fronds and fennel pollen.
Ingredients: Cimarrón blanco tequila;El Silencio espadín mezcal;Fennel juice (juice of fennel bulbs);Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice;Agave syrup;Soda water to top

Name: Scottish Beats
About: Nodding to the classic Blood & Sand this drink by Jason Percival the bar manager at Boston’s Post 390 relies on beets for its dramatic rosy hue and a hint of sweetness.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Double-strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.
Ingredients: Scotch;Cherry Heering liqueur;Sweet vermouth (Vya Dolin or Carpano);Cointreau;Beet puree (cooked and peeled beets pureed)

Name: Posset
About: Although the full recipe takes a couple of hours this classic drink is accomplished in a crockpot so it’s basically a set-it-and-forget-it type of recipe. Get a batch started before friends arrive then spoon into coffee mugs.“We use an IPA as the beer base” says Mike Bohn of New York City’s Olmsted “which gives the drink a contrasting freshness from the hops and citrus plus a little porter thrown in to add some coffee richness.”
HowToMake: Serves 10�"12 (6 oz pours). Place the mace allspice berries cloves and cinnamon on top of a square of cheesecloth and use kitchen twine to tie tightly into a spice sachet. Turn a crockpot on high. Add the cream and eggs and whisk until homogenized. Once warm whisk in the sugar until dissolved then add the beers liquors and spice sachet. Continue to cook on high for 2 hours until the mixture forms what is essentially a cooked layer of egg and curd on top. Turn temperature down to warm until you’re ready to serve. To serve whisk into fine curds then spoon into coffee mugs. Grate fresh nutmeg on top to garnish.
Ingredients: Mace;Allspice berries;Whole cloves;Grated fresh cinnamon;Heavy cream;Eggs;Sugar;India pale ale;Porter;Strega liqueur;Allspice dram;Velvet falernum

Name: Hot Apple Pie
About: Looking for something to warm you up when it’s cold out? Try this cocktail from Smith & Whistle at the Sheraton Grand London Park Lane.
HowToMake: Bring all of the ingredients to a boil while stirring occasionally. Strain into an Irish Coffee mug and garnish with 2 dried apple slices and a cinnamon stick. *Cinnamon-infused honey: Add 3 to 5 cinnamon sticks to a small jar (4 oz or so) and fill with honey of choice. Let sit 4 to 6 days tasting on occasion and remove the cinnamon sticks once the cinnamon flavor is satisfactory (i.e. present without being overwhelmingly strong).
Ingredients: Calvados;Mead;Apple juice;Freshly squeezed lemon juice;Cinnamon-infused honey

Name: Steeply Devoted
About: This boozy tea by bartender Elia Covino at Chicago’s Rebar in Trump hotel will warm you up during winter. “I wanted to make something to replace the mulled wine we would serve around the holidays that would appeal to the Hot Toddy drinkers and that spirits people wouldn’t generally think would go well in a warm cocktail” says Covino. “I knew I wanted vermouth to be a component and the gin was a wonderful addition adding more depth and a floral component. The milk chocolate elixir plays off both of those so well and the ginger snap liqueur and honey add a touch of sweetness.”
HowToMake: Steep all the ingredients except for the dried fruit in 6 oz hot water for 4 minutes to make a tea.  Add the dried apples apricots and strawberries in a cup. Pour the tea over the fruit. *Honey syrup: Add 1 cup honey and .5 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator. **Dried fruit mix: approximately 2 apples 2 apricots and 5 strawberries.
Ingredients: NOLET'S Silver Dry Gin;Art in the Age ginger snap liqueur;Carpano Antica Formula vermouth;Honey syrup;Rare Tea Cellar Emperor’s Milk chocolate elixir;Lemon peels;Dried fruit mix
Brands: Art in the Age;carpano;NOLET'S Finest Gin;Rare Tea Cellar

Name: Remember the Maine
About: If you appreciate a good Manhattan—a rye Manhattan specifically—then the Remember the Maine will most likely find a home in your drinks repertoire. The cocktail comes from Charles H. Baker Jr’s. The Gentleman’s Companion
HowToMake: In a chilled coupe or cocktail glass add the absinthe. Roll around to coat and discard the excess. Add the rye vermouth and liqueur to a mixing glass with ice and stir well. Strain into the prepared glass and garnish with a brandied cherry.
Ingredients: Rye whiskey;Sweet vermouth;Cherry Heering liqueur;Absinthe

Name: Cobra's Fang
About: Until recently fassionola syrup which was used in many old Tiki drinks including the Hurricane was lost to the past. The Jonathan English Company bottled it in the 1950s and modern bartenders have either created house-made versions or substituted passion fruit syrup. Recently Cocktail & Sons
HowToMake: Blend all of the ingredients with 6 oz of crushed ice for 5 seconds and pour into a highball glass or tall Tiki mug. Garnish with a mint leaf and lime wheel.
Ingredients: Dark Jamaican rum;151-proof demerara rum;Freshly squeezed lime juice;Falernum;Freshly squeezed orange juice;Fassionola syrup;Angostura bitters;Grenadine;Herbsaint liqueur

Name: Red Snapper
About: This classic gin cocktail is an alternative to the Bloody Mary.
HowToMake: Pour the salt and pepper onto a small plate. Rub the juicy side of a lime wedge along the lip of a pint glass rim the glass with the salt and pepper and fill the glass with ice. Add the remaining ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into the prepared glass and garnish with a celery stalk and lime wedge.
Ingredients: Celery salt;Freshly ground black pepper;Lime wedge;Gin;Tomato juice;Freshly squeezed lemon juice;Tabasco;Worcestershire sauce

Name: Wisconsin Old Fashioned
About: This cocktail aka the Brandy Old Fashioned is practically the official Wisconsin state drink and takes brandy instead of whiskey.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients except for the brandy to an Old Fashioned glass and muddle. Add ice to fill the glass add the brandy then top with the 7Up/Sprite (or seltzer or sour soda). Garnish with a skewered brandied or maraschino cherry and an orange slice.
Ingredients: Orange slices;Brandied or maraschino cherries;Angostura bitters;Sugar cube;7Up/Sprite seltzer or sour soda (sour mix and soda water);Brandy

Name: Pink Squirrel
About: This cocktail has a good deal in common with the Brandy Alexander and Grasshopper  with its crème de cacao and cream. Where it differs markedly is in the inclusion of crème de noyaux a once popular but relatively forgotten liqueur that is similar to amaretto. The red color of the liqueur usually comes from cochineal which doesn’t affect the singular herbal-meets-bitter almond flavor.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients into a shaker filled of ice and shake until cold. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with grated nutmeg.
Ingredients: Tempus Fugit crème de noyaux;Tempus Fugit white crème de cacao;Heavy cream

Name: Rusty Nail
About: Cocktails don’t come much easier than this one which has been around since the late 1930s. A lot of recipes suggest equal parts but you’re better off starting with two ounces of scotch and a half ounce of Drambuie tinkering until you find your personal ratio. No matter how you drink it you’ll be channeling the Rat Pack in no time.
HowToMake: Combine the ingredients in a rocks glass add 1 large ice cube and stir. Garnish with a lemon twist.
Ingredients: Blended scotch whisky;Drambuie liqueur

Name: Maribell's Late Agai
About: This savory cocktail by bartender Reid Lewis at Dallas’ Bowen House
HowToMake: Combine all of the ingredients except for the olive oil in a mixing glass and stir. Pour into a Nick & Nora glass and top with the olive oil. Garnish with a lemon peel speared with a rosemary sprig. *Rosemary-infused Spanish olive oil: Take a large handful of fresh rosemary stems split them into 2 equal parts then moderately roast 1 part with a brulee torch. The other half remains fresh. Simmer 2 cups Spanish olive oil add all of the rosemary and simmer at low heat for 20 minutes. Strain through a cheesecloth into an eyedropper.
Ingredients: Don Ciccio & Figli finocchietto liqueur;Dolin Blanc;Celery bitters;Rosemary-infused Spanish olive oil

Name: Dr. Osthimer
About: This shaken cocktail has just enough citrus to brighten up the sweet flavor profile. It’s precisely what the doctor ordered.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients to a shaker and dry-shake (without ice) then shake with ice. Double-strain into a sherbet glass. Garnish with 6 mint sprigs and 4 dashes of Angostura bitters.
Ingredients: FEW bourbon;Fresh lemon juice;Simple syrup;Tempus Fugit crème de cacao;Green Chartreuse;Egg white
Garnish: 6 Mint sprigs;4 dashes of Angostura bitters

Name: La Bruja Dulce
About: La Bruja Dulce is a witch’s brew of high-quality rye and stand-out liqueurs. The spirit-forward cocktail perfectly balances sweet and spicy flavors.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir. Pour into a bucket glass and garnish with an orange twist.
Ingredients: FEW rye;Luxardo Amaretto di Saschira liqueur;Ancho Reyes ancho chile liqueur;Leopold Bros. maraschino liqueur;Bittercube Corazón bitters;Bittercube Jamaican #1 bitters

Name: Wabash Avenue Sour
About: The Wabash Avenue Sour updates the Whiskey Sour by adding Chicago’s own FEW bourbon or rye. And that’s not the only ingredient shaking up the classic recipe.
HowToMake: Add all ingredients and dry-shake (without ice) then add ice and shake again. Strain into coupe and garnish with rhubarb bitters.
Ingredients: FEW bourbon or rye;Fresh lemon juice;Cherry liqueur (Cherry Heering or Luxardo Sangue Morlacco);Small Hand Foods pineapple gum syrup;Egg white

Name: Lunar Eclipse
About: At upscale Dallas gastropub Victor Tangos bartender Matt Ragan wanted to offer his guests a turmeric-infused vodka drink that could give them a nice healthy buzz.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over ice and garnish with a celery stick. *Turmeric-infused vodka: Combine 1 stick chopped turmeric and 750 mL vodka and let infuse for 24 hours. Check to taste and let infuse longer as needed. Strain.
Ingredients: Turmeric-infused vodka;Carrot juice;honey;Freshly squeezed lemon juice

Name: Vodka Red Bull
About: Sometimes you want an expertly made and well-balanced cocktail. And sometimes you want some booze and artificial energy. Enter the Vodka Red Bull once and arguably still quite popular at many city clubs and beyond.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients to a highball glass over ice and stir.
Ingredients: Vodka;Red Bull can

Name: Blow Job
About: This layered shot originated around the early ’90s in the U.S. and is meant to be imbibed hands-free.
HowToMake: In a shot glass slowly pour the amaretto then the Irish cream and top it with the whipped cream without mixing. .
Ingredients: Amaretto liqueur;Irish cream liqueur;Whipped cream

Name: Vodka Gimlet
About: The Vodka Gimlet is not a drink to be toyed with. Unlike its gin counterpart which can slink and sway beneath a periodic table of botanicals a good Vodka Gimlet should be two things and two things only: cold and strong. Keep your vodka in the freezer—and keep it away from the bottle of Rose’s collecting dust on your bar. The concentrated lime cordial upon which many a Gimlet has suffered is no substitute for fresh-squeezed lime juice and sugar syrup.
HowToMake: Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a lime wheel.
Ingredients: Vodka;Fresh lime juice;Simple syrup

Name: Asian Pear
About: HKB baijiu was created as a “gateway” baijiu for the Western palate. Orson Salicetti at New York City’s Lumos uses it in this cocktail for its floral lightly sweet notes which complement the pear juice and liqueur. With the inclusion of agave and lime this is essentially a sour with some additional components.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a coupe glass and garnish with a fresh sage leaf. *Lumos spice elixir: Infuse 1 part allspice clove and cinnamon separately in 3 parts baijiu. After 3 weeks strain and taste each infusion then combine the infusions. Transfer to a dropper and use by single drops as it is very powerful.
Ingredients: HKB baijiu;White pear juice;Maraschino liqueur;Pear liqueur;Lumos spice elixir;Agave syrup;Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice

Name: The Kir Royale: The Ultimate Champagne Cocktai
About: The best-known Champagne cocktail the Kir Royale turns any glass of bubbly into a special occasion.
HowToMake: Pour the crème de cassis into a Champagne flute. Top with the sparkling wine. Garnish with a lemon twist.
Ingredients: Crème de Cassis;Dry sparkling wine to top

Name: Smoke on the Water
About: This day-drinking-ready cocktail from Carlos Perez at Chicago’s Nellcote is simultaneously elegant and ready to blaze.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a rocks glass. Soak a fresh rosemary sprig upside down with 100-proof alcohol for five minutes. Put the sprig upright in the rocks glass and light right before the first sip.
Ingredients: Banhez Mezcal Artesanal;Cointreau;Hibiscus simple syrup;Fresh watermelon juice;Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice

Name: Maple Smoked Rumhattan
About: This drink from Zak Doy of Toronto’s Rush Lane & Co. enlists the help of a maple plank for smoking the inside of a glass (and reinforces Canadian pride of course).
HowToMake: Char the maple plank with the flame from a blowtorch then cover the smoking surface with the glass so the smoke coats the inside of the glass with the maple aromatic. Add all of ingredients to the smoked glass with one large ice cube and stir to combine.
Ingredients: Maple plank;Mount Gay Extra Old rum;Bénédictine;Fernet-Branca;Angostura bitters;Smoked mezcal bitters

Name: Holywater
About: “The fire caramelizes the sugar giving the drink depth and added richness” says Lauren Schell of Seaworthy in New Orleans. “It’s a crucial element of balance in addition to being eye-catching and purposefully interactive.” The Chartreuse-meets-sugar fire inside a hollowed-out lime might be simple to create but is a visual stunner while simultaneously helping to balance out the drink’s citrus notes.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients except for the Chartreuse bitters and sugar cube into a shaker and dry-shake. Pour into a chilled rock glass top with crushed ice and float 3 dashes of Angostura bitters. Hollow out a lime half and place it cut side up on top of the drink. Add the Chartreuse and sugar cube to the lime half. Light the lime half aiming for the Chartreuse let it burn for 10 to 15 seconds and blow out the flame.
Ingredients: Spiced rum;Cognac;Orgeat Syrup;Lime juice;Lemon juice;Grapefruit juice;Angostura bitters;Green Chartreuse;Sugar cube

Name: Spiked Hot Chocolat
About: A perfectly decadent after-dinner treat for your next party. Set out a few bottles of your favorite spirits and liqueurs and let your guests choose their own adventure.
HowToMake: Put the chopped chocolate in an Irish Coffee mug. Pour the hot milk into the mug and let stand for 2 minutes then stir with a spoon until smooth. Pour in the spirit of your choice and stir to combine. Garnish with mini marshmallows.
Ingredients: Finely chopped semisweet chocolate;Hot milk;Spirit of Choice

Name: Stone Fence
About: This two-ingredient autumnal classic is traditionally made using two ounces of rye bourbon rum or brandy and topped with apple cider.
HowToMake: Add the spirit and bitters to a Collins glass over ice. Fill the glass to the brim with the cider and stir. Garnish with a mint sprig.
Ingredients: Rye bourbon rum or brandy;Angostura bitters;Apple cider

Name: Cardinal Penicillin
About: This variation of the Penicillin is a local favorite at The Punch Room at The Ritz-Carlton Charlotte and is made with honey from beehives at the restaurant’s rooftop garden and locally grown ginger.
HowToMake: Rim a rocks glass with smoked lava sea salt. Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Double-strain into the prepared glass over ice. *Honey ginger syrup: Add 2 cups water and 3 thumb-size pieces of peeled and thinly sliced ginger to a small pot and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer for 30 minutes. Add 1.5 cups local honey strain out the ginger and let cool. Store in the refrigerator. Keeps up to 3 weeks.
Ingredients: Cardinal Barrel Rested gin;House-made honey ginger syrup;Freshly squeezed lemon juice

Name: Draw Play
About: For football season we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.“I’m a lifelong San Diego Chargers fan and travel every year to see my Bolts play” says bartender Vincent Toscano of Rye in San Francisco. “In honor of the team this drink is refreshing because every week is a new beginning and bittersweet because we don’t always win.”Toscano uses bourbon American whiskey because football is America’s sport. “And Wild Turkey should be America’s bourbon” he says. “I like the family aspect of it. When you meet [Wild Turkey distillers] Jimmy Eddie and Bruce they are such genuine and honest people. It shows in their whiskeys. They don’t try to put a spin on their product or have this fantasy world of a story. They are bourbon makers first and foremost.”
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients except the blood orange soda to a shaker with ice and shake until cold. Fine-strain over ice into a Collins glass fill to top with the soda and garnish with a basil leaf and straw.
Ingredients: Wild Turkey 101 bourbon;Cynar;Lemon juice;Honey syrup (1:1 honey:water);Basil leaves;Bundaberg blood orange soda

Name: Gold Rusher
About: For football season we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.“The original 49ers were gold seekers that came through California in 1849 during the Gold Rush” says bartender Helen Diaz of Bloodhound and Churchill in San Francisco. “When I think about the 49ers I think Gold Rush and then I think of the Gold Rush cocktail. This is the Gold Rusher! What better way to represent this team but to add a little fernet to the drink?” she says calling on the fact that San Francisco consumes more fernet than any other place in the country.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until cold. Double-strain over a large handcut chunk of ice into a rocks glass and garnish with a mint sprig. *Ginger solution: Heat 1 part water in a small pot over medium heat. Add 1 part sugar and 1 part ginger juice and stir until the sugar is completely dissolved. Remove from heat and let cool before using.
Ingredients: Bourbon;Fernet-Branca;Fresh lemon juice;Ginger solution;Honey syrup (3:1 honey:water);Angostura bitters

Name: Abbott Road
About: For football season we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.“Our goal in creating a cocktail for the Bills was to capture the pride of the fans whose loyalty is steadfast win or lose” says bartender Jeff Yannuzzi of Buffalo’s Toutant
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until cold. Double-strain over a large ice cube into a rocks glass and garnish with an apple skin twist and green apple foam. *Concord grape shrub: Combine 1 cup pureed concorde grapes (pushed through a sieve to remove seeds and skins) with 1 cup raw sugar in a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the sugar is completely dissolved. Add 1/4 cup white wine vinegar 1/4 cup red wine vinegar and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil and allow to reduce by half. Cool to room temperature before using. Will keep in the refrigerator for at least 1 month. **Green apple foam: In a bowl combine 450 grams Granny Smith apple juice 10 grams citric acid 120 grams granulated sugar and 5 grams gelatin. Stir and pour into an iSi canister and charge once before using to top the drink.
Ingredients: Tommyrotter American gin;Concord grape shrub;Lockhouse Ibisco bitter;Honey syrup (2:1 honey:water)

Name: Death Star
About: For football season we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.“I have been a Cowboys fan since I was about six years old” says bartender Peter Novotny of Dallas’ Armoury D.E. “I go to games when I can but getting a good seat at the Death Star [the nickname for the Cowboys stadium] costs a pretty penny. I usually end up tailgating and sitting in the cheap seats or party-pass seats.” This bright blue riff on a Margarita is a nod to the Cowboys team colors. Novotny even stencils a Cowboys star onto the top of the drink.
HowToMake: Rim a coupe glass with salt. Add all of the ingredients to shaker and dry-shake (without ice) to aerate the ingredients with the egg white. Wet-shake (with ice) and fine-strain into the prepared glass. Use a star stencil and spray a blue curaçao star on top of the drink. *Cinnamon agave syrup: Simmer 6 cinnamon sticks in a 1:1 agave:water simple syrup for 5 minutes. Remove from heat and let cool. Discard cinnamon sticks before using.
Ingredients: Tequila Cabeza blanco;Green Chartreuse;Giffard blue curaçao liqueur;Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice;Cinnamon agave syrup;Egg white

Name: Rye-se Up
About: For football season we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.AMER bartender David Petro’s Atlanta Falcons–inspired cocktail is made with rye whiskey and is served up as he says “to represent the Falcons high-flying offense.” The deep red color evokes the team’s color. Petro uses lemon sherbet to deepen the flavors of the drink and egg white to give it a nice rich texture.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until frothy and very cold. Strain into a coupe and garnish with a cherry and grating of orange zest.
Ingredients: Rittenhouse rye;Cherry Heering liqueur;Freshly squeezed lemon juice;Lemon sherbet;Cappelletti Amaro Sfumato Rabarbaro;Egg white;Cane sugar simple syrup;Angostura bitters;Peychaud’s bitters

Name: Little FIB
About: For football season we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. Hastings Cameron a bartender at several Madison Wisc. bars including Imaginary Bar describes this cocktail tribute to the Green Bay Packers as a “perverse Shamrock shake” in which the mint and fennel of Strega are fortified by similar notes in gin from Death’s Door Spirits a Wisconsin distillery. “I grew up in Chicago rooting for the Packers as a little contrarian” says Cameron. “As an adult I still love blue and orange (mostly orange) but couldn’t possibly care less about the Bears or the Cubs for that matter” he says. While this drink was purely aesthetically inspired by the Packers’ team colors—“Lil Wayne didn’t need anything more than the team’s colors to inspire this” says Cameron—it involves a pretty complex matcha foam evidence of Cameron’s tendency toward molecular gastronomy-like bartending. The booziness of the cocktail is inspired by the ice-cold winters in Wisconsin. “Drink builds tend to swell in volume the farther north we get from Madison. The 2.5 ounces of 80-plus-proof booze is a nod to that cultural imperative” he says.
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a coupe express the oil of a lime peel and garnish with the peel. Top with matcha foam. *Matcha foam: Whisk 10 grams matcha with 600 grams hot water. Divide the tea evenly into 2 plastic containers. While still hot add .95 percent gelatin by mass to the first container and whisk. Allow the second container to cool then whisk in 2 percent xanthan gum by mass. Combine the two containers and whisk in 1 barspoon hydrated gomme. Whisk in 100 grams of simple syrup and a pinch of ascorbic acid. Place in an ice bath to cool completely. Fill an iSi canister with ice water to cool. After 15 minutes empty the water and fill the canister with the matcha foam base. Screw on the lid add charge shake vent add second charge shake vent add third charge shake vent.
Ingredients: Liquore Strega;Tequila Ocho Plata;Death’s Door gin;Dolin dry vermouth;Clear Creek muscat grappa;St. George Spirits Green Chile vodka;Saline solution (or tiny pinch of salt)
Brands: Clear Creek;Death’s Door Spirits;Dolin;St. George Spirits;Strega;Tequila Ocho

Name: Front Seven
About: For football season we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.“The D line and the linebackers are the strongest group in the Ram’s current lineup” says John Coltharp the head bartender at Los Angeles’ Seven Grand. “This stiff cocktail is a tribute to those seven players; it also features the earthy flavors the Rams want the opposing running back to experience when they shove his face into the ground.”
HowToMake: Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until cold. Strain into a rocks glass over ice. Express the oil from a lemon peel over top of the drink and garnish with the peel on the ice skin up.
Ingredients: Slow Hand white whiskey;Cynar;Campari;Orange bitters;Peychaud's bitters

Name: Prairie Buzz
About: The ideal nightcap for the coffee-inclined the combination of cold brew and chinato in this cocktail by The Bennett in New York City make for the perfect balance of caffeinated zip and herbal calm.
HowToMake: Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake. Strain over one rock into a rocks glass and garnish with a dusting of ground nutmeg.
Ingredients: Rieger’s Kansas City whiskey;Vino chinato;Cinnamon syrup;Cold-brew coffee;Amaretto liqueur;Cream

Name: Lynx
About: If you’re looking to add a little chill to your pre-dinner coffee but don’t quite want to go the cold-brew route the Lynx at Cambridge Mass.’s Park is the cocktail for you. Instead of serving the drink over ice the chilling agent is actually a giant frozen cube of coffee. (This idea could get very dangerous very fast.)
HowToMake: Combine all of the ingredients except for the cube of coffee in a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a rocks glass over the large frozen coffee cube.
Ingredients: Maison Rouge cognac;Cream;Amaro Meletti;Simple syrup;Large frozen cube of coffee

Name: Spark & Stormy
About: Who says coffee cocktails can’t be a little topical? This creation from Vance Henderson of Drambuie
HowToMake: Combine all of the ingredients except for the club soda in a shaker with ice and shake. Double-strain over fresh ice in a Collins glass and top with the club soda. Garnish with 3 fresh basil leaves.
Ingredients: Drambuie;Mezcal;Chameleon coffee concentrate;Pineapple juice;Club soda to top

Name: Shoulda Benne Pirate
About: This sweet locally inspired coffee drink from Harold’s Cabin in Charleston S.C. adds a crumble of benne seed wafers a South Carolina low country staple for a unique crunchy garnish. If you can’t find benne seed wafers use thin sesame wafers instead.
HowToMake: Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with benne seed wafer crumble. *Strawberry-infused Striped Pig rum: Fill a Mason jar with halved strawberries and add Striped Pig rum to completely cover the strawberries. Store in a cool dark place for up to 2 weeks. The berries will turn ghost white. Strain through a metal strainer into a second jar. Keeps for 3 months.
Ingredients: Strawberry-infused Striped Pig rum;Cold-brew coffee;Baileys Irish cream;Simple syrup;Egg white

Name: Midnight Oil
About: “The Midnight Oil brings to life in cocktail form one of my all-time favorite snack combos: a morning coffee and a slice or two of banana bread” says bartender Brett Esler of Whisler’s in Austin. “With an aged rum base a touch of the Domaine de Canton ginger liqueur for a little depth and some vanilla extract to round it out you have yourself a slightly caffeinated fall-driven sipper.”
HowToMake: Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a coupe and garnish with a skewered bruleed banana slice.
Ingredients: Mount Gay Black Barrel rum;Stumptown cold-brew coffee;Domaine de Canton ginger liqueur;Giffard Banane du Brésil liqueur;Vanilla extract

Name: Espresso Milk Punch
